The RCMP have charged a man whom they say has been driving without a driver’s license for 15 years and was allegedly driving impaired with his grandchild in the vehicle earlier this month. Mounties reportedly pulled over a vehicle on Highway 1 near Swift Current, Saskatchewan, on May 14 for a license check. The driver presented officers with a Saskatchewan photo ID card and admitted to not having a driver’s license, according to the police. Upon further investigation, it was found that his license had expired in 2005.

Subsequently, the police began an impaired driving investigation and claim that the driver provided a breath sample that was 1.5 times over the legal limit. The 55-year-old man from Regina is now facing multiple charges, including impaired driving and consuming alcohol in a motor vehicle. He is scheduled to appear in Swift Current provincial court in September.

Additionally, the police reported that the eight-year-old child who was also in the vehicle was taken to the Swift Current detachment. There, the child colored pictures and had lunch until his mother arrived.

Harris Grill, a well-known Pittsburgh eatery with locations in Downtown and Shadyside, has announced that it is permanently closing its Fourth Avenue location in Downtown Pittsburgh. The last day of service at this location will be Thursday, December 30.

In a press release, the Harris Grill team cited struggles to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic as the reason behind the closure. "The Harris Grill 4th Avenue has struggled to remain open since the Coronavirus pandemic descended in March of 2020," the release stated. "With the loss of the downtown business office population and cancellation of cultural trust activities, sales have been down 75%." While some business has returned, the restaurant noted that "there is simply not enough continuing and regular foot traffic for the number of restaurants currently attempting to operate downtown."

The decision by some Downtown offices to delay or modify their return to in-person work has also impacted Harris Grill's cash flow issues. Furthermore, Allegheny County is still experiencing a high number of COVID-19 daily cases, and officials expect the situation to worsen as the Omicron variant spreads and people travel and socialize for the winter holidays.

Swansea head coach Steve Cooper praised his team for handing striker Rhian Brewster the chance to grab the headlines after an impressive Sky Bet Championship victory at Middlesbrough. The 20-year-old Liverpool loanee scored twice in three minutes as the visitors ran out 3-0 winners at the Riverside Stadium. His brace and Andre Ayew’s penalty effectively clinched the points after only 34 minutes.

Cooper said: “In the first half in particular, he looked a real threat. He got his two goals – he was disappointed he didn’t have three. He’s a really good player, but we are a team that likes to play as a team. Rhian obviously will get some headlines today because he’s got a brace, but it’s as a consequence of the team playing the way we want to play.”

Brewster celebrated his 18th-minute opener by holding up a t-shirt bearing the message “Our colour is not a crime” in support of the Black Lives Matter campaign on a day when the players of both sides and the match officials took a knee before kick-off. Cooper said: “Rhian has a voice like everybody else and we all support each other. We’re as one here and it was just another example of that.”

The England Under-21 international doubled his tally in the 21st minute before Ayew completed the job from the spot, in the process maintaining the Swans’ bid for a play-off place. Cooper said: “We’ve always been in the mix. We’ve never been too far away from the play-off positions if we haven’t been in them, and that will continue after this weekend. We have just got to make sure that we just focus on the next game. The games are getting less and less and time is precious. We have got to make sure that we maximise everything that’s in our hands.”

Boro head coach Jonathan Woodgate admitted he was left “stunned” on the sidelines by a first-half display which belied what he had seen on the training ground earlier in the week. Woodgate said: “It’s hard to explain that type of performance. It wasn’t nice to see. In the week if you had seen how we were training, it was very good and to turn in a performance like that isn’t good enough.

The body of a man found wrapped in cloth on the roadside near Lohiya Garden in Magarpatta, Hadapsar on Friday has been identified as Santosh (34), a resident of Malwadi, Hadapsar.  Police have confirmed the death to be a murder.

Santosh, who lived with unidentified roommates, was employed by caterer Narayan Vyas (30) in Loni Kalbhor.  He had previously worked for another caterer, Jayesh Kadam (32), also a Hadapsar resident.  Santosh had taken a temporary assignment with Vyas on December 31st.

According to Senior Police Inspector Balkrushna Kadam of Hadapsar police station, Jayesh Kadam discovered Santosh's body at Vyas's establishment on the morning of January 1st after receiving a call that Santosh was unresponsive.  Fearing the implications of having a dead body, Kadam placed Santosh in a tempo.  He attempted to locate Santosh's residence in Malwadi but was unsuccessful, ultimately disposing of the body near Lohiya Garden.

A post-mortem conducted at Sassoon General Hospital revealed that Santosh had been strangled. Consequently, a murder case (Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code) was registered at Hadapsar police station and subsequently transferred to Loni Kalbhor police station.

The Pittsburgh Steelers held their final practice before Monday’s game against Washington, and three key players were missing.  Starting quarterback Ben Roethlisberger (knee) was held out and listed as questionable, as was starting cornerback Steven Nelson (knee), who is doubtful for Monday.  Placekicker Chris Boswell (hip) was also sidelined and is questionable for the game.

Nelson’s absence is expected, as he suffered a knee injury against Baltimore on Wednesday and underwent an MRI on Thursday.  Boswell’s hip issue, however, is new, as he wasn't on the injury report before Saturday. If Boswell can't play, the Steelers will likely elevate Matthew Wright from the practice squad.  The Steelers signed Wright just five days ago, choosing him over Brandon Wright, a 23-year-old rookie from Georgia State, after a tryout.

At the time, it appeared Wright's signing was a precaution against a COVID-19 emergency, as the Steelers also added a backup long-snapper to the practice squad. But the move may also have been  preemptive, given Boswell’s hip.

Wright, a Central Florida alum, isn't entirely new to the Steelers, although he hasn't kicked in a regular-season NFL game.  He signed with Pittsburgh as an undrafted free agent in 2019 and competed with Boswell for the placekicking job during the preseason, converting five of six field goal attempts.  The Steelers ultimately stuck with Boswell, who rewarded them with a resurgent 2019 season and a stellar 2020 performance (16 of 17 field goals made).

# Top Gun: Maverick - Everything You Need to Know

The need for speed returns to theaters after more than three decades. Following years of anticipation, *Top Gun: Maverick*, the sequel to the 1986 classic, is finally arriving with Tom Cruise reprising his iconic role alongside other familiar faces.

After the release of the first official trailer in July and a second in mid-December, here's a comprehensive look at what we know about this highly anticipated sequel, scheduled for release in June 2020.

## Quick Facts
- **Title**: Top Gun: Maverick
- **Release Date**: June 26, 2020
- **Cast**: Tom Cruise, Val Kilmer, Miles Teller, Jennifer Connelly, Jon Hamm
- **Director**: Joseph Kosinski

## Latest Trailer
The December 16 trailer offers an extended look into the cockpit with Cruise's character. It opens with Maverick executing daring aerial maneuvers while a voiceover establishes his legendary status at the Top Gun flight academy. Now serving as an instructor, Maverick demonstrates his hands-on teaching approach by challenging students to two-on-one dogfights, quickly proving why his reputation precedes him.

The trailer skillfully pays tribute to iconic scenes from the original: pilots' bar singalongs, occasional brawls, Maverick's high-speed motorcycle rides with his new love interest (Jennifer Connelly), and athletic beach scenes—though this time featuring football rather than volleyball.

## Production Details
Jon Hamm highlighted the film's groundbreaking technical achievements in a May 2019 interview with Collider: "They're using technology never before seen. We're shooting in 6K, delivering incredibly high-definition footage. The aerial sequences are mind-blowing—and mostly practical, with real pilots experiencing actual G-forces."

## Cast Breakdown
- **Tom Cruise** returns as Pete "Maverick" Mitchell
- **Val Kilmer** reprises his role as Tom "Iceman" Kazansky
- **Miles Teller** plays Goose's son, sporting a mustache reminiscent of Anthony Edwards' original character
- **Jennifer Connelly** joins as a single mother running a local bar
- **Jon Hamm** and **Ed Harris** round out the stellar cast in undisclosed roles

## Behind the Scenes
Joseph Kosinski (*Oblivion*, *TRON: Legacy*) directs, with original producer Jerry Bruckheimer returning. Kenny Loggins plans to record an updated version of "Danger Zone," potentially collaborating with contemporary artists to reimagine the iconic soundtrack.

# Foxconn to Manufacture Face Masks Amid Coronavirus Crisis

Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, announced Thursday it will begin producing surgical face masks at its Shenzhen factory alongside Apple products in response to the novel coronavirus outbreak.

"Face masks are now the standard equipment in our fight against the epidemic," Foxconn stated in a 1,200-word announcement on its WeChat social media platform. "Every second counts in this battle, the sooner we can ensure a supply of these goods, the sooner we can stop the epidemic, save lives and get through these difficult times."

The company, officially known as Hon Hai Precision Industry, has already completed test production and is seeking certification. "We anticipate being able to produce 20 million masks by the end of February," according to the Foxconn statement.

## Impact on Operations and Economy

Foxconn's extensive network of Chinese factories is scheduled to resume operations on February 10, following an extended Lunar New Year holiday caused by the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. The virus has now spread to more than 20 countries, with mainland China reporting over 31,000 confirmed infections and 636 deaths.

The global health crisis is expected to affect international supply chains and manufacturing, given China's crucial role in the global economy. Foxconn has already revised its sales forecast, with chairman Young Liu telling Bloomberg News the company now projects a sales increase of one to three percent this year, down from January's forecast of three to five percent.

A recent study suggests that red wine, particularly a plant compound called resveratrol found in it, may have beneficial effects on depression and anxiety for those who enjoy a glass in the evening. Resveratrol is known for its potential heart health benefits, and the study published in Neuropharmacology now indicates that it could also aid in alleviating depression and anxiety symptoms.

The study, which focused on the impact of resveratrol in mice and built upon previous in vitro research, concluded that resveratrol may help protect against corticosterone, a stress hormone associated with depression and anxiety. While resveratrol is just one of the compounds in red wine, it is important to note that alcohol, as a whole, acts as a depressant on the body’s central nervous system (CNS). Although CNS depressants may not induce immediate feelings of sadness, prolonged use can lead to lethargy, muscle weakness, agitation, and impaired judgment.

Moreover, alcohol consumption can disrupt the sleep-wake cycle and cause attention deficits, potentially leading to issues such as blackouts. While temporary feelings of euphoria and altered judgment may accompany alcohol consumption, sustained and heavy use can have lasting effects on memory and immune functions. These effects are commonly associated with depression, such as disrupted sleep, altered judgment, lethargy, agitation, and muscle weakness.

The relationship between red wine, depression, and anxiety is multifaceted. While resveratrol has shown promise in lowering stress hormone levels linked to these conditions, it is essential to consider the broader impact of alcohol consumption. Scientific knowledge has long suggested that red wine can benefit heart health due to its polyphenol antioxidants, including resveratrol. However, recent research indicates that individuals with diets naturally high in resveratrol do not necessarily have reduced risks of heart disease or cancer.

Dr. Kenneth Mukamal from Harvard Health advises putting claims of resveratrol's heart health benefits into context alongside other lifestyle factors and alcohol consumption. Understanding the effects of different drinking patterns and types of alcoholic beverages is crucial. While acknowledging the potential anti-depression and anti-anxiety effects of resveratrol in red wine, it is essential to consider the broader impact of alcohol on the CNS.

# Stoneham Fire Department Battles House Fire, Rescues Family Dog

STONEHAM -- Stoneham Fire Department responded to a house fire at 164 North St. on Nov. 6, Chief Matthew Grafton reports.

The incident began at 1:49 p.m. when a neighbor alerted a passing Stoneham Police officer to smoke coming from the home. Upon arrival, firefighters observed smoke and flames inside the home and immediately struck a second alarm.

While no residents were home during the fire, crews successfully rescued a dog found on the second floor. "All of the responding crews did a great job working quickly as a team to bring this incident under control," Grafton said. "I'm grateful that nobody was hurt, including the family dog who was able to be removed and brought to safety outside."

Multiple units responded to the scene, including:
- Stoneham Fire's Ladder 1 and Engines 3 and 5
- Mutual aid from Woburn, Reading, Wakefield, Winchester and Melrose Fire Departments
- Boston Sparks Rehab Unit
- Stoneham Police Department
- Stoneham Department of Public Works
- Action Ambulance

Firefighters extinguished flames on the first floor but discovered the fire had extended into the walls and attic. While crews battled the blaze, the Medford, Malden and Saugus Fire Departments provided station coverage in Stoneham.

The single-family home is currently uninhabitable. The American Red Cross is assisting residents with finding alternative shelter.

The fire is believed to have originated on the first floor. Stoneham Police and Fire investigators are working with the State Fire Marshal's Office to determine the cause.

PARIS - US Open champion Sloane Stephens stated on Tuesday that her friendship with Madison Keys remains unaffected, despite their upcoming French Open semi-final match at Roland Garros, a rematch of last year's final at Flushing Meadows. The 10th seed delivered a commanding performance to defeat Russian Daria Kasatkina, who had previously eliminated world number two Caroline Wozniacki, with a score of 6-3, 6-1 on Court Philippe Chatrier in the quarter-finals. Earlier in the day, the 13th seed Keys secured a spot in the semi-finals for the first time by defeating Kazakhstan's Yulia Putintseva 7-6 (7/5), 6-4.

Stephens, who clinched her first Grand Slam title in New York last September with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Keys, emphasized that their off-court relationship will not be affected by their upcoming on-court clash. She shared, "When we step onto the court, it's time to compete. But until then, there will be no awkwardness or tension between us." Stephens narrowly avoided an early exit in the third round against Camila Giorgi before securing an 8-6 victory in the deciding set.

This year marks the first time since 2002 that two American women have reached the semi-finals at Roland Garros, with Serena Williams prevailing over sister Venus in that year's final after a semi-final victory against Jennifer Capriati. Stephens, who was ranked 957th just six weeks before her maiden Grand Slam triumph last year due to injury setbacks, has now made it to a major semi-final for the third time. Reflecting on the achievement, the 25-year-old remarked, "Having two Americans in the semi-finals of the French Open is pretty remarkable. It guarantees that at least one American will be in the final, which is truly special. Overall, it's a situation where no one has anything to complain about."

During her match against Kasatkina, Stephens and her opponent exchanged breaks early in the match. Stephens' powerful shots in the eighth game earned her the opportunity to serve for the set, which she successfully did, including a stunning backhand drop shot. In the second set, despite Kasatkina starting strong with a service hold, Stephens broke in the third game with a sharp cross-court forehand and sailed to victory after just an hour and 10 minutes of play.

Keys, on the other hand, demonstrated her prowess by hitting 30 winners against Putintseva to secure her semi-final spot. Although Keys struggled under pressure at the US Open last year, she is confident that this experience will not impact her upcoming match at Roland Garros. In her match against Putintseva, Keys displayed mental resilience, bouncing back from a break in the seventh game to claim the set in a tie-break.

Looking ahead, two-time champion Maria Sharapova is set to face 2016 winner Garbine Muguruza in the other half of the draw, while world number one Simona Halep will take on double Grand Slam champion Angelique Kerber on Wednesday.

# Discover Financial Posts Strong Q1, Eyes International Expansion

*By Jochelle Mendonca*  
*March 21 (Reuters)*

Discover Financial Services reported first-quarter earnings that significantly exceeded Wall Street expectations for the eighth consecutive quarter, driven by increased credit card usage among American consumers. The company also announced plans to accelerate its international expansion efforts.

## Financial Highlights
- Earnings reached $624 million, or $1.18 per share, up from $459 million ($0.84 per share) a year ago
- Analysts had expected earnings of $0.94 per share
- Total loans grew 9% to $56.3 billion
- Credit card loans increased by $1.6 billion to $45.9 billion
- Transaction volume in payment services rose 8% to $46.7 billion

## Credit Quality Improvements
The company reported stronger credit quality metrics, indicating improving consumer financial health:
- Loan loss provisions decreased 64% to $152 million
- Delinquency rates for loans over 30 days past due fell 137 basis points to 2.22%
- However, the company cautioned that loan loss provisions may increase later in 2012 as loan balances grow

## International Expansion Strategy
Unlike its larger competitor American Express, which already maintains a strong international presence, Discover is now taking steps to expand beyond U.S. borders:
- Recently signed an agreement with Diners Club Ecuador to issue Discover cards
- Partnered with National Payments Corporation of India for transaction processing
- These moves aim to reduce dependence on the U.S. market for future growth

"We believe it will allow us to market test a model that could eventually become a framework for expanding Discover branded card issuance into additional countries with what to-date has been a purely domestic model," said Chief Executive David Nelms during the post-earnings conference call.

## Corporate Updates
- Announced a $2 billion share buyback program following Federal Reserve approval
- Shares closed at $31.64 on the New York Stock Exchange
- Stock has gained over 40% in the past year

Like American Express, Discover operates both as a direct consumer lender and competes with Visa Inc and MasterCard Inc in transaction processing for banks.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio (WDTN) –  Clark County health officials are celebrating the volunteers who have been instrumental in running their COVID-19 vaccination clinics during this year’s National Volunteer Week.  Approximately 150 people have donated their time at the Clark County Combined Health District’s clinic located at the Upper Valley Mall, according to Sandy Miller, the district’s Medical Reserve Corps coordinator and nursing supervisor.

"I felt I had the time, the knowledge, and the ability to make a difference," said Dr. John Dobson, one of the volunteers.  Dr. Dobson, a recently retired orthopedic surgeon with over 30 years of experience, traded his scalpel for a needle a year ago to vaccinate his fellow community members.

"It's been rewarding," Dr. Dobson remarked. "The people coming in to be vaccinated are incredibly positive and grateful to be here."

Volunteers comprise up to two-thirds of the staff at the clinic, Miller explained.  They come from both medical and non-medical backgrounds and undergo comprehensive training before volunteering.

"We simply couldn't do it without them," Miller emphasized. "It would be impossible. We wouldn't have the necessary manpower or resources."

Due to a recent decline in demand for the vaccine, the clinic has been scaled down, Miller noted.  Volunteers like Dr. Dobson hope to see an increase in vaccinations soon.

"I feel for the people who aren't getting vaccinated," he expressed. "I'm glad for those who are, as they're protected. But the unvaccinated population remains at risk."

# Foreign Minister Emphasizes Voting Rights for Overseas Pakistanis

ISLAMABAD — Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi announced Friday that the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) government aims to integrate overseas Pakistanis into the nation's political system by granting them voting rights.

Speaking virtually to elected Pakistani Americans, including members of the Pakistani American Council and various city mayors and deputy mayors, Qureshi highlighted the significant contributions of overseas Pakistanis to the country's economy. He particularly praised the Pakistani American community, noting their special importance to Prime Minister Imran Khan, and credited the diaspora for achieving record foreign remittances this year.

"We envision a system where dual nationals can actively participate in elections," Qureshi stated.

The Foreign Minister briefed the audience on the government's economic achievements, emphasizing their success in managing the COVID-19 pandemic through strategic initiatives. He also outlined the administration's shift in foreign policy focus from geo-political to geo-economic considerations.

Qureshi called upon elected Pakistani Americans to strengthen bilateral relations between Pakistan and the United States through their influential positions.

This announcement follows the National Assembly's recent passage of the Election Act Amendment Bill, 2020. The bill, presented by Dr. Babar Awan, Adviser to the Prime Minister on Parliamentary Affairs, introduces numerous electoral reforms, including voting rights for overseas Pakistanis. The amended legislation modifies the Election Act, 2017, marking a significant step toward inclusive democratic participation.

CONAKRY, Guinea (AP) — Guinea's opposition parties announced on Wednesday that they will not participate in the legislative elections scheduled for February. They intend to push for a delay unless the president withdraws his bid to seek another term. 

The opposition's statement follows last year's massive demonstrations where tens of thousands urged President Alpha Condé not to amend the constitution to allow him a third term. At least nine people were killed during one of the protests in October. 

At least five parties have declared their intent not to take part in the February 16 vote. They have also called for new demonstrations on January 13 to protest both the legislative elections and Condé's proposed constitutional changes. 

"Not only will we not participate in this election, but we will also oppose its occurrence by all legal means, as it is merely a charade," stated Ousmane Gaoual Diallo, spokesperson for the Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea, one of the leading opposition parties. 

"We cannot engage in an election that is rigged, with an electoral commission president whose actions are dictated by President Alpha Condé," added Sidya Touré of the Union of Republican Forces, another opposition leader. 

Despite the opposition's declarations, Presidential adviser Souleymane Keita asserted that the vote will proceed. 

"If the opposition chooses not to participate, they will face the consequences," he said. "We will move forward with the elections on February 16, with or without the opposition." 

Condé's mandate concludes in December 2020, yet he seeks a referendum to enable a third term in the West African nation, which has a population of approximately 12 million. The 81-year-old Condé was first elected to a five-year term in 2010, marking Guinea's initial democratic transition of power since gaining independence from France in 1958. He was re-elected in 2015.

Namaste India, run by Megha Mehta, Komal Patel, and Pallavi Rane, will be serving authentic Indian street food, including the popular Aamchi Mumbai Vadapav – a bread bun filled with a fried potato filling, topped with onions and a trio of sauces.  Originally from Mumbai and now a Leeds resident for eight years, Megha and her partners are excited to participate in their first major event after a successful debut at the Indian Food Festival at Kirkgate Market last September.  "People really loved our food," she said. "We are excited and looking forward to it."

Bringing Caribbean cuisine with a twist is Kirk Hewitt of Treasure Taste, travelling from Birmingham. Returning for the ninth consecutive year is George Welton of Brown & Blond, a Leeds-based brownie business. He describes his creations as a "rich and chewy decadent treat" with flavors like cookie dough, black forest, and the best-selling raspberry white chocolate.  "Our trade at the festival has grown significantly over the years," he notes, "with return visitors and as people get to know the brand."

His menu features handmade burgers topped with slow-cooked pulled pork or beef brisket. HÀ NỘI - Of the 14 teams in the V.League 1, Sông Lam Nghệ An (SLNA) are the only team never to have played below the top tier. However, that unblemished record is in danger as they sit at the bottom of the table with only 10 points from 12 matches. After their 1-0 loss to Thanh Hóa on Sunday, acting skipper Phan Văn Đức emotionally posted on his Facebook page, calling for unity and perseverance among his teammates. The loss has placed SLNA in a precarious position, facing the risk of relegation.

SLNA’s recent struggles have prompted significant changes within the club. The result led to the resignation of president Nguyễn Hồng Thanh and coach Ngô Quang Trường last week, marking a seismic shift for the team. Despite these challenges, SLNA has a storied history, having never played below the top tier and producing many of Việt Nam’s biggest football talents. They have won three V.League 1 titles, three National Cup trophies, and four National Super Cups, alongside success at lower age levels.

In the past, SLNA has overcome tough situations. Their previous nightmare was in 2018 when they languished in last place but managed to bounce back with eight consecutive wins, finishing fourth. The team’s worst-ever finish was last year when they placed 10th. However, the club has been struggling with financial issues, affecting their ability to retain key players and make strategic signings. Many homegrown talents like Quế Ngọc Hải, Nguyễn Trọng Hoàng, Ngô Hoàng Thịnh, and Phạm Khắc Ngọc have left the team in recent years due to financial constraints.

This year, SLNA's reliance on Vietnamese international Phan Văn Đức has been evident, as he has scored five goals this season, accounting for 71 percent of the team’s total goals. The team's three foreign players have contributed only two goals, leaving Đức to shoulder much of the offensive burden. Former coach Trường admitted that SLNA is overly dependent on the 25-year-old, and other teams have managed to neutralize their threat by focusing on him.

In addition to financial woes, SLNA is suffering from an injury crisis. Key players like midfielder Đặng Văn Lắm, captain Hoàng Văn Khánh, defender Nguyễn Sỹ Nam, and striker Hồ Phúc Tịnh have been sidelined for several weeks. Despite these challenges, the team remains hopeful for a great escape as they are only three points away from Sài Gòn FC in the relegation playoff spot. SLNA's first task will be to secure three points against Hà Nội FC on Friday at home.

Hà Nội FC, currently seventh with 17 points, is also facing challenges this season, struggling defensively with 14 goals conceded. In their 25 meetings, SLNA has secured only five wins against Hà Nội FC, alongside 10 draws and 10 defeats. Coach Nguyễn Huy Hoàng of SLNA expressed determination, stating, "We must accept challenges. We are working hard and united to get through difficulties.” Meanwhile, captain Khánh aimed to inspire his teammates on social media, asserting that "Sông Lam Nghệ An will never give up!” VNS

# Neeraj Chopra's Journey to Tokyo Olympics: A Story of Comeback and Resilience

## The Triumphant Return
In a remarkable comeback, Neeraj Chopra threw 87.86m at the ACNW League Meet in Potchefstroom, South Africa, qualifying for the Tokyo Olympics by clearing the 85m mark. This achievement, coming after a 1.5-year hiatus, was particularly significant - the distance exceeded the 86.89m throw that won gold at the 2019 World Championships.

"I feel proud of making a strong comeback. Participating in a competition after 1.5 years and clearing the Olympic mark gives me immense satisfaction," Chopra says.

## The Injury Setback
The road to this comeback wasn't smooth. Following a stellar 2018, where he claimed gold at both Commonwealth Games and Asian Games and set a national record of 88.06 metres, Chopra began experiencing elbow pain in November 2018.

"I started feeling my injury back in November 2018. I continued to train, but was not having too many issues despite the pain. But it aggravated by April," he recalled. The condition worsened until he couldn't even lift a javelin, leading to surgery in May 2019.

## The Rehabilitation Journey
Post-surgery, Chopra underwent an intensive rehabilitation period, first in Mumbai and then at JSW's Inspire Institute of Sport in Bellary. He began with basic activities like cycling, gradually progressing to hand exercises and strength training.

"After surgery, I immediately started cycling, because I was unable to move my hand. Later, I started hand and strengthening exercises and slowly started gaining my strength. I kept myself motivated by setting a target for myself each day to do better than the previous day."

## World Championships Disappointment
Despite qualifying for the World Athletics Championships with an 83.90m throw in September 2018, Chopra had to withdraw due to his recovery. "I had trained really hard for the World Championships. It was constantly on my mind, whenever I was at the training. But injury ki wajah se sab gadbad ho gaya," he explained.

## The Path Forward
With the Olympic qualification secured, Chopra isn't resting on his laurels. He's already back in training, preparing for the Federation Cup and IAAF Diamond League in Doha in April, leading up to the Tokyo Olympics where he could become India's first track-and-field Olympic medalist since 1900.

"My target of qualifying for Tokyo is accomplished. From the next day onwards, I restarted my original training schedule. The preparations have begun for the Tokyo Olympics and for all the competitions that are on the road," he says.

## Mental Resilience
Throughout his recovery, Chopra maintained a positive attitude. "Everyone told me that injuries are a part of an athlete's life'. They told me not to worry too much about time off the track and just focus on my recovery."

"I believed I could qualify for Tokyo because I was having a good time at the training. Everything was working out and bhaari haath chal raha tha. So, I was expecting a good comeback. But the fact that I qualified on my first attempt, it makes me really happy," he concluded.

Usain Bolt's arrival on the Central Coast has already made a significant impact, so much so that Mariners coach Mike Mulvey would be thrilled to have the Olympic champion on board for a year if that's what it takes. Bolt's "indefinite" trial period with the Mariners began on Tuesday morning, amidst more hype than any A-League club has previously experienced, arguably excepting Alessandro Del Piero’s arrival at Sydney FC. Yet, this story is quite different: a 32-year-old Olympic sprinter aiming to become a successful professional footballer.

He is a work in progress, as was evident from his first training session in front of the cameras in Gosford. However, Mulvey is more than willing to keep Bolt around for the next 12 months if that's necessary to develop him into a footballer. "We’re absolutely delighted that Usain has chosen our club, this great community on the Central Coast, to pursue his ambition," Mulvey said. "If it takes 12 months, I'm happy for him to be here. He’s already attracted the largest media presence to this area. The spotlight is on the Central Coast and the people here, and I think that's fantastic. It's all fine with me."

Any notions of this being merely a gimmick or PR stunt are swiftly dismissed. At his age and with his achievements, Bolt could easily be relaxing on a Caribbean beach. Instead, the likable and humble Bolt is determined to succeed in a sport he has loved since childhood. It’s this character strength that makes having Bolt on board a pleasure for Mulvey. "You don't lower your standards when Usain Bolt walks in the door. This guy is a winner," Mulvey stated. "Eight gold medals in the Olympics. That achievement requires not just great ability but also immense mental strength. If he can pass some of that onto my players, who are working hard to climb up from the bottom, it will be invaluable for our young lads. They’re thinking, 'how far can he take me on my journey?'"

Bolt's presence at training was palpable, and it would be understandable for anyone to feel nervous under such scrutiny. "He’s a fantastic athlete, and we’re absolutely delighted to have him here with us," Mulvey added.

Juno-nominated singer-songwriter Craig Cardiff, known for his intimate performances and community engagement, led a songwriting workshop for Algonquin College students on February 7th.  Sipping a pink fruit smoothie, clad in wool socks, Cardiff sat on the floor of the small stage in the Commons corner lounge, guitar in hand. "Everybody here has something to share," he announced to the dozen participants gathered before him.

Cardiff, a seasoned performer at the college, often incorporates workshops before his concerts.  "Why not get the chance to connect with people?" he explained, highlighting his belief in the power of community involvement.  He routinely conducts these sessions in schools.

The students, eager to learn from the experienced musician, embraced the opportunity. "I really wanted to do something new," shared Anastasia Young, a first-year travel and tourism student, in an interview with the Times. Although not a musician herself, Young recognized the value of refining one's craft. "We’re always trying to make ourselves better in every area of our lives," she observed. "So why not in writing, or in our craft?"  She emphasized the benefit of feedback, believing that the perspectives of others can lead to "opportunities for growth" and collaborative projects. For Young, the presence of others in the creative process is a necessity, not a luxury.

The workshop involved small groups writing songs within a time limit set by Cardiff, culminating in performances for their peers. Among the participants were Jake Devine and Felix Ducharme, both first-year introduction to music industry arts students.  Devine, self-described as "pretty stubborn," admitted he had never co-written a song before but was open to the experience.  His motivation was clear: "I wanted to see someone else’s perspective on how they write songs.”  Similarly, Ducharme acknowledged his solitary writing habits but reconsidered after the workshop.  "I don’t write with people, but I think maybe I should start," he reflected. "Different perspectives aren’t so bad."

Cardiff expressed his hope that the workshop would foster connections beyond the session. "We spend all our time alone then wonder why we get stuck," he pointed out, underscoring the advantages of collaborative songwriting.

Following the workshop, Cardiff treated the intimate audience to a performance, his smooth voice and rhythmic fingerpicking echoing through the candlelit room.  He shared the story behind his song "Boy Inside the Boat," explaining that it was inspired by the negativity he witnessed in the world—deaths, terror attacks, and more.  "There’s always a surplus of bad things if we look for them," he remarked.

Korean-American hip-hop artist Jay Park recently reflected on his past negative comments about Korea. On October 1, Netflix released the first episode of the original show 'Paik's Spirit,' featuring Jay Park and fellow hip-hop artist Loco as guests. During a meal, Loco brought up the time when Jay Park faced heavy criticism for his past remarks.

In 2009, comments Jay Park made about Korea in 2005, shortly after he began training at JYP Entertainment, were discovered on his personal social media. Written in English to a friend, they read, "Korea is gay. I hate Koreans. I want to go back." These comments quickly spread online. Just three days later, Jay Park left his group, 2PM, and returned to his hometown of Seattle in the United States.

Reflecting on this period, Jay Park explained, "It wasn't entirely my decision to come to Korea at first. When I was asked to join JYP Entertainment, my mom suggested I should go for our future. My family was struggling financially in Seattle, and she thought I could earn good money there."

He continued, "There were many popular artists at JYP Entertainment, but I didn't know much about JYP or Korea. I went for my family. Life in Korea was very different from what I expected. It was my first time living away from my family and friends, and I had given up everything in Seattle for that. It wasn't easy for me; the cultural differences were challenging. I may have complained to my friends back in the States, and that's where those comments came from."

Jay Park added, "After I started gaining attention as the leader of 2PM, someone dug up those comments from the social media account I no longer used, and it became an issue. People kept saying, 'Jay Park hates Korea and Koreans,' but that can't be true because my parents are Korean, and I'm Korean myself."

He concluded, "Anyway, I was ignorant and thoughtless back then. I was too young, and my words came out wrong. I think I expected everyone to live like I did. I was too selfish.

A woman revealed her impressive carpet transformation, taking it from cream to a stylish grey in just over an hour using £1 worth of dye.  She shared her savvy technique in the Facebook group Mrs Hinch Cleaning Tips, explaining how she achieved the chic update with minimal effort.

"So, just want to say the Dylon in a spray bottle really does work," she wrote.  "Brought my carpet up like new as well with all the rubbing in.... this took 1.5 hours to do and cost me a total of £1 for the dye I used."

Her method involved mixing four tablespoons of Smoke Grey Dylon fabric dye with 700ml of warm water.  She used three bottles of this mixture on her carpet.  Applying the dye with a spray bottle while wearing gloves, she left it to dry overnight and reported no color transfer the next day.

Her post generated significant interest, racking up over 2,200 comments and impressing many.  "I had no idea you can dye a carpet," one person admitted. Another added, "Would never have thought of doing that, looks fab."

The Dylon Dye Pod fabric dye in Smoke Grey, which she used for the project, is currently available for around £5.  This clever hack echoes a previous story where a woman similarly transformed her brown stairs to grey using a £5 Wilko product.  This budget-friendly approach to home improvement contrasts sharply with other recent stories, such as a new mum's emotional £500,000 Grand Designs renovation and a single mum's surprise return from holiday to a £50 living room makeover courtesy of her parents.

The Director-General of the Ghana Education Service (GES), Prof. Kwasi Opoku-Amankwa, has emphasized the importance of maintaining professionalism among teachers by upholding the teacher licensure examination. During a visit to the Accra College of Education, which was hosting the Ghana Teacher Licensure Examination, he expressed concerns about the implications of reversing the progress made in aligning Ghanaian teachers with international standards.

The examination, originally scheduled for September 24 and 25, 2020, had to be rescheduled to October 1 and 2, 2020, due to changes in the academic calendar caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. A total of 31,167 newly trained teachers are participating in this two-day examination, covering topics such as Literacy, Essential Professional Skills, and Numeracy.

Prof. Opoku-Amankwa highlighted that professionalism in teaching is crucial for ensuring the quality of education in Ghana. He explained that licensing teachers and providing continuous professional development opportunities are integral components of enhancing the professionalism and effectiveness of educators.

The Director-General cited examples of other professions such as medical practitioners, lawyers, and architects, where licensing and adherence to a code of ethics are standard practice. He pointed out that countries like the United Kingdom and South Africa have already implemented teacher licensing systems to raise educational standards.

Prof. Opoku-Amankwa underscored the government's commitment to supporting teachers through initiatives like the provision of a professional development allowance and continuous professional development courses.

Altitude Film Sales has taken worldwide sales rights to the comedy feature "Dead In A Week (Or Your Money Back)," which is currently in pre-production and set for an early 2017 shoot. The film, directed by Tom Edmunds in his feature debut, tells the story of a young man who hires an ageing assassin to assist with his suicide after nine failed attempts on his own life.

Leading the cast are two-time Oscar nominee Tom Wilkinson (known for "Michael Clayton"), BBC/TWC’s "War & Peace" star Aneurin Barnard, who will also be seen in Christopher Nolan’s upcoming war drama "Dunkirk," and Marion Bailey, recognized for her role in "Mr. Turner" and her recent appearance in Nicholas Hytner’s "The Lady In The Van." Additional casting is currently underway.

Producers Daniel-Konrad Cooper ("Burn Burn Burn") and Nick Clark Windo ("Blooded") have joined forces with executive producer Gina Carter ("Bright Young Things") of Sprout Pictures to bring this unique project to fruition. Mike Runagall of Altitude Film Sales expressed enthusiasm for the film, stating, “The film is built around an arresting and intriguing premise and has all the ingredients to be a fresh, crowd-pleasing comedy with broad commercial appeal, and we’re thrilled to be working with the filmmakers to bring this to screen.”

Southampton's comeback from two goals down against Burnley on Sunday might have looked fortunate, but underlying data reveals they deserved the win.  Their Fantasy Premier League Threat score, which measures the quality of goalscoring chances, reached a gameweek 30 high of 352.  Danny Ings' individual Threat of 122 was second only to Harry Kane (126) and nearly matched Burnley's entire team total (125).  A deeper dive into the week's statistics can inform your fantasy strategy.

**Threatening Heights:**

* Mohamed Salah (Liverpool) GW1 - 161
* Dominic Calvert-Lewin (Everton) GW2 - 144
* Ollie Watkins (Aston Villa) GW15 - 140
* Harry Kane (Tottenham) GW3 - 138
* Harry Kane (Tottenham) GW30 - 126


Kane and Ings' triple-digit Threat totals represent only the 22nd and 23rd instances of a player reaching 100 in a single match this season. Ings shattered his previous best of 82, while Kane, who also boasts a 138 from gameweek three, now holds two of the season’s top five Threat scores. Ings' performance ranks seventh.  With Tottenham's double gameweek in 32 approaching, overlooking the England captain seems incredibly risky.

**Spurs' Defensive Deficiencies:**

Despite Kane's attacking prowess, Southampton, along with Newcastle, dominated the Threat metric in gameweek 30.  Newcastle, surprisingly, generated the second-highest Threat total of the week (338), comfortably their best this season and only the third time they've surpassed 200. While Dwight Gayle led Newcastle with 78, their challenging upcoming fixtures suggest avoiding Tottenham defenders might be wise.

**James's Creative Spark:**

Chelsea's heavy defeat to West Brom offered little solace, but Reece James shone with a league-leading Creativity score of 66.  Creativity, which measures the potential of passes to become assists, mirrors Threat for goals.  A defender topping this metric is significant.  Chelsea, despite playing with 10 men, were one of two teams to generate more Threat than their opponents but still lose.

**Wolves' Emerging Opportunity:**

Wolves, the other team to out-Threat their opponents in a losing effort, appeared to have West Ham's number despite a slow start.

Residents of Freedom Park in Nomzamo Strand, Cape Town, are reaching out to the government for assistance in rebuilding their lives after a devastating fire left half of the community destitute. The blaze ripped through the area, destroying homes and disrupting the lives of many.

As the nation observed Freedom Day, the inhabitants of the informal settlement were still grappling with the loss of their homes, furniture, and personal belongings. The fire ravaged 90 structures, affecting over 300 people last Monday.

Community counselor Sitembile Mfecane highlighted the ongoing struggles faced by the fire victims in reconstructing their lives. Despite assessments by the Department of Disaster Relief and Sassa, no tangible assistance has been provided yet. While some donations from empathetic residents have been received, the affected families require more support.

Mfecane stressed the urgent need for necessities such as food, clothing, and materials to rebuild homes, especially with winter approaching. With a high rate of unemployment in the community, the financial burden is significant. Without substantial resources, aid, and donations, the residents may find it challenging to overcome this trying period.

An appeal has been made for individuals and organizations to step in and help the community recover from this tragic event. Community leaders are urging the public to lend support to the affected families.

For those willing to assist, please contact Sitembile Mfecane at 073 248 0407.

(Source: Cape Argus)

COLUMBIA (WBTW) – The South Carolina High School League unanimously approved the starting dates for the winter sports seasons this morning. High school boys and girls basketball are set to commence practice on November 2nd, with teams allowed to engage in two scrimmages before the regular season kicks off on November 30th. Just like football, the playoffs will be condensed to four rounds, heightening the importance of regional play every night. Attendance is anticipated to be restricted, with social distancing guidelines still in effect and masks required for everyone inside.

High school wrestling will be permitted to start practice on November 9th, while the first matches are scheduled to begin on December 14th.

The SCHSL is currently in the process of securing venues for the football and cheerleading finals in December. Williams-Brice Stadium and Benedict College in Columbia have traditionally hosted the finals, but will not do so this season due to COVID-19.

Chris Paul, known more famously as "CP3", has always been regarded as one of the top point guards in the league. Even though he had a brilliant season with OKC Thunder, it is widely reported that Chris Paul is expected to move this offseason to one of the multiple teams desperately looking for an elite point guard. NBA Trade Rumors: Chris Paul wants to play in a big market franchise, preferably New York or Los Angeles.

According to Jonathan Macri of the Knicks Film School, Chris Paul wants to play in a big market again next season, with Los Angeles and New York on the top of his list. With Chris Paul's heart set on playing in either Los Angeles or New York, fans of the four franchises in those cities have reason to be optimistic about landing an elite player this offseason. Paul has proved his worth time and again, with his basketball IQ and superior playmaking skills valued around the league by GMs and Head Coaches.

After the 2018-19 season, the Oklahoma City Thunder traded Russell Westbrook for Chris Paul, and analysts gave them a 0.2% chance of making the playoffs. However, Chris Paul's inspiring leadership led the young group of talented players to a Game 7 in the first round of the NBA playoffs, beating all odds.

Looking at the possibilities, let's evaluate each team on the top of Paul's list. Starting with the LA Lakers, despite trade rumors linking Chris Paul to the franchise, it seems like an unlikely destination due to his massive contract. The Brooklyn Nets already have a premier point guard in Kyrie Irving, making it unlikely for them to trade for Paul. This leaves the New York Knicks as a potential destination, with ample cap space and a desperate need for a point guard, making them a viable option for Chris Paul.

In conclusion, with next season fast approaching, teams around the NBA are looking to add quality to their rosters. Chris Paul has dominated the NBA Trade Rumors recently, and his desire to play in a big market franchise like New York or Los Angeles adds intrigue to the offseason negotiations.

CAPE TOWN (Reuters) - South African lawmakers elected Cyril Ramaphosa as state president on Wednesday, May 22, 2019, in the first parliamentary sitting since the ruling African National Congress (ANC) secured a majority in the general election earlier this month.  Ramaphosa, also the leader of the ANC, ran unopposed and was elected by the National Assembly, the lower house of parliament.  His inauguration is scheduled for Saturday.  The ANC's victory in the May 8th election, while decisive, saw a decline in their share of the vote, reflecting public frustration over ongoing corruption scandals and persistent racial inequalities that remain a significant challenge even a generation after the party's rise to power.

# Starting Young Horses: The Billy Stud Approach

A sound foundation is essential for young horses, regardless of which discipline they follow. At the heart of this philosophy is Will Plunkett, whose expertise in starting young horses spans a quarter-century and over 1,000 equine pupils.

"I've broken horses for everything; eventing, showjumping, dressage, Arabs, for racing – even a Shire horse," says Will, who oversees the basic training of 50 Billy Stud three-year-olds annually.

Car-buying consumers are at great risk after weather events like Hurricane Harvey and the threat posed by Hurricane Irma. They're at risk that flooded vehicles will eventually flood the market. The late Tom Zimmer, a former National Insurance Crime Bureau investigator and long-time source of mine, demonstrated for me three years ago how states will print salvage titles in the insurance companies' names -- and in a different color. "A regular Tennessee title is going to be green," he demonstrated. "Notice how the (Tennessee salvage title) is blue."

By law, when a flood drowns cars on a retail or auction lot, the lot must total out those vehicles in coordination with its insurance company and brand those cars' titles as salvage titles in the name of the insurance company. It also takes days, even weeks to secure a salvage title on a flooded vehicle. There's the flood itself, then the waiting to get a claims adjuster out to conduct an inspection, then the determination of loss and liability, then the generation of the title. "There's a gap of time between the actual incident and the branding of the title, so basically, you are unprotected at that point until those titles are branded," said Stan Norton, managing partner of City Auto and dealer member of the Tennessee Motor Vehicle Commission.

Bottom line, you should never buy a car without proof of a clean title. Period. If you insist on taking the risk of considering a car that has either a salvage title or no title at all, Zimmer said use your eyes -- and your nose -- to determine if it may be a flooded vehicle. "Are there artificial air fresheners in there that are probably covering up the odor of mold?" he said. He also said look for sand, dirt or silt traces in the upholstery, on the floorboard and around the interior. Chris Basso, public relations director for Carfax vehicle history reports, recommended before purchasing the car, have a reliable mechanic inspect the trunk, engine, and spare tire well for water or debris. Look for condensation in the dashboard, headlights, and taillights -- and look for excess rust on interior metal parts.

Andy Wise walks you through the steps of filing a flooded vehicle claim, as long as you have comprehensive coverage. "You should rely on vehicle history reports, and you should absolutely get those," Norton said.

# From Parking to Paradise: A Parisian Garage Transformed

In the heart of metropolitan Paris, where residential space comes at a premium, interior designers Céline Pelcé and Géraud Pellottiero of Atelier Pelpell have achieved something remarkable. They've transformed an ordinary parking garage into an extraordinary 700-square-foot home for a family of four, proving that innovative design can triumph over spatial constraints.

## Preserving Heritage While Embracing Modernity

The designers made the bold choice to retain key architectural elements of the original structure—exposed concrete beams, ramps, and vaults—lending authenticity and character to the space. Their primary challenge lay in maximizing natural light, as the structure originally featured just a single wall of windows.

## Ingenious Storage Solutions

Perhaps the most impressive aspect of this transformation is the integration of nearly 70 cleverly concealed storage spaces within the walls, ceilings, and floors. Storage corridors line the entrance and hallway between living areas and bedrooms, ensuring every square inch serves a purpose.

As Pelcé explains, "With a single contribution of natural light from the windowed facade facing street, the apartment is designed to be 'turned' toward this light with its glass rooms. Elements holding the old garage function were kept as witnesses and graphic structures of the apartment."

## Custom-Crafted Interiors

Local artisans collaborated with Atelier Pelpell to create 80% of the apartment's furniture. Highlights include:
- A kitchen island featuring a built-in extendable dining table
- A space-saving curved sliding door for the master bedroom
- Bedrooms oriented toward the window wall to maximize natural light
- A multi-functional children's alcove that doubles as toy storage
- A mezzanine loft accessible by ladder, featuring both double and single beds

## Thoughtful Details

The bathroom showcases a sophisticated blend of colored glass and black tiles, accommodating both a generous bathtub and shower. Select pieces from prestigious brands complement the custom furnishings:
- Press Citron shelving in the living room
- TOGO sofas from Ligne Roset
- A statement yellow chair by Desormeaux-Carrette
- BALLROOM lamps from NORDKRAFT
- Elegant wallpaper by Belgian brand Tenue de Ville

This transformation stands as a testament to the power of innovative design, proving that with vision and creativity, even the most utilitarian spaces can become extraordinary homes.

# Cast of 'Insidious: Chapter 3' Shares Insights at WonderCon

The stars of the upcoming horror film "Insidious: Chapter 3" made an appearance at WonderCon in Anaheim, California this past weekend. The event featured Stefanie Scott, Dermot Mulroney, Hayley Kiyoko, and Angus Sampson, alongside producer James Blum. During a roundtable interview, Scott and Mulroney, who portray a daughter-father duo in the film, discussed the authenticity of the horror elements and Scott's commitment to performing her own stunts.

## Q&A with the Stars

**Q: As newcomers to this established franchise, how were you received by the cast and crew?**

**Mulroney:** "I was amazed at how welcoming this franchise was to new actors. Leigh [Whannell]'s decision to tell an origin story and go back in time is brilliant, rather than simply continuing forward with another family encountering demons. This approach allows us to bring back Lin Shaye, the godmother of horror, and introduce a compelling new family narrative. We find ourselves dealing with Quinn's mother's death, depicting a fractured family trying to cope. Since this takes place six years before the first 'Insidious,' there's potential for Chapter 4."

**Scott:** "I would absolutely return! Though I'm not sure how much more Quinn can endure, I'd break both arms again—I'm that eager to do it!"

**Q: Were you horror fans before joining 'Insidious'?**

**Scott:** "Absolutely! I love horror movies, haunted attractions, 'The Shining,' and especially the first two 'Insidious' films. Like many teenagers, I'd go see them with friends on Friday nights."

**Mulroney:** "As a father of a teenager, I often find myself driving groups of kids to midnight showings of horror films. Our film is more psychologically impactful than most. Working with Stefanie was fantastic—she brings authentic teenage representation to the role, not just another typical horror movie victim. Her character deals with real issues: grief, loss, and possession."

[Interview continues with detailed discussions about the film's intensity, stunts, and production experience...]

"Insidious: Chapter 3" releases in theaters June 5.

(JTA) — A medical group that caters to Orthodox women in Brooklyn has finally won the right to operate their own ambulance after years of advocacy. On Thursday, New York State's Regional Emergency Medical Services Council granted an ambulance permit to Ezras Nashim, whose name carries dual meaning - literally translating to "women's aid" while also referring to the women's section in Orthodox synagogues.

Founded in 2014 by Orthodox women in Brooklyn, Ezras Nashim serves as a counterpart to Hatzoloh, a long-established emergency services organization staffed predominantly by men. The women's group was created to better serve religious women who, for modesty reasons, might prefer treatment from female medical staff.

Among the organization's founders is Judge Ruchie Freier, who holds the distinction of being the first Orthodox Hasidic woman elected to public office in America. Her daughter, Leah Freier Levine, serves as the group's director of outreach and development.

"We hope this is the end of the long journey," Freier Levine told the Forward, which first reported news of the permit.

# New Community Science Program Launches to Protect Ontario Waterways

The Sault's Invasive Species Centre has launched IsampleON, a new community science program aimed at protecting Ontario's waterways from invasive species this summer. The initiative will mobilize volunteers from more than 500 organizations across the province to help identify invasive species in Ontario's lakes.

"Volunteers will be collecting and analyzing water samples on lakes and shorelines," explained Rebecca Schroeder, Aquatic Invasive Species liaison. "They will then be sending them back to us where we analyze them for presence or absence of invasive mussel veligers." This proactive approach will help the Centre protect watersheds throughout the province.

The Federation of Ontario Cottagers' Association will coordinate the volunteer efforts. Terry Rees, the organization's executive director, emphasized the unique role of volunteers: "Each of them has got a unique opportunity to be eyes and ears on the water and look out for our environment."

While invasive mussels remain a concern across Ontario, the program will initially focus on 25 lakes from three watersheds. A key component of the initiative is raising public awareness, particularly among boaters who use multiple lakes.

"It means everyone who moves a boat from one waterbody to another has an opportunity to do their part to ensure they're not moving any water from one waterbody to another," Rees noted.

Gerald Bäck, founder of the personal search engine Archify, announced an investment from Balderton Capital at the re:publica conference in Berlin. The venture capital firm acquired a 20 percent stake in the young company, joining a portfolio that includes game supplier Wooga, location service SCVNGR, online game Habbo, and Airbnb competitor Housetrip.  This investment followed Archify's decision to relocate its operations from Vienna to the German capital.

Bäck explained to futurezone that the move was driven by several factors.  "In Vienna there are few people with the necessary skills, in Berlin there are more people who potentially fit the job," he stated.  Additionally, he cited Berlin's growing influence in the internet sector, particularly its focus on the US market, which is Archify's target audience.  The exorbitant real estate prices in London, another potential relocation option, further solidified the decision in favor of Berlin.  Bäck also revealed that attending a start-up boot camp in Copenhagen cemented the realization that remaining in Vienna was not a viable option for the company's growth. While the five-person team plans to transition to Berlin, Bäck intends to initially commute between the Austrian and German capitals.

Archify is developing a personal search engine designed to complement Google.  Bäck explained, "Google is great for searching for information you don't yet know." Archify, however, focuses on searching an individual's own digital history, including social networks and browsing activity.  The platform currently boasts 5,000 registered users, with 3,000 active users, 80 percent of whom engage with Archify daily.

The platform offers a browser plug-in that saves all visited websites to a separate account.  It also integrates with Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn, archiving posted content for future searches.  Gmail integration is planned for the next development phase. Unlike tools like Evernote and Delicious, Archify automates the recording of internet usage, eliminating the need for manual saving. Bäck identifies CloudMagic and Greplin as direct competitors but believes Archify's automated browsing history feature gives it a competitive edge.

The news from the Lloyd’s insurance market this week highlights its deep concern about the potential loss of access to the single market should the UK leave the European Union. Lloyd's believes there is a serious possibility that several key firms, tired of the uncertainty, may decide to relocate. Lloyd’s chairman John Nelson expressed these fears strongly before the referendum, and nothing has occurred since to change his perspective.

This serves as a timely reminder, amid the hype surrounding recent positive reports on the UK’s current economic performance, that Brexit is a long-term issue. The challenges it presents have yet to be properly defined, much less addressed. Nonetheless, Lloyd’s at least has a future to worry about, which is noteworthy considering this week marks the 20th anniversary of its remarkable recovery. Two decades ago, Lloyd’s pulled off the greatest recovery act in the history of the City when its members voted in favor of a recovery plan that saved it from extinction.

The problem that brought Lloyd’s to its knees was the underwriting of open-ended commitments to insure pollution and asbestosis liabilities in the US without a full understanding of the risks. The situation was exacerbated by some market participants playing "pass the parcel" with the worst liabilities. When the bills came due, the members—known as Names—whose personal wealth backed the market, could not or would not pay. Instead, they sued their agents and underwriters for negligence.

For the Van Alstyne Leader

HOWE - It's been six months since Summit Hill Elementary opened for the 2019-2020 school year, and district officials say the new facility has been a resounding success.

"It's gone very well," Superintendent Kevin Wilson said. "Like with any new building, there's been a few growing pains, but we're really happy with the floorplan and the way that everything has evolved."

## Background and Need

The journey to the new school began in 2017 when voters approved a $17 million bond package. The construction was necessitated by an enrollment spike of more than 200 kids over just a couple of years.

According to Wilson, this put the district in an awkward position. They weren't big enough to support two full elementary schools, but their existing facilities were overcrowded. As a result, the previous elementary school (now the intermediate school) could only accommodate students up to the fourth grade, forcing fifth graders to attend classes with middle-school teenagers.

"We never really like having the fifth graders at the middle school, but we did it out of necessity," Wilson said. "Building the new school gave us an opportunity to bring them back into a more appropriate age group."

## Innovative Design

The district chose a pod floor plan that separates each grade level into different hallways. This layout limits traffic from other grades and fosters collaboration between teachers and students. Each pod includes collaboration spaces, allowing teachers to utilize an open classroom setup, employ technology, or coordinate small group projects.

# Astroworld Festival Tragedy and Concert Safety

## The Tragedy and Its Victims

Eight people lost their lives at Travis Scott's Astroworld Festival in Houston when the crowd surged during the rapper's set. The packed audience was pushed toward the stage, with many concertgoers reporting they were crushed to the point where they couldn't breathe, while others were trampled.

### Remembering Those Lost

- John Hilger (14) - A freshman at a Houston high school
- Brianna Rodriguez (16) - Remembered for her passion for dancing
- Jacob Jurinek (20) - A promising young journalist
- Franco Patino (21) - An Illinois native
- Rudy Pena (23) - A college student from Texas
- Danish Baig (27) - Died saving his fiancée's life
- One unidentified victim (early twenties)

A memorial now stands outside the concert venue in Houston, honoring these lives lost.

## The Incident and Investigation

A criminal investigation is in its early stages. While Scott reportedly stopped the show at least three times to ask for help for concertgoers, some have criticized both the artist and organizers for allowing the concert to continue. Scott and Kylie Jenner, who was present at the show, have expressed their devastation on social media, with Jenner stating they were unaware of any fatalities until after the event.

## How Other Artists Handle Concert Safety

### Examples of Responsible Concert Management

1. **Linkin Park**
- Stopped their show when people fell in the mosh pit
- Emphasized safety first
- Taught crowd to help others up when they fall

2. **Dave Grohl (Foo Fighters)**
- Paused performance to help a child with special needs
- Arranged safe seating at the stage

3. **Slayer**
- Halted show to ensure clear aisles
- Explained safety rules to the audience

4. **ASAP Rocky**
- Stopped performance when people fell
- Directed crowd to help others and maintain calm

5. **Playboi Carti**
- Responded to organizers' concerns about passing out
- Implemented strict safety measures at subsequent shows
- Used clear pre-show safety announcements

These examples demonstrate how artists can effectively manage crowd safety while maintaining the concert experience.

# A Tech-Savvy Tribute to College Football History

ATLANTA - The College Football Hall of Fame seamlessly blends tradition with technology to create an immersive celebration of the sport's rich heritage. Upon entering the main lobby, visitors are immediately struck by its most impressive feature: a spectacular wall adorned with 777 helmets, representing every four-year college and university with a football program, from SEC powerhouses to NAIA institutions.

This striking mosaic of team colors and logos is just the beginning of a personalized journey through college football history. "We are a very personalized experience," explains Kimberly Beaudin, vice president of marketing and sales. Visitors receive an RFID-enabled pass coded with their preferred team, allowing the building to interact with them directly. "As they go around the building, the building will recognize you. 'Hi Kimberly, would you like to see Gators content? Hi, Kimberly, would you like to sing the Gators fight song?'" Beaudin notes that while visitors get priority access to content from their chosen school, they can easily explore other programs and traditions.

The hall combines historical artifacts with interactive experiences. Traditional exhibits showcase century-old helmets, UGa's iconic sweater and collar, and statues of major college football awards. For a more hands-on experience, visitors can:
- Record segments at the ESPN College Gameday set, complete with a customized video
- Test their skills on a 45-yard indoor playing field
- Kick extra points
- Practice passing and running drills
- Make touchdown catches in the end zone

"You could spend a whole day here, but on average, folks spend about two-and-a-half hours," says Beaudin. The experience culminates in "the hallowed ground where the players are actually enshrined."

Traffic safety experts have tried various strategies to combat speeding, as speeding-related crashes claim around 12,000 American lives annually. Initially, they attempted flashing signs to alert drivers of their speed, believing that drivers would slow down if they were aware of their speed. When this method proved ineffective, they deployed law enforcement officers to deter speeding, emphasizing the deterrent effect of severe penalties for speeding violations. Subsequently, hidden speeding cameras were installed on major roads to encourage cautious driving by creating uncertainty about when drivers were being monitored.

The latest approach in the ongoing battle against speeding involves placing a GPS device inside cars to incentivize drivers to maintain safe speeds. Researchers have discovered that a GPS device that monitors a vehicle's speed relative to the posted speed limit, coupled with a financial incentive, effectively reduces speeding behavior. In a study supported by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, drivers were offered a $25 reward each week for safe driving, with penalties deducted for exceeding speed limits.

The experiment demonstrated significant reductions in speeding violations, particularly for drivers exceeding speed limits by nine or more miles per hour. The combination of rewards for safe driving and penalties for speeding violations proved highly effective in modifying driver behavior. The study revealed that some drivers even turned the incentive system into a personal challenge, further motivating them to comply with speed limits.

The success of this incentive-based approach suggests potential applications beyond research studies. Ian Reagan, a traffic safety researcher, envisions insurance companies offering similar tracking devices to policyholders interested in reducing their premiums. Unlike current rebate programs, these devices would provide real-time feedback to drivers, informing them of the financial implications of their driving behavior after each trip.

In conclusion, this innovative method of using incentives to promote safe driving behavior represents a promising advancement in traffic safety initiatives. By combining rewards and penalties, authorities aim to encourage drivers to adhere to speed limits and reduce the risk of speeding-related accidents. The evolving landscape of traffic safety strategies may soon see widespread adoption of such incentive-based programs by insurance companies and other stakeholders.

New Delhi: Following protests, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) clarified on Thursday that it had not declared the Amarnath cave shrine in the south Kashmir Himalayas a "silence zone."  A bench headed by NGT Chairperson Justice Swatanter Kumar stated that silence must be observed only directly in front of the ice stalagmite formation resembling the 'Shivalinga.'  A detailed order is forthcoming.

The NGT's clarification came after it had declared the shrine a "silence zone" on Wednesday, prohibiting religious offerings beyond the entry point.  The tribunal had previously suggested that establishing a "silence zone" around the shrine could help prevent avalanches and preserve the area's pristine environment.

The Amarnath cave shrine is a major Hindu pilgrimage site.  Covered in snow for most of the year, the cave is accessible to pilgrims only for a brief period during the summer.

The Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP), a Hindu right-wing organization, protested the NGT's initial order, calling it a "Tughlaki fatwa" (whimsical decree) and arguing that Hindus were not responsible for all ecological problems.

Conversely, environmental activist Gauri Maulekhi, whose petition led to the NGT's directions, welcomed the original order as "good and progressive."  She told PTI on Wednesday, "The Amarnath cave is situated in a fragile ecosystem.  These directions will make the Amarnath Yatra safer and more convenient for devotees, protecting the shrine from degradation and ensuring its preservation for future generations."

**Prosecutor Denies Threatening Saginaw Diocese**

BAD AXE — A prosecutor involved in a sexual abuse investigation concerning priests from the Diocese of Saginaw has denied threatening the Diocese in a 2004 letter.

Mark Gaertner, a former Huron County prosecutor and current assistant prosecutor in Saginaw County, is collaborating with law enforcement on investigations into past sexual abuse of minors by priests in the Diocese.

Gaertner served as the Huron County prosecutor when Bad Axe Police investigated former Bad Axe Priest Jack E. Leipert following allegations of sexual abuse at Sacred Heart Church in 2000. Ultimately, the county chose not to press charges against Leipert despite a 21-year-old Caseville man accusing him of molestation.

The Diocese informed the Tribune this week that this complaint prompted Leipert's removal from the ministry in 2001. Erin Looby Carlson, director of communications for the Diocese of Saginaw, explained via email: "In 2001, it was determined that there appeared to be credible complaints involving the sexual abuse of minors against Jack Leipert from his earlier years in ministry."

Following the incident at Sacred Heart, Leipert was permanently removed from priestly duties and was prohibited from presenting himself as a priest.

**No Charges Sought Locally**

Leipert, known as "Father Jack," served as a pastor at Sacred Heart from July 1990 to January 2001. The Bad Axe Police Department, supported by the Huron County Sheriff's Office, investigated the alleged molestation in November 2000.

Details of the investigation were reported by the Tribune in a May 2 article titled "Former Bad Axe Priest Investigated Locally for Alleged Sex Abuse." On Tuesday, Gaertner told the Tribune that the case against Leipert was not robust enough for a trial victory.

Efforts to gather evidence through a recorded conversation between Leipert and the alleged victim were unsuccessful due to technical failure and the alleged victim not asking all the questions provided by law enforcement.
