**Big Health's Daylight App Proven Effective for Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Randomized Controlled Trial**

**SAN FRANCISCO & LONDON – July 29, 2020 –** Big Health, the global leader in digital therapeutics for mental health, and the University of Oxford's Sleep Circadian Neuroscience Institute today announced the publication of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) in the journal *Depression and Anxiety*.  The study demonstrates the efficacy and safety of Big Health's Daylight app in improving symptoms of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).

The fully automated smartphone-based program leverages evidence-based cognitive and behavioral techniques to help users manage worry and anxiety.  Trial results revealed that Daylight significantly reduced anxiety symptoms compared to the control group after six weeks.  Impressively, 71% of Daylight users achieved remission of GAD by week 10, compared to just 33% in the control group.  These improvements were maintained even at the 26-week (uncontrolled) follow-up, which coincided with the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic – a period of heightened anxiety globally.

"This trial confirms that Daylight is a safe, effective first-line digital therapeutic for worry and anxiety," said Professor Jasper Smits, PhD, Department of Psychiatry at the University of Texas, Austin.  "The consistent and measurable improvements in mental health observed in Daylight users are significant and meaningful, demonstrating the potential of this software to offer relief to those suffering from worry, anxiety, and related conditions."

Anxiety is the most prevalent mental health issue in the United States, affecting over 40 million adults annually.  GAD, characterized by excessive and difficult-to-control worry accompanied by physical symptoms and functional impairment, affects 5-6% of the population in the UK and US, respectively. The COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated these challenges, with numerous surveys reporting increased rates of anxiety and stress.

"Anxiety and other mental health challenges cause immense distress globally, yet access to effective solutions remains limited due to stigma and the constraints of in-person care, further compounded by the pandemic," explained Dr. Jenna Carl, vice president of clinical development and medical affairs at Big Health. "These study results confirm Daylight's meaningful impact and its potential to support millions in achieving better mental health, particularly those with limited access to traditional care."

The trial involved 256 participants randomized to either the Daylight intervention or a control group (who received the intervention later).  Participants met criteria for GAD with moderate to severe symptoms, assessed using established clinical measures (MINI and SCID for diagnosis; GAD-7 for severity). Assessments occurred at baseline, mid-intervention (week 3), post-intervention (week 6, primary endpoint), follow-up (week 10), and long-term follow-up (week 26).

In addition to quantitative results, qualitative feedback from participants was positive, highlighting the app's engaging design, soothing voice guidance, practical tools, and overall effectiveness in managing anxiety.  Participants reported feeling more in control, better equipped to challenge negative thoughts, and more confident in their ability to handle anxiety.

Beyond the primary outcomes on anxiety, the study also found statistically significant improvements in worry, depressive symptoms, sleep difficulty, wellbeing, and quality of life.  The effects of Daylight were consistent across demographic groups and severity levels.

Daylight was developed in collaboration with anxiety experts from Boston University, UCLA, University of Oxford, and the University of Texas at Austin.  The program combines animation, developed by veterans of Pixar and Radiolab, with a calming human voice to create an immersive and personalized experience.  Daylight is Big Health's second digital therapeutic, following the success of Sleepio, its digital sleep improvement program.  Daylight has received CE mark approval, signifying its compliance with EU medical device safety and performance requirements.

"The Kissing Booth" star Joey King is in negotiations to join Brad Pitt in Sony Pictures' action-adventure thriller, "Bullet Train."  Based on Kotaro Isaka's Japanese novel "Maria Beetle," the film will be directed by David Leitch from a script by Zak Olkewicz.

Leitch and Kelly McCormick will produce "Bullet Train" through their company, 87North, alongside Antoine Fuqua.  Kat Samick is executive producing, with Ryosuke Saegusa and Yuma Terada of CTB Inc., representing Isaka.

Sony has yet to set a production date and is keeping plot details and character descriptions under wraps.

King rose to prominence in 2018 with Netflix's teen romantic comedy franchise "The Kissing Booth," starring as Elle Evans alongside Jacob Elordi and Joel Courtney.  The sequel, "The Kissing Booth 2," debuted on Netflix on July 24, and the streaming service recently announced a third film, set to release in 2021.  "The Kissing Booth 3" was filmed back-to-back with the second installment, and production is already complete.  The entire cast, including King, Courtney, Elordi, Taylor Zakhar Perez, and Molly Ringwald, will return.

Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand is visiting Long Island Friday to discuss new bipartisan legislation that would expand the U.S. Small Business Administration’s microloan program. Gillibrand was making a stop at Farmingdale State College to say that the Mircoloan Modernization Act would make it easier for entrepreneurs to access capital to grow their business. The new legislation would be of benefit to women and minority business owners, along with other entrepreneurs, who struggle with access to capital because banks often deny them loans to start and grow a business.

Gillibrand said the act would raise the total limit on outstanding loans to intermediary lending organizations, allowing for more loans to be made to women, minority and other business owners. It would also expand the number of opportunities for more hands-on training assistance so that more small business owners can succeed. Women receive less than 5 percent of conventional small business loans, yet they own nearly 40 percent of businesses across the nation, according to the U.S. Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship. And loan denial rates for minority firms were nearly three times higher than those of non-minority-owned firms, U.S. Department of Commerce reports.

This bipartisan legislation was sponsored by Sen. Deb Fischer (R-NE) and has passed in the House of Representatives. The bill is also cosponsored by Senators Tim Scott (R-SC), Chris Coons (D-DE), Jeanne Shaheen (D-NH), Joe Donnelly (D-IN), and Gary Peters (D-MI).

How do you find a man who can go toe-to-toe with Helen Mirren—especially when she is in full imperial mode? Such was the challenge when Mirren took the lead in "Catherine the Great," HBO’s lavish four-part mini-series about the 18th-century Russian empress. Her casting raised no eyebrows; it was a role she was born to play, with her innate nous, wit, ruthlessness, and ability to portray the empress’s romantic exploits. But who had the charisma, charm, and raw machismo to play Grigory Potemkin, the army officer who became Catherine’s lover, right-hand man, and—potentially, albeit secretly—her husband? Hemkunt Foundation, a non-governmental organisation (NGO) known for delivering oxygen to those in need during the second wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, recently had a temporary COVID centre vandalised by unidentified individuals on Thursday, 3 June. According to reports, the destruction started in the early hours of the morning, with the perpetrators stealing the facility's generators and cutting off its power supply.

Fortunately, no patients were present at the facility in Gurugram's Sector 61 during the attack. However, individuals seeking to refill their oxygen cylinders were turned away due to the vandalism. Hemkunt Foundation has been instrumental in aiding vulnerable individuals struggling with oxygen shortages amid the pandemic's peak, emphasizing the urgent need for access to 20,000 square meters of space around the city centre to maintain their life-saving services.

Denver (CNN) — Colorado authorities have issued a warrant for homicide following the discovery of human remains in rural southern Colorado, police reported on Wednesday. Local and state officials announced that they uncovered the remains of three individuals on two properties in Lasauses, Colorado, while executing a search warrant.

Authorities are now seeking Adre Jordan Baroz, 26, in connection with these remains. "Our primary objective is to remove him from the streets," stated Alamosa Police Chief Ken Anderson, who announced the warrant. "He currently poses a danger to the public."

Chief Anderson also noted that Baroz is considered armed and dangerous. Lasauses is a small town situated along the Rio Grande in southern Colorado, nestled between Alamosa to the north and the New Mexico border to the south.

The investigators mentioned that the remains have yet to be identified. It may take weeks or even months to determine the gender, age, and identity of the deceased. However, Monte Vista Police Chief George Dingfelder confirmed that forensic anthropologists have established the remains belong to three individuals.

On November 10, the Conejos County Sheriff’s Office, which has jurisdiction in Lasauses, requested assistance from the Colorado Bureau of Investigation in executing the search warrant, according to Sheriff Garth Crowther. Upon discovering remains at the initial property, evidence prompted the authorities to search a nearby location, where they found additional remains.

Due to the ongoing investigation, law enforcement has not disclosed details regarding why Baroz has been identified as a suspect, how long the remains were on the properties, or whether they are connected to any recent missing persons cases. Investigators continue to search the properties for more remains and evidence.

CNN’s Eliott C. McLaughlin contributed to this report.

Disney's "Shang-Chi and The Legend of the Ten Rings" has become a box office sensation, grossing $71.4 million in ticket sales over the Labor Day weekend. This marks a significant achievement as the movie was the first Marvel film to be exclusively released in theaters since the onset of the pandemic. It is set to remain in theaters for 45 days before becoming available on streaming services.

Starring an Asian superhero in the lead role, "Shang-Chi" has received critical acclaim and has secured the second-highest box office earnings during the pandemic, trailing only behind "Black Widow." The latter, released in July simultaneously in theaters and on Disney+, led to a legal dispute when Scarlett Johansson sued Disney for breaching her contract, alleging that the online release affected her compensation tied to ticket sales.

The success of "Shang-Chi" has revitalized confidence in the theatrical movie industry, surpassing initial projections and demonstrating the effectiveness of a theatrical-first strategy in attracting audiences to cinemas. Amid delays in major movie releases due to the Delta variant surge, the movie industry has found hope in the performance of "Shang-Chi."

Despite its triumph at the domestic box office, "Shang-Chi" faces another hurdle as it has yet to receive approval for screening in China. This setback has not dampened the movie's success, which is seen as a pivotal moment for representation and inclusivity in the superhero genre.

The National Association of Theatre Owners has pointed to the exceptional performance of "Shang-Chi" as evidence that an exclusive theatrical release can yield greater profitability, contrasting with the hybrid release model tested by "Black Widow." The response from moviegoers to "Shang-Chi" has been overwhelmingly positive, signaling a promising resurgence for the theatrical movie experience.

Hyundai unveiled fingerprint access technology on the 2019 Santa Fe at the Guangzhou International Automobile Exhibition, showcasing its ambitious plans for biometric car access.  This technology, initially launched in China for the Santa Fe crossover SUV, features fingerprint scanners integrated into the door handles and ignition button.  While other automakers have used fingerprint scanners for ignition, Hyundai claims to be the first to implement this technology for door handles, addressing security and durability concerns that have previously hindered wider adoption.  According to ZDNet, these concerns stem from the need for the technology to withstand various weather conditions, including extreme temperatures, sun, snow, and rain.

Hyundai assures a low 1 in 50,000 failure rate for the fingerprint reader, employing capacitance technology—measuring electricity levels in different parts of the finger—to prevent unauthorized entry.  The system allows multiple users to register their fingerprints, and the vehicle intelligently adjusts seat and mirror positions based on the recognized driver.

This 2019 Hyundai Santa Fe first drive revealed that this technology is part of Hyundai's strategy to enhance its brand perception and boost sales in the competitive Chinese auto market, where the company has faced challenges.  The automaker hopes this innovative feature will elevate its reputation and stimulate SUV sales. # Flash Flooding Alert: Millbrook Streets Closed

Severe flooding has forced the closure of two major intersections within Millbrook city limits, according to local officials. The affected areas include the intersections of Pine Leaf Drive and Dogwood Circle.

Laois Kayak & Canoe Club members Brian Ogilvie, Finbar O’Donovan, and Jim Tierney paddled their way to a historic gold medal at the 2018 Liffey Descent. This victory marks the first Liffey Descent gold for any Laois club.  The Canadian Triple class team faced challenging conditions in the grueling 32km race, which started at the K Club in Straffan, Co Kildare.

Over 500 kayakers from around the world competed in this year's event, made more technical by low water levels resulting from a summer drought and the lack of an upstream flood release by the ESB.  The challenging course included 11 weirs and one portage, making the race particularly tough.  The trio finished with a winning time of 3 hours 50 minutes, acknowledging it was the toughest race they had ever paddled, making the victory even sweeter.

“The key to the race was getting a strong start and reading the river correctly,” Finbar O’Donovan told the Leinster Express. “We knew that it would spell disaster if we took the wrong route over the high drops. Luckily, we got everything right on the day.”  The less experienced competitors faced carnage on the big weirs, highlighting the skill and precision required to navigate the challenging course.

Congratulations are also extended to Laois Kayak & Canoe Club members Seamus Byrne, Matt McGrath, Patrick Marshall, and Catherine Byrne, who all finished the race with commendable times.

**About The Club**

Based in Durrow, Laois Kayak and Canoe Club offers a variety of kayaking and canoeing activities, from white water river-running and canoe polo to freestyle play boating and flat-water racing.  The club caters to all skill levels, from beginners to experts.  Affiliated with Canoeing Ireland (ICU), the club provides training and progression following Canoeing Ireland's skills award programmes, led by ICU qualified instructors.

For more information, visit www.laoiskayak.com or find them on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/laoiskayak/  Contact: Brian Ogilvie, mob. 086 1739029, email. info@laoiskayak.com

# Treasury Secretary: Iran Sanctions Cut Off 95% of Oil Revenue, Further Actions Planned

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin announced that the Trump administration's sanctions have successfully blocked 95% of Iran's oil revenue, speaking during an interview on Fox News' "Sunday Morning Futures" with Maria Bartiromo. The administration is actively working with China and Europe to implement additional sanctions against Iran, which the U.S. designates as the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism.

The interview focused primarily on new sanctions imposed following Iran's missile attack on U.S. forces in Iraq. Mnuchin explained that recent measures, including a new executive order, expanded their capability to implement both primary and secondary sanctions across multiple sectors, including metals, construction, and travel.

When questioned about potential further sanctions, Mnuchin emphasized the comprehensive nature of their current authority: "With the new executive order, we have very strong authorities now across all industries." He clarified that the primary goal is to cut off funding sources for terrorist activities and nuclear weapons development, while still allowing humanitarian aid to reach Iranian citizens.

Addressing concerns about China's continued relationship with Iran, Mnuchin noted that while China receives approximately 70% of Iran's current oil exports, this represents a fraction of Iran's previous oil trade. He detailed recent diplomatic efforts with Chinese officials:

- Chinese state companies have ceased oil purchases
- U.S. officials met with a Chinese delegation at the State Department
- Sanctions have been imposed on Chinese shipping companies involved in Iranian oil trade
- Ongoing efforts continue to eliminate remaining oil activities

Regarding European allies, particularly France, Mnuchin confirmed that European nations are complying with primary sanctions to avoid secondary sanctions. He specifically addressed INSTEX (Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges), warning that it could face secondary sanctions depending on its implementation.

The Treasury Secretary concluded by reiterating the administration's commitment to humanitarian support through a Swiss channel, emphasizing that the sanctions target Iran's terrorist activities and nuclear ambitions rather than its citizens.

# Alberta Expands COVID-19 Vaccine Distribution to Include Paramedics

*By Stephen Dafoe*

The Government of Alberta announced Monday that it is expanding its COVID-19 vaccine distribution to include paramedics and emergency medical technicians (EMTs), having already administered 46,791 doses.

"We are ramping up our capacity to ensure that regardless of how many vaccines arrive in Alberta, we have people ready to receive them and health-care workers prepared to administer them," Premier Jason Kenney said in a media release. "Alberta is already leading in the number of doses delivered – and we will continue expanding our vaccination efforts for the benefit of all Albertans. Our main constraint remains the available supply of vaccines."

Alberta Paramedic Association President Dusty Myshrall expressed gratitude to Health Minister Tyler Shandro and Premier Kenney for responding to the association's concerns.

"Including paramedics in the early prioritization list acknowledges the unique challenges we face as front-line health-care workers serving during a pandemic," Myshrall said. "Alberta has already established itself as a national leader in vaccine deployment, and today's announcement further solidifies Alberta's commitment to protecting health-care workers and vulnerable Albertans."

## Eligible Health-care Workers

The following health-care workers are now eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine:

- Health-care workers in COVID-19 units, medical and surgical units, and operating rooms
- Health-care workers in emergency departments
- Home-care workers
- Staff of long-term care and designated supportive living facilities
- Respiratory therapists
- Paramedics and emergency medical technicians

## Local Updates

As of January 11, according to the government update:

- **Morinville**: No new cases, four additional recoveries, with 39 active cases
- **Sturgeon County**: No new cases, six additional recoveries, with 48 active cases

The Federal Government has directed civil servants to return to work starting Monday. This applies to those who have been away from the office since the March lockdown implemented to curb the spread of COVID-19.  The announcement was made on Thursday by Boss Mustapha, Chairman of the Presidential Task Force (PTF) on COVID-19, and Sanni Aliyu, the National Coordinator, during a PTF press briefing.

Previously, only civil servants at Salary Grade Level 12 and above, along with essential workers, were required to report to their physical workplaces.  This new directive extends to all remaining civil servants below SGL 12.

Ministries, Departments, and Agencies (MDAs) have been instructed to implement staggered work schedules to ensure social distancing within their offices.

After Derby County's Championship play-off final loss to Aston Villa, a disheartened Tom Huddlestone was left pondering what could have been. Aston Villa secured a 2-1 victory at Wembley, earning promotion to the Premier League. Anwar El Ghazi put Villa ahead with a header just before half-time, and John McGinn scored a second goal shortly before the hour mark, capitalizing on a mistake by goalkeeper Kelle Roos. Derby managed to score a consolation goal late in the game when Jack Marriott's shot deflected off Martyn Waghorn.

Despite their efforts, Frank Lampard's team fell short in the end. Reflecting on his emotions after the match, Huddlestone expressed deep disappointment, saying, "I feel devastated, contemplating what might have been. The game was closely contested. Both teams had a slow start. We managed to find our rhythm in the middle of the first half, but conceding a goal just before half-time from what seemed like a harmless cross was a significant setback."

Throughout the season, Derby had staged remarkable comebacks, and they needed another one at Wembley. "That was the halftime message," Huddlestone revealed. "We have been in more challenging situations before – like Norwich away and Leeds in the play-offs. Everyone counted us out then, but we fought back. Unfortunately, we couldn't create a clear opportunity for an equalizer. We believed we had done enough to push the game to extra time. I felt the game was evenly poised, and if we had managed to score the equalizer, we would have seized the momentum and won within the regular ninety minutes. Towards the end, they appeared fatigued."

Huddlestone was reinstated to the starting lineup as Lampard made two changes to the team. "As you grow older, the chances of featuring in these significant matches diminish, so it was a personal moment for me. However, I would have preferred to be on the bench and witness a victory," admitted the former England international.

BUFFALO, N.Y. (AP) — The owner of the Buffalo Beauts, Kim Pegula, relinquished control of the National Women's Hockey League (NWHL) franchise on Wednesday, a move that could further jeopardize the future of the league as it struggles to keep its five franchises afloat without the support of the world's top players. Pegula informed NWHL Commissioner Dani Rylan of her decision during a conference call on Tuesday. The call was considered Rylan's final opportunity to change Pegula's mind, according to a person with direct knowledge of the decision who spoke on condition of anonymity.

The NWHL will re-assume control of the Beauts, but will have to renegotiate facility fees if the league intends for the team to continue playing at the Pegula-owned HarborCenter. Rylan thanked Pegula Sports for running the Beauts over the past two seasons and acknowledged their commitment to advancing hockey at all levels.

The Beauts were among the NWHL's first four teams and have advanced to the Isobel Cup championship game in each of the league's four seasons, winning it in 2017. The Pegulas earned league-wide praise for how they operated the team, providing players access to the Sabres' practice and workout facilities, and assisting in marketing efforts. Without the Pegulas, the NWHL will need to cover the Beauts' operating and salary costs, estimated to be close to $200,000.

Last week, more than 200 players announced they would not play in North America this year without what they deem a single, economically viable professional league for women. The list included many Beauts players, such as U.S. national team defenseman Emily Pfalzer and Canadian national team goalie Shannon Szabados.

Key Position Battle: Strong Safety stands out as the most crucial position battle for the Texans. Tashaun Gipson, the team's starting SS and interception leader in 2019, was unexpectedly released this offseason, just a year into his three-year, $22.5 million deal. Jahleel Addae, Gipson's backup from last year, was not re-signed. The question of who will replace Gipson in 2020 remains unanswered. Eric Murray and Michael Thomas, veteran free-agent signings, are poised to compete for the starting role alongside free safety Justin Reid. Neither Murray nor Thomas have secured a consistent starting position in their careers. Jaylen Watkins was also signed this offseason for added depth, but apart from Reid, the Texans' situation at strong safety may only be considered average, which would come as a relief.

Major Strength: Quarterback. It's simple. Deshaun Watson is the linchpin in Houston's lineup, leading the team to back-to-back playoff appearances despite modest expectations for the roster. The Texans recognize Watson's significance to their success and have focused on fortifying their offensive line over the past two seasons. Watson was responsible for 34 of the team's 44 offensive touchdowns last year (26 passing, seven rushing, and one receiving) and nearly reached 4,000 passing yards for the second consecutive season. While the absence of DeAndre Hopkins this season will be felt, Watson's talent, combined with the skills of Will Fuller, Brandin Cooks, Kenny Stills, and Keke Coutee, should keep the offense dynamic. Additionally, the Texans boast depth in their tight end group, with Jordan Akins, Darren Fells, and Jordan Thomas providing solid red-zone targets for Watson. As Watson goes, so go the Texans, a trend that is expected to continue into 2020 and beyond.

Main Weakness: Defensive Line. In his debut season as defensive coordinator, Anthony Weaver faces a challenge with the Texans' defensive line. The departure of D.J. Reader in free agency and the void left by Jadeveon Clowney's trade last August must be filled. The Texans ranked in the bottom eight in both passing and rushing yards allowed last season, finished in the bottom six in sacks, ranked second to Washington as the worst defense on third downs, and ended dead last in red-zone defense. While it's baffling how the Texans made the playoffs last year, it's unsurprising they squandered a 24-0 lead against the Kansas City Chiefs in the Divisional Round. The lack of pressure upfront has been a glaring issue, negatively impacting the entire defense.

Farm loan waivers have become a hot topic in Indian politics, with three newly elected Congress-led state governments announcing their intentions to waive off farm loans. Rahul Gandhi, the Congress chief, tweeted about the loan waivers in Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh, hinting that Rajasthan might follow suit soon. This move comes after the Congress defeated the BJP in these states.

The real impact of these loan waivers remains to be seen, as the quantum of funds required and the ability of the governments to fund such one-time expenses are in question. The fine print of the waivers, including the conditions for farmers to qualify, will determine the total amount needed in each state. Past experiences in states like Karnataka, Punjab, and Uttar Pradesh show that the actual impact of loan waivers takes time to materialize.

The history of farm loan waivers in India dates back to the UPA government's massive waiver in 2008, which helped them win another term in office. Subsequent loan waivers in states like Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Tamil Nadu have added to the burden on state finances. The RBI's report highlights the strain on state budgets due to revenue deficits and growing liabilities.

The current situation in the three Congress-led states raises concerns about revenue growth and fiscal responsibility. The states may face challenges in funding the loan waivers given the slow pace of revenue growth. The decline in tax revenues, particularly related to GST implementation, adds to the uncertainty surrounding the financial implications of the waivers.

While the exact amount for the farm loan waivers is unclear, it is evident that the states' revenue streams are not strong. Until GST collections stabilize, these governments may need to cut expenses in other areas to accommodate the loan waivers. The financial implications of these decisions will unfold in the coming months, shedding light on the feasibility and impact of the farm loan waivers in these states.

What have the national anthem, breastfeeding, sarcasm and environmental disasters got in common? Over the last year, there have been calls for each of these topics to be taught in schools – a practice known as ‘curriculum dumping’. Every time a societal issue arises, the expectation is for schools to address it.  If only pupils learned about knife crime, acid attacks, revenge porn, or gambling, the logic goes, these problems would disappear.

This raises some common sense questions. With an already packed curriculum, do schools have the time and expertise?  A new report by the campaign group Parents and Teachers for Excellence highlights this issue. After scouring social media, newspapers, and other sources, the group unearthed 213 examples of suggested new ‘subjects’ for 2018 alone.  It points out that schools would need hundreds of additional hours to teach them all.  The top three themes proposed were health, finance, and technology.  Other suggestions included the Commonwealth, workers’ rights, litter picking, the RAF, marriage, how to avoid dog bites, oceans, feminism, and even using trampolining to teach literacy skills or Love Island to critique celebrity culture.  Some of the more outlandish ideas included teaching sado-masochism and swearing.

The report also raises concerns over schools becoming ‘catnip’ for lobby groups and policy-makers, asking, “What should schools stop doing to make time for your proposal?” Parents and Teachers for Excellence concludes: “We believe that teachers and schools are the ones best placed to decide what their students need to know.”

Yet, sometimes policy-makers do offer valuable suggestions.  Education Secretary Damian Hinds recently revealed a new initiative: a ‘bucket list’ or ‘passport’ of activities for primary pupils, encouraging learning outside the classroom.  This recognizes that learning doesn’t have to be confined to school and that parents can be the natural educators.  The passport includes 20 activities for each year group.  Tasks for reception pupils include visiting a farm, painting a self-portrait, making a paper boat, re-telling a story to an audience, and posting a letter.

# Wall Street Growing Cautious on FANG Stocks

Wall Street is getting jittery over FANG stocks, with particular concern focused on tech giant Alphabet. FANG—an acronym created by CNBC's Jim Cramer—represents a basket of high-growth technology stocks: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, and Alphabet (formerly known as Google).

Despite FANG stocks significantly outperforming the market this year—Facebook up 31%, Amazon up 30%, Netflix up 23%, and Alphabet up 22%, compared to the S&P 500's 9% return—analysts are beginning to express valuation concerns.

In a note to clients Thursday, Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Graham downgraded Alphabet to "hold" from "buy," while maintaining his $1,000 price target, which represents just 3% upside from Wednesday's close. The stock, which recently reached the $1,000 level for the first time, is down 2% in Thursday premarket trading following the report.

Graham outlined three key reasons for the downgrade:

1. Limited growth potential: "We think much of the growth over the past two years is due to ad load increases on mobile search and YouTube, which (especially the former) will be hard to repeat."

2. Margin pressure: "Our refreshed detailed segment analysis suggests firmly that consensus gross margin estimates are too high, and while revenue growth mostly makes up for this, we believe this limits the potential for upward EPS revisions."

3. Valuation concerns: "GOOGL's P/E multiple of ~24x is expensive by historical standards, and puts the stock within a pitching wedge of our $1,000 price target."

# COVID-19 Outbreak at Toronto School Reveals Student-to-Student Transmission

Toronto's Chief Medical Officer of Health reports that nearly all COVID-19 cases at Etobicoke's Silverthorn Collegiate Institute stem from student-to-student transmission, with some potentially linked to school events.

## School Closure and Current Status

The school's entire student body of 773 has transitioned to remote learning following Monday evening's outbreak declaration by Toronto Public Health. Of the 11 identified cases, nine appear to have spread between students, with seven remaining active.

Dr. Eileen de Villa noted that investigations revealed multiple opportunities for transmission during various multi-grade activities, both on and off campus. The school's location in the Markland Woods community, where vaccination rates lag behind the city average (73% versus 81.6% for residents 12 and older), has prompted additional preventive measures:

- Establishment of a mobile vaccination clinic on school grounds
- Distribution of take-home COVID-19 testing kits
- Comprehensive contact tracing efforts

## Provincial Context

While Ontario education officials maintain that in-school transmission remains "minimal," Silverthorn's situation presents a concerning counterexample. The outbreak comes amid broader trends in Ontario's education system:

- 117 new cases reported in the latest 24-hour period
- 1,234 active cases across Ontario schools (lowest since September 23)
- 657 schools reporting at least one active case
- 28% of Ontario's total active cases now linked to schools
- At least 230 cohorts in self-isolation across the Greater Toronto and Hamilton Area

## Historical Comparison

Current infection rates exceed those observed during the same period last year:
- 2021: 3,088 total confirmed cases (including 2,713 students)
- 2020: Didn't reach 3,000 cases until November 11

Education Minister Stephen Lecce maintains confidence in existing safety protocols, noting that three-quarters of Ontario schools currently report no active cases despite the Delta variant's prevalence.

The timeline for Silverthorn's return to in-person learning remains undetermined as investigations continue.

On January 29th, TechCrunch reported that Facebook was paying teenagers $20 a month in gift cards to participate in its "Research App."  This app granted Facebook system administrator-level access to users' mobile app activity, web browsing, and even encrypted communications.

Facebook later admitted to Congress that it had paid four times as many teenagers for this unlimited surveillance access than it had initially disclosed just weeks prior.

This revelation sparked outrage, leading Apple to ban all Facebook apps from iOS for violating its Enterprise Certificate rules.  Facebook shut down the Research App and told reporters that only 5% of its users were teenagers with signed parental consent forms.

The following day, TechCrunch reported that Google's Screenwise Meter app also violated Apple's Enterprise Certificate rules, resulting in a similar suspension of Google's iOS apps.  Both Facebook and Google's apps were reinstated by Apple later that same day.

Senator Mark R. Warner (D-VA) demanded transparency from CEO Mark Zuckerberg, requesting information on the percentage of 13- to 18-year-olds incentivized with $20 monthly gift cards to install the Facebook Research App and grant root network access to their data.

In a written statement, Facebook's VP of U.S. Public Policy, Kevin Martin, claimed: "At the time we ended the Facebook Research App on Apple’s iOS platform, less than 5 percent of the people sharing data with us through this program were teens."

On February 7th, MIT Technology Review published a scathing article arguing that the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA), designed to prevent children from joining social media without parental permission, was a failure.  The article cited a 2017 joint poll by the National PTA and Facebook, which found that three out of five American parents knew their under-13 children used messaging apps and social media.

Independent tech analysts claimed that some teenagers had received over $1,000 in Visa gift cards for participating in the Facebook Research App. They highlighted the potential for these online gift cards to be used for illicit purposes, such as accessing pornography or purchasing illegal contraband.

As the scandal continued to unfold, Kevin Martin wrote to Senator Warner on February 20th, revising his previous statement about the Research App: "At the time we ended the Facebook Research App on Apple's iOS platform, less than 5 percent of the people sharing data with us through this program were teens. Analysis shows that number is about 18 percent when you look at the complete lifetime of the program, and also add people who had become inactive and uninstalled the app."

Martin also added: "Potential participants were required to confirm that they were over 18 or provide other evidence of parental consent, though the vendors did not require a signed parental consent form for teen users."

## Government Formation Delays
Three weeks after seizing power, the Taliban has yet to form Afghanistan's new government. The official announcement, initially planned for Friday, remains pending. According to Euronews International Correspondent Anelise Borges, a preliminary list of 13 names has emerged, suggesting Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar as the likely prime minister and Sheikh Hibatullah Akhundzada as the potential supreme leader of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.

The Panjshir Valley stands as the only region outside Taliban control. While social media buzzed with rumors of Taliban victory in the province, local residents denied these claims to AFP.

Former Vice-President Amrullah Saleh, currently in Panjshir, has appealed to the international community to recognize this region as Afghanistan's legitimate seat of power. However, global attention remains focused on the Taliban's next moves.

# Renu Dalal's Simple & Delicious Vegetarian Recipes

Renu Dalal, daughter of celebrated chef, cookbook author, and television presenter Tarla Dalal, has released her second cookbook, "Simple & Delicious Vegetarian Recipes." Following the success of her debut bestseller "Modern Vegetarian Recipes," this new collection features carefully curated recipes chosen for their innovation, health benefits, and ease of preparation. Here are some highlights from the book:

## Stuffed Oats Chilla
A health-conscious twist on traditional chilla, made with oat flour and vegetable stuffing. Perfect for breakfast, a wholesome snack, or main course.

### Ingredients
For the Chilla:
- 1 cup oats (powdered)
- 2 tbsp gram flour (besan)
- 1½ tsp oil
- ½ tsp chopped green chilies
- 1 cup water
- ½ tsp turmeric powder (haldi)
- ½ tsp asafetida (hing)
- 1 tbsp chopped coriander leaves
- Salt to taste
- 3 tsp oil for cooking

For the Vegetable Stuffing:
- ½ cup boiled green peas
- ½ cup boiled potatoes, peeled & chopped
- ½ tbsp oil
- 1 tbsp chopped onions
- 1 tbsp chopped tomatoes
- ½ tsp turmeric powder
- ½ tsp garam masala
- Pinch of asafetida
- Salt and chili powder to taste
- 1 cup tamarind chutney for serving

### Method
1. **For the Stuffing:**
   - Heat oil in a vessel
   - Add turmeric powder, garam masala, asafetida, onions, and tomatoes; sauté for 30 seconds
   - Add green peas, potatoes, salt, and chili powder; cook for 2 minutes

2. **For the Chilla:**
   - Combine gram flour, green chilies, asafetida, coriander, turmeric powder, powdered oats, oil, water, and salt
   - Heat oil in a non-stick pan
   - Pour batter and spread into a round shape
   - Cook both sides until done
   - Add stuffing, fold, and serve hot with tamarind chutney

Cordoba coach Miroslav Djukic characterized Ronaldo's actions, which also included an apparent slap of Edimar as the defender fell and a forearm to the face of Jose Angel Crespo, as "an act of desperation."  Djukic also criticized Ronaldo's gesture towards the Real Madrid badge.

"His gesture with the badge was ugly and conceited," Djukic told Marca.  "Such behavior is unbecoming of the best players in the world, which he and [Barcelona's Lionel] Messi are."

Djukic further suggested that Cordoba's success in containing Ronaldo during the match contributed to the Portuguese international's frustration.  "He wasn't feeling good. That's what caused the whole thing; it stemmed from his desperation," Djukic concluded.

**Spinach and Barley Risotto**

Serves 4 to 6.

**Ingredients:**

- 2 tbsp. sunflower or olive oil  
- 1 1/2 c. barley (hulless or pearled)  
- 1/4 c. minced shallots  
- 1 small bunch green onions, trimmed and chopped  
- 1/4 c. white wine  
- 4 to 5 c. vegetable or chicken stock  
- 3/4 to 1 lb. spinach, rinsed, dried, and sliced into 1/4-in. strips  
- 1/4 c. chopped fresh parsley  
- Generous pinch of grated nutmeg  
- 1/4 c. shredded aged Parmesan cheese  
- Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste  
- Pinch of red pepper flakes  

**Directions:**

1. Heat the oil in a large deep heavy saucepan over medium-high heat. Add the barley, shallots, and green onions, tossing to coat with the oil. Cook until the shallots are tender, about 3 minutes.

2. Stir in the wine, then add the stock 1/2 cup at a time, allowing the barley to absorb the liquid as you stir. Cook until the barley is tender, about 30 minutes for the pearled barley and 40 to 45 minutes for the hulled barley.

3. Toss in the spinach, parsley, and nutmeg, and stir. Then, fold in the cheese. Season to taste with salt, pepper, and red pepper flakes.

**Nutritional Information per Serving** (for 6 servings):

- Calories: 290  
- Fat: 8 g  
- Saturated Fat: 2 g  
- Cholesterol: 0 mg  
- Sodium: 210 mg  
- Carbohydrates: 46 g  
- Dietary Fiber: 10 g  
- Added Sugars: 0 g  
- Protein: 12 g  

**Exchanges per Serving:** 3 starch, ½ medium-fat protein, ½ fat.

**Notes:**  
You can prepare the risotto a day in advance. Reheat and add the spinach and cheese just before serving.

Rents in London have decreased during the Coronavirus pandemic, according to property portal Zoopla. However, London remains an exception, as rents have risen in a vibrant rental market across the UK as a whole.

"Average rents in London have fallen by 5.2 percent over the last 12 months, reaching levels last seen in 2014," Zoopla reported. This decline is attributed to "new working patterns and the lack of tourism during the pandemic."

In contrast, rents outside of London increased by 1.7 percent, and rental demand has surged by a fifth over the past year. This strong demand is driven by a squeeze on lending to potential first-time buyers, Zoopla explained. 

"At the same time, supply remains constrained, with investment in buy-to-let properties still reduced following changes to Stamp Duty (the additional 3 percent surcharge on second properties) and the broader tax regime introduced from 2016 onwards."

Renters are increasingly interested in larger properties, particularly those with access to outdoor spaces. 

"The search for space, first observed in the sales market, is now being strongly replicated by renters. Zoopla's top searches for rental properties include terms like gardens, parking, garages, balconies, and pets, reflecting a need for outdoor space and freedom necessary to cope with lockdown. There is also evidence that while the market as a whole is moving more quickly, the market for rented houses is moving more rapidly than that for rented flats, highlighting this desire for more space among renters."

"For most of the UK, the demand-supply gap is supporting moderate levels of rental growth," said Zoopla's head of research, Gráinne Gilmore.

"The split in the rental market caused by COVID-19 has now become pronounced, and we are witnessing a firmly entrenched two-speed market. 

"We haven't seen an exodus of students from cities, and as more people remain in the rental market due to the squeeze on mortgage lending, higher levels of demand will continue to support rents. However, muted earnings growth will begin to limit the potential for rental growth in some markets. 

"The search for additional space, both indoor and outdoor, within the rental sector is set to continue as the country experiences further lockdown periods."

# U.S. and Taiwan Strengthen Economic Ties Through New Dialogue Initiative

The United States and Taiwan are deepening their economic partnership through a newly established dialogue framework, marking another significant development in the Trump administration's enhanced engagement with the self-governed island.

The cornerstone of this cooperation is a five-year agreement establishing the U.S.-Taiwan Economic Prosperity Partnership Dialogue, designed for annual meetings. While not reaching the scope of a comprehensive bilateral trade agreement, this initiative represents a substantial advancement in Washington-Taipei relations.

Beijing, which maintains its claim over Taiwan and reserves the right to reunify by force if deemed necessary, has expressed strong opposition to these developments.

Brent Christensen, director of the American Institute in Taipei (the de-facto U.S. embassy), emphasized the significance of the dialogue: "This economic partnership not only reflects the robust U.S.-Taiwan economic relationship but also signals its continued growth and evolution."

Recent developments have paved the way for stronger economic ties:

- Taiwan's August 2020 decision to ease restrictions on American beef and pork imports removed a significant trade barrier
- U.S.-Taiwan trade reached approximately $103.9 billion in 2019
- The dialogue encompasses crucial areas including:
  - The State Department's Clean Network project
  - 5G security
  - Semiconductor cooperation
  - Investment screening
  - Scientific and technological collaboration

Taiwan's Foreign Minister Joseph Wu characterized the dialogue as an "important milestone," noting it represents "the highest level regular economic dialogue between the U.S. and Taiwan." He emphasized the importance of identifying specific areas for concrete cooperation and progress.

The talks, conducted partially in person in Washington, were led by U.S. Undersecretary of State Keith Krach and Taiwanese Minister John Deng, with additional participants joining virtually from both sides.

This dialogue follows significant diplomatic exchanges earlier in the year:
- Keith Krach's visit to Taiwan
- Health Secretary Alex Azar's historic visit—the highest-level U.S. Cabinet official to conduct talks in Taipei since 1979
- China's response included military demonstrations, with fighter jets crossing the Taiwan Strait during both visits

The strengthening relationship has also extended to defense cooperation, exemplified by the Trump administration's increased arms sales to Taiwan, including a $2.37 billion Harpoon missile systems deal announced in October.

**Henri: A Northeast Tropical Storm**

NEW YORK — Henri, downgraded to a tropical storm on Sunday, churned inland across the Northeast. Here’s a breakdown of this unusual weather event:

**Henri's Status and Impact**

Henri, downgraded from hurricane status early Sunday, made landfall in Rhode Island at midday. By Sunday evening, it weakened further while moving over western Massachusetts and Connecticut.  While wind speeds decreased to 40 mph (64 kph), the primary threat remains heavy rainfall, leading to potential storm surges and inland flooding, historically more dangerous than high winds.

Henri veered west after landfall, impacting Connecticut and New York's Hudson River Valley with heavy rain and potential flooding. While the storm surge wasn't as significant as Superstorm Sandy in 2012, the storm's slow movement concentrates rainfall, increasing flood risks.  The storm is forecast to move east early Monday, affecting Vermont and New Hampshire before exiting into the Gulf of Maine.

**Hurricanes vs. Tropical Storms**

The distinction lies in sustained wind speeds. Hurricanes have sustained winds of 74 mph or higher, while tropical storms have sustained winds up to 73 mph.

**Historical Context: Henri, Bob, and Gloria**

Henri’s near-hurricane landfall would have been New England's first in 30 years.  Hurricane Bob in August 1991 caused 17 deaths and $1.5 billion in damage.  Connecticut residents may recall Hurricane Gloria in September 1985, which hit Long Island and Connecticut, resulting in eight deaths and nearly $1 billion in damage.

**Storm Naming Conventions**

The World Meteorological Association assigns human names to Atlantic storms, cycling through a list of 21 names each season.

**Formation and Climate Change**

Two factors contribute to northward-tracking storms: a tropical system and steering currents. While rare, Henri's path isn't directly attributed to climate change, although global warming is known to intensify hurricanes, making them stronger and wetter.

**Preparedness and Comparisons**

Residents are advised to take standard precautions: secure boats, fuel vehicles, stock supplies, and prepare for potential power outages, which could last a week or more. While Henri is unlikely to replicate Superstorm Sandy’s impact on New York City and the Jersey Shore, the Hudson River Valley faces significant flood risk.  Unlike Sandy, Henri provided less preparation time.

**Comparisons to Other Storms**

Henri is unrelated to 1991's "Perfect Storm" (also known as the Halloween Storm), a nor'easter that later developed a hurricane at its center.  This unnamed hurricane would have been called "Henri" due to the six-year recycling of Atlantic hurricane names (excluding retired names like Katrina and Bob).  The 2000 film "The Perfect Storm" depicts this event, not Hurricane Bob. While Hurricane Irene in 2011 impacted Vermont, it had weakened to a tropical storm by then.

**Current Situation and Governor's Status**

Despite some schools returning, tourists remain on the Atlantic coast.  Outgoing Governor Cuomo, whose term ends Monday at 11:59 p.m. EDT, is currently managing the state's response to Henri.

# Town's carnival goes 'virtual' for 2020

The organisers of a north Norfolk carnival are pressing on with this year's event - but it will be something out of the ordinary.

Sheringham Carnival, which was to take place August 1-9 but was cancelled in its traditional form due to the pandemic, is now to take place as a 'virtual' event.

A spokesman said the carnival committee was drawing up a timetable of events that could be done online or within family groups at home, and shared via the internet. "On Carnival Day we will be hosting a virtual carnival garden party, so you can join in at home or anywhere," they said. "In these uncertain times we hope our carnival week can bring a little joy back for us all. We miss you, stay safe."

The spokesman added that the carnival committee planned to launch a new website in the coming weeks where people could download pictures, buy t-shirts or donate to support the event.

ETH Zurich, the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, is a leading institution known for its focus on science and technology. Established in 1855, it has become a center of innovation, channeling research into high-tech sectors like computer science, micro and nanotechnology, and medicine. The university boasts an impressive track record, with 21 Nobel laureates having studied, taught, or researched there. ETH Zurich has established its presence beyond Switzerland through initiatives like the Singapore-ETH Centre (SEC).

In 2010, Dr. Remo Burkhard moved to Singapore to build the Singapore-ETH Centre, the first research center established by ETH Zurich outside Switzerland. The center was established in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore under its Campus for Research Excellence and Technological Enterprise (CREATE) program. It aims to tackle pressing urban challenges in collaboration with Singaporean universities, government agencies, and industry.

Since its founding, the Singapore-ETH Centre has become a vibrant research hub with approximately 200 researchers working under two main programs: Future Cities Laboratory (FCL) and Future Resilient Systems (FRS). FCL, established in 2010, focuses on making cities more sustainable and livable, while FRS, launched in 2014, aims to enhance the resilience of infrastructure systems.

A pioneering project under the Future Cities Laboratory is the Cooling Singapore initiative. Led by SEC director Gerhard Schmitt, the project seeks to mitigate the urban heat island (UHI) effect in Singapore and improve outdoor thermal comfort (OTC) and liveability. The initiative aligns with Singapore's commitment to reduce emission intensity by 36% from 2005 levels by 2030.

"As urban centers like Singapore become more densely populated, more heat is generated, impacting the environment. The Cooling Singapore project aims to address these challenges," says Dr. Burkhard. The project received a grant from Singapore's National Research Foundation in 2017, bringing together expertise from the National University of Singapore (NUS), SMART (Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology), and TUMCREATE.

The Cooling Singapore project has a multifaceted approach. It seeks to establish an inter-agency task force comprising members from various Singaporean agencies and institutions to exchange knowledge through workshops. This collaboration is crucial as tackling UHI involves economic development, urban planning, and transportation, requiring the collective effort of scientists, agencies, industry, and policymakers.

One of the project's key tasks is applying microscale climate models to study areas like Jurong Lake District, the Central Business District, and Punggol. These case studies help researchers understand how OTC varies and how different urban designs can mitigate UHI. Initial results suggest a need for more scientific research, pointing towards improving efficiency and cost-effectiveness in strategy implementation.

Beyond policy and planning, businesses and individuals also play a role in mitigating urban heating. "Heat is trapped and released from roads and buildings; energy consumption in industry and transportation are significant contributors to UHI," explains Dr. Burkhard. The Cooling Singapore team has developed a catalog of 86 measures to remove heat from the system, offering guidance on building materials, orientation, and clustering for better wind flow.

Meanwhile, the Future Resilient Systems program and the ETH Risk Centre organized the inaugural Infrastructure Resilience Conference in Zurich, fostering knowledge exchange to enhance infrastructure resilience. The upcoming World Congress on Resilience, Reliability and Asset Management will continue these efforts in Singapore.

The Singapore-ETH Centre is also collaborating on the Digital Underground project with the Singapore Land Authority, aiming to develop 3D digital mapping methods for underground utility networks. This is crucial as Singapore explores the use of underground spaces due to limited land mass.

In addition to these projects, the 3for2 Beyond Efficiency project has adapted energy-efficient technologies developed at ETH Zurich for tropical climates. Implemented at United World College Southeast Asia, Dover campus, preliminary results show a significant reduction in energy consumption, making it one of Singapore's most energy-efficient office spaces.

ETH Zurich's initiatives in Singapore exemplify its commitment to global challenges. With a focus on freedom, responsibility, and open-mindedness, ETH Zurich fosters an environment for independent thinking and pioneering solutions. As Lino Guzzella, President of ETH Zurich, notes, "A good university doesn't just teach knowledge but the ability to think." This ethos drives the university's innovative contributions to society and public debate.

**Belarus Faces New Sanctions Over Jetliner Incident and Journalist Arrest**

Western nations are preparing to impose new sanctions on Belarus and sever its aviation links after it dispatched a warplane to intercept a Ryanair aircraft, resulting in the arrest of a dissident journalist. This action has been condemned by officials as "state piracy." The arrested journalist, 26-year-old Roman Protasevich, appeared in an online video, claiming he was in good health while in pretrial detention in Minsk, and admitted to organizing mass disturbances in the capital last year. However, his allies, including his father, dismissed these statements as being made under duress.

Polish Deputy Foreign Minister Pawel Jablonski reported that Protasevich's mother had expressed concerns about his health, though details remain scant. Meanwhile, Belarus’ Interior Ministry stated that Protasevich was in jail without health complaints. U.S. President Joe Biden condemned Belarus's actions and requested options to hold those responsible accountable.

U.S. National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan, in a call with exiled Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, reiterated the United States' support for democracy, human rights, and fundamental freedoms for the Belarusian people. The White House conveyed these sentiments.

European Union leaders, meeting in Brussels, called for a ban on Belarusian airlines from the 27-nation bloc's airspace and urged EU-based carriers to avoid Belarus airspace. They also agreed to expand the list of sanctioned Belarusian individuals and requested an urgent investigation by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) into the Ryanair plane’s forced landing in Minsk during its Greece-Lithuania flight.

Belgian Prime Minister Alexander de Croo emphasized the need for a "swift and severe" reaction. Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney described the incident as "aviation piracy, state-sponsored." EU and other Western countries have also demanded Protasevich's release, whose social media platform, maintained in exile, remains one of the few independent news outlets about Belarus following last year’s crackdown on dissent. Accompanying Protasevich, 23-year-old student Sofia Sapega was also detained.

Some nations and airlines preemptively reacted to the Ryanair flight diversion. Britain instructed its airlines to avoid Belarus and suspended the air permit for Belarus's national carrier, Belavia, effective immediately. KLM, part of Air France KLM, temporarily halted flights over Belarus, as reported by Dutch news agency ANP.

Despite these actions, options for Western retaliation seem limited. The ICAO lacks regulatory power, and the EU cannot control flights over Belarus, except those departing from or arriving in Europe. Skipping Belarusian airspace would increase travel time and costs.

Previous rounds of U.S. and EU financial sanctions on Minsk have had little effect on President Alexander Lukashenko's behavior, who survived mass protests following a disputed election. Lukashenko has consistently denied election fraud. Since then, authorities have detained thousands of his opponents, with prominent figures either imprisoned or exiled.

Protasevich’s former employer, NEXTA, interviewed his mother, who suspected a bomb threat on the flight as a ruse to capture her son. "I just want to say that my son is simply a hero," she declared tearfully, urging international awareness. His father, Dzmitry Protasevich, described the situation as "total insanity."

Belarus claims it acted due to a false bomb threat attributed to Hamas, a claim the group denies. State media reported the intervention as a direct order from Lukashenko. Ryanair’s CEO Michael O’Leary described the event as a state-sponsored hijacking, suggesting security agents were on board. Lithuanian officials noted that five passengers, including Protasevich and Sapega, did not continue the flight, suggesting three others disembarked in Minsk.

Meanwhile, Russia, a supporter of Lukashenko, accused the West of hypocrisy.

# Dutch Paper Alleges Huawei's Hidden 'Backdoor' in Major Telecom Network

According to a Thursday report by Dutch newspaper De Volkskrant, Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei allegedly maintained a concealed "backdoor" in a major Dutch telecommunications network, potentially enabling unauthorized access to customer data. The report cites confidential intelligence sources.

The Dutch General Intelligence and Security Service (AIVD) is reportedly investigating whether this security vulnerability could have facilitated surveillance activities by the Chinese government.

When contacted, a Huawei representative firmly rejected these allegations, stating: "We comply with laws and rules in every country where we operate." The spokesperson further emphasized that Huawei "keeps the door closed to governments or others who want to use our network for activities that would threaten cybersecurity."

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced at the Labour congress an extension of the government's small business loan scheme until the end of the year, providing continued support during uncertain economic times.  Originally set to expire on July 24, the scheme offers interest-free loans for up to one year (3% interest thereafter) with no repayments required for the first two years.  This extension ensures businesses facing potential future cash flow difficulties will retain access to crucial funding.

“This means those businesses who are doing okay now, but who may experience cash flow difficulties further down the track, will still have access to it,” Ardern told the assembled party members at Te Papa.  Later, speaking to media, she emphasized the advantage of these loans over cash grants (as previously recommended by Treasury and the National Party), highlighting the flexibility they offer. “Sometimes they’ve drawn it down not necessarily needing it straight away, but being concerned they wouldn’t be able to access it down the track. What this does is say that if you don’t need it, you don’t have to apply but it will be there for several more months."

Eligibility criteria remain unchanged: businesses with 50 or fewer employees who qualified for the original wage subsidy can apply for loans of $10,000 plus $1,800 per equivalent full-time employee, up to a maximum of $100,000.  The existing $5.2 billion allocated to the scheme remains sufficient, as Small Business Minister Stuart Nash previously stated that uptake was not expected to reach this maximum figure, which was based on every eligible business applying.

Since May 12th, over 90,000 small businesses have applied for loans totaling more than $1.51 billion. The majority of applicants operate in construction, accommodation, restaurants and cafes, retail trade, transport, and manufacturing. Data shows that around 80% of applicants have one to five employees, and over 90% have ten or fewer. "The average value of each loan is modest, around $16,700. But it is much-needed working capital to help in a tight spot," Nash said.

(CNN) — Speaking from his Mar-a-Lago estate on Friday, a day after the strike that killed Qasem Soleimani, President Donald Trump said he authorized the precision strike against the commander of Iran's security and intelligence services because he was plotting "imminent and sinister attacks" on Americans.  "We caught him in the act and terminated him," Trump said, adding that Soleimani should have been taken out by his predecessors.

Trump cast his decision as one of deterrence, not aggression. "We took action last night to stop a war. We did not take action to start a war," he said.  While seeking to portray the strike as preventative, Trump continued to threaten Iran's leaders with further strikes should they continue destabilizing actions in the region.

"We do not seek regime change," Trump stated, adding that Iran's use of proxy fights "must end and it must end now." He declared, "The future belongs to the people of Iran."

Trump boasted of US military might and intelligence capabilities.  "We have the best intelligence in the world," he said. "If Americans anywhere are threatened, we have all of those targets already fully identified, and I am ready and prepared to take whatever action is necessary, and that in particular refers to Iran."

CHEYENNE, Wyo. (AP) — Five days after testing positive for COVID-19, Wyoming Governor Mark Gordon continues to experience mild symptoms.  He remained in isolation while working remotely on Monday, according to spokesman Michael Pearlman.  The governor's wife, Jennie Gordon, tested negative and is isolating separately.

Two staff members in the governor's office have also tested positive.  All other recent close contacts of the governor have tested negative, Pearlman confirmed.

Governor Gordon first experienced symptoms on November 22nd and immediately took an at-home test.  He received a second test at a medical clinic on Wednesday.  Both the at-home test and the clinic test returned positive results.

The source of Governor Gordon's infection remains unclear, Pearlman stated.

# The Rich History and Art of Irish Coffee

Irish Coffee, a timeless caffeinated cocktail, is elegantly simple with just three core ingredients, keeping whiskey as its centerpiece. As National Irish Coffee Day approaches on January 25, this beloved drink, enjoyed worldwide from brunch to dessert, deserves special recognition.

## Origins and Evolution

The story begins in the early 1940s at the Foynes Airbase Flying Boat Terminal Building in Limerick, Ireland. Chef Joseph Sheridan created the drink for stranded passengers, combining good Irish whiskey with hot coffee. When a passenger asked if he had used Brazilian coffee, Sheridan famously quipped, "No, that was Irish Coffee!"

The drink's journey to America came through Stanton Delaplane, a San Francisco Chronicle travel writer, who discovered it at Shannon Airport. Collaborating with the Buena Vista Cafe's owners Jack Koeppler and George Freeberg, Delaplane helped introduce Irish Coffee to the United States on November 10, 1952. The team even enlisted help from San Francisco's mayor, George Christopher, who suggested using cream aged at least forty-eight hours for better flotation. Through Delaplane's widely-read travel column, the drink gained popularity across America.

## Modern Mastery

While the Buena Vista Cafe has served millions of Irish Coffees since its introduction, the drink has evolved globally. However, few establishments have mastered it like The Dead Rabbit in New York City. Jack McGarry, co-owner of the legendary Irish cocktail bar, emphasizes the importance of perfect balance: "Most places around the world, it's got too much coffee or whiskey, terrible cream, too sweet or too dry or too hot."

McGarry's approach treats Irish Coffee like any refined cocktail, where all ingredients are present but none dominate. He serves it at precisely 75 degrees Celsius and uses Sumatra coffee from Indonesia for its rich body and earthy, chocolatey notes.

## The Dead Rabbit's Irish Coffee Recipe

```
Ingredients:
- 0.5 oz Demerara Syrup
- 1 oz Bushmills Original Irish Whiskey
- 3.5 oz unsweetened coffee
- Freshly whipped cream for topping

Directions: [Original text ends before providing directions]
```

While many modern variations exist, often incorporating unnecessary frilly toppings and sugary syrups, The Dead Rabbit's version is widely respected as one of the finest interpretations of this classic drink.

# Jamie Lynn Spears Opens Up About Teen Pregnancy and 'Zoey 101' Legacy

Jamie Lynn Spears has broken her silence about her teenage pregnancy, which made headlines nearly 13 years ago while she was starring in Nickelodeon's "Zoey 101." Now 29 and mother to two children—12-year-old Maddie and 2-year-old Ivey—Spears recently shared her story while promoting a reimagined version of the show's theme song.

In a candid interview with NYLON, Spears recalled the overwhelming emotions of discovering her pregnancy at 16. "You have your first love, or what you call love in high school. You think it's forever, and then suddenly—I'm pregnant," she revealed. "I was mortified to tell my parents and family. TMZ's opinion was the least of my concerns."

She continued, "I was focused on the people I loved who I had to tell, and the reality that I was practically a child myself carrying another life."

## Setting the Record Straight

Spears definitively addressed long-standing rumors about "Zoey 101's" conclusion. "The pregnancy happened approximately six months after we wrapped filming," she clarified. "While there were discussions with Nickelodeon about airing the remaining episodes, the show had naturally concluded—we had simply outgrown it."

During her pregnancy, Spears retreated to Louisiana, purchasing a gated property where she could prepare for motherhood away from the spotlight. "I chose to face my reality head-on," she explained. "Though I wasn't condoning teenage pregnancy, these were my circumstances, and I was determined to handle them responsibly."

## Life After 'Zoey 101'

Following her split from Casey Aldridge (her daughter's father) in 2010, Spears found love again with businessman Jamie Watson. The couple married in 2014 and welcomed a daughter in 2018.

## Career Revelations

In an unexpected disclosure, Spears shared that she had auditioned for "Twilight"—reluctantly, at her management's insistence. "I thought they were crazy suggesting I play a vampire," she remembered. "Ironically, I felt ill during the audition, where I believe Lily Collins was also present. Unknown to me at the time, I was pregnant."

Spears is now embracing her "Zoey 101" legacy with "Follow Me (Zoey 101)"—a reimagined version of the show's theme song, originally co-written by her sister Britney Spears and newly remixed by DJ Chantel Jeffries. The track releases October 22 at 10:22 PM.

# Olympic Glory: Hidilyn Diaz's Historic Gold Medal Journey

*Photo: Hidilyn Diaz competing in the women's 55kg weightlifting event at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan. (AP Photo/Luca Bruno)*

From humble beginnings with a bamboo pole to Olympic glory, weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz's grueling journey to the Tokyo Games reached its pinnacle on the Olympic podium. Her victory marked a historic milestone as she secured the Philippines' first gold medal since the nation began competing in the Summer Olympics in 1924.

In a stunning upset, Diaz outperformed Chinese world record holder Liao Qiuyun with her final lift. The triumph was especially poignant given the challenges she faced during the pandemic, including training in isolation in Malaysia, far from her loved ones.

"I'm looking forward to reuniting with my family in the Philippines—I've missed them dearly," Diaz shared. "After nearly three years in Malaysia, I'm grateful to finally return home and celebrate this achievement with them."

A seasoned Olympian, Diaz's remarkable career includes four Olympic appearances, the honor of carrying her nation's flag at the 2012 London Games' opening ceremony, and a silver medal from the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics.

"This is a dream realized," Diaz declared with emotion. "I want to show that we Filipinos are strong and capable of Olympic success. To the young generation in the Philippines: dream big. That's how my journey began—with big dreams that I finally achieved."

Her path to victory required extraordinary adaptability. During the pandemic lockdown, when her gym closed, Diaz improvised by creating training equipment from water bottles attached to a bamboo pole, performing overhead lifts and squats to maintain her strength.

Diaz, who serves as a sergeant in the Philippines Air Force, offered a respectful salute on the podium.

**GREEN BAY, Wis. —** Dale Cihlar, typically a buoyant and optimistic farmer, found himself in despair. Several of his prized dairy cows had died, milk prices were plummeting, and he faced a $1,600 monthly payment for a new manure storage system.

"I've never been in debt like this," said Dale, a fourth-generation dairy farmer who took over the family farm in 1990. He and his wife, Karen, sat at their kitchen table, surrounded by a mound of paperwork—some detailing milk prices, others highlighting their income struggles.

After unsuccessful appeals to various banks, Dale considered selling part of the farm to make ends meet. However, Karen had a different plan, one she hadn't shared with her husband.

"He's too proud, but I thought if people knew, maybe they would help," she told USA Today Network-Wisconsin.

Karen took to GoFundMe, a crowdfunding platform, to write a heartfelt plea to save the family farm. Her adult children and their friends shared the campaign on Facebook, and donations began to trickle in. As word spread on social media, Karen received calls from local farmers offering help, including one who had extra hay.

The community, including friends, family, and strangers, rallied to prevent the demise of another family farm. Donations poured in from people in other states as well.

Since 1873, the Cihlar family has farmed the 110-acre property, sustaining the family for generations. To handle the historical fluctuations in milk prices, Dale had embraced the budgeting practices of his forebears, saving diligently to cover large expenses and ride out price swings.

Frugality was so ingrained in Dale's psyche that he didn't marry Karen until he made his last payment on the family farm. Although milk prices had been low before, they had never been this low for three consecutive years.

Savings among dairy farmers were depleting across the state. Wisconsin lost 500 dairy farms in 2017, and more than 150 had quit milking cows so far this year. The number of milk herds dropped by 20% from five years ago, according to the state Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection.

The Cihlar farm weathered these highs and lows until a perfect storm of issues hit. The historically low milk checks worsened after several prized cows died, and the $1,600 monthly manure storage system payment drained the farm’s savings.

Dale and Karen managed to squeak by on Karen’s salary from the Door County Medical Center, but their savings were exhausted. For over 100 years, the 110-acre farm and 40 cows had supported the Cihlar family.

"I couldn't be the last one. I've always thought this farm would last and be part of my family far into the future," Dale said.

In less than a month, the GoFundMe page Karen created raised enough money to buy one cow. After a month, they'd raised nearly $8,000 of the $35,000 goal.

"I started to cry. I couldn't believe that people were actually helping us," Karen said.

When Karen showed Dale the GoFundMe site and the donations, he was dumbfounded.

"There are so many causes needing help, and I thought no one would ever want to help a farmer," Dale said, shaking his head. "I was wrong; this is beyond words."

The cost of a dairy cow ranges from $1,000 to $1,600, with significant additional expenses for feed and veterinary care.

While the financial support was crucial, the campaign had a broader impact by highlighting the plight of dairy farmers and showing that people can help. Offers of free feed poured in, and farmers leaving the business sold some stock to the Cihlars at reduced rates to ensure the farm's success.

Dale's extended family also pitched in to keep the farm within the family.

"I'm the only cousin still in farming, and this farm means a lot to them too," he said.

Besides the donations, Dale took a part-time truck-driving job to help make ends meet. Despite knowing firsthand the challenges of dairy farming, both Dale's stepson and son-in-law are determined to keep the farm in the family. They plan to take over when Dale retires, assisting with farm chores while maintaining their day jobs.

"They help out every morning and night and know it's not easy," Dale said.

Ethan Lautenbach, Karen's son from her first marriage, shares Dale's passion for farming.

"It's a challenge every day," Ethan said, adding that he enjoys the lifestyle.

Son-in-law Steven Baxter grew up on a small goat farm in Texas and is president of the Door County Farm Bureau. Like Dale, Steven is captivated by the animals and sees them as integral to the business.

"If it wasn't for their milk, we wouldn't have a dairy," Steven said. "When a calf is born, it's a miracle, and we do everything to ensure it grows up healthy because, in the long run, that cow is what takes care of us."

Press Release: Dominica Fire Brigade Receives Timely Assistance

In the wake of Hurricane Maria's devastation, the local fire brigade in Dominica has been tirelessly engaged in post-disaster cleanup and restoration efforts, while also fulfilling its routine firefighting responsibilities in and around the capital city of Roseau.

Last week, the brigade issued an urgent plea for help when a crucial piece of equipment, a fire pump, required immediate replacement. The absence of this essential pump would have severely limited the brigade's ability to provide crucial assistance to communities in urgent need.

Responding swiftly to this call for aid, Stephen Lander, CIBC FirstCaribbean's Country Head in Dominica, took action by reaching out to the bank's philanthropic arm, the Comtrust Foundation. Within a remarkably short timeframe, a new fire pump was secured in Barbados, swiftly procured, and then transported to Dominica by the Barbados Coast Guard. Over the weekend, Lander personally delivered the pump to Josiah Dupuis, the Fire Chief of the Dominica Fire Brigade.

Chief Dupuis expressed deep gratitude on behalf of the fire brigade, the residents of Roseau, and the surrounding areas, emphasizing how the timely acquisition of the pump would significantly bolster their ongoing recovery and firefighting operations.

CIBC FirstCaribbean has pledged a generous sum of up to US$100,000 for relief initiatives in Dominica. This commitment comes in addition to an earlier donation of US$450,000 made by both the bank and its parent company, CIBC, to support the Caribbean nations impacted by Hurricane Irma.

Since its establishment in 2002, the bank has consistently earmarked a minimum of US$1 million annually to support various noble causes throughout the Caribbean.
