# Google Pixel 3 XL Hands-On Review: Evolution, Not Revolution

Google has taken a page from Apple's playbook with its Pixel 3 XL, essentially iterating on the Pixel 2 XL's design while adding a controversial notch to the display. While this incremental approach might disappoint Android enthusiasts, we spent some hands-on time with the device to evaluate its merits.

## Design and Display

Google has maintained its signature Pixel aesthetic while making subtle refinements. The distinctive two-tone rear panel now features either a glossy or matte glass finish, available in three colors: Just Black, Not Pink (a subtle rose hue), and Clearly White.

The front showcases an expanded 6.3-inch display, up from the Pixel 2 XL's 6-inch screen, while maintaining identical physical dimensions. This feat was achieved by extending the display to the chassis edges and incorporating a notch for the front cameras and earpiece. As with its predecessor, the 3.5mm headphone jack remains absent, requiring users to embrace either wireless audio or dongles.

The 1440x2960 OLED display shows marked improvement over its predecessor, exhibiting none of the color shifting or muted tones that plagued the Pixel 2 XL's pOLED screen. Initial impressions of image quality, website rendering, and general content consumption are positive, though extended testing will be necessary for a definitive assessment.

However, the notch design proves problematic. While notches have become commonplace in modern smartphones, the Pixel 3 XL's implementation is particularly conspicuous. Unlike the subtle notch of the OnePlus 6, this deeper, more prominent cutout draws unnecessary attention to itself, despite housing dual front-facing cameras.

## Performance

The Pixel 3 XL ships with Android 9 Pie and Google's Pixel Launcher interface. Performance is exemplary, thanks to the combination of the Snapdragon 845 processor, 4GB of RAM, and Google's optimization efforts. While Qualcomm will likely introduce a new flagship processor in early 2019, the current chipset should remain capable for years to come.

Storage options include a generous 128GB capacity, complemented by Google's cloud storage offerings.

## Camera

Google continues to buck the dual-camera trend, opting instead for a single rear lens enhanced by sophisticated AI processing. The system captures multiple images simultaneously, combining the best elements to produce optimal results. Based on initial testing, the camera appears to maintain the Pixel line's reputation for photographic excellence.

The dual front-facing cameras enable wider-angle selfies and support various creative features, including automatic capture triggered by facial expressions and adjustable Portrait mode depth effects.

## Initial Verdict

While the Pixel 3 XL offers few surprises—thanks to numerous pre-release leaks—it appears to be a capable flagship device that showcases Android at its finest. However, with a premium price point of £869, potential buyers should consider alternatives like the OnePlus 6 and Samsung's Galaxy S9 and Note 9 before making a decision.

A full review will follow to provide comprehensive analysis, particularly regarding the controversial notch design and overall value proposition in today's competitive Android landscape.

Arthur Moats, the former Pittsburgh Steeler known for his on-field ferocity—including the tackle that ended Brett Favre’s legendary 297 consecutive game streak—is not easily intimidated. Yet, the 6-foot, 240-pound linebacker admits to feeling fear when offered a one-year, veteran’s minimum “prove it” deal with the Steelers in 2014.  He wrestled with the uncertainty: Was his career over? Should he uproot his life and move from Buffalo to Pittsburgh?

“A lot of people have paralysis through analysis,” Moats explains. “They overthink and allow fear to become a blocking force.” His advice?  “Use that fear as motivation. Take the chance and see what you’re able to accomplish.”  Moats confronted his fear, thrived in Pittsburgh, and earned a three-year contract after that initial season.

Since retiring in 2019, he’s dedicated himself to a lifelong passion: improving lives.  His book, *Theory of Life* (Leadership League), outlines a five-point plan for better living based on the acronym M.O.A.T.S.: Make happiness a priority; Openness yields strength; Actively inspire others; Turn fear into focus; Smile, spread my inner love everywhere.

This philosophy stems from his upbringing in the Tidewater region of Virginia.  Raised by ministers, he developed a strong sense of duty to others. Recognizing that his stable childhood was an ideal not everyone experiences, Moats emphasizes the importance of adult mentorship for children in challenging circumstances. “Whether it’s an uncle or other family member,” he says, “it’s important to have someone they can look to for advice and direction.”

While each element of M.O.A.T.S. is crucial, Moats is particularly passionate about actively inspiring others.  “Many people mistakenly believe they need wealth, success, or a platform to be inspirational,” he notes. “But inspiration is simply instilling belief in someone.  Acknowledging their efforts, offering encouragement, or empathizing with their struggles – it costs nothing.”  He believes that once people understand this simplicity, they’ll be more willing to inspire those around them.

Throughout *Theory of Life*, Moats quotes inspirational figures like Hellen Keller, Rosa Parks, Booker T. Washington, Paulo Coelho, Dr. Joyce Brothers, and Lao Tzu—a diverse group notably lacking in athletes. This unconventional approach is characteristic of Moats, who has always charted his own course.

Bank of Beijing will extend a 10 billion yuan ($1.6 billion) credit line to Tencent Holdings Ltd, strengthening the Chinese Internet giant's position in the competitive online finance sector against rival Alibaba.

The partnership will primarily support Bank of Beijing's Jingyitong initiative, which enables users to access medical care and other services through a chip-enabled card system, the companies announced on Wednesday.

This move comes as Tencent expands its financial services offerings. In January, the company launched trial operations of WeBank, a government-endorsed service providing loans to individuals and small and medium-sized businesses.

# Stolen SANDF Weapons Trafficked to War Zones, Investigation Reveals

Military-grade weapons from the South African National Defence Force (SANDF), including devastating machine guns capable of dismembering targets, have been stolen and reportedly smuggled across South African borders for use in conflict zones.

The trafficking operation has potentially been facilitated by existing gaps in firearms legislation. More alarmingly, sources indicate these weapons may have been used against South African soldiers deployed internationally.

While authorities intercepted some weapons, including rocket launchers, before they left South African territory, intelligence sources confirm that numerous arms have successfully crossed borders and are currently deployed in active conflict zones. Officials also express concern about the possibility of stolen military weapons being stockpiled for potential use against the state.

A National Prosecuting Authority letter from August last year, addressed to the Western Cape police commissioner, details a comprehensive firearms investigation. The document emphasizes that removing the lead investigator could "prove to be detrimental" and reveals that the initial investigation has expanded significantly.

The letter specifically highlights how "loopholes in the firearms legislation and regulations are used to facilitate trans-border smuggling of firearms" from South Africa to other nations. It further notes that "investigation is required into the import and export of firearms by individuals and/or arms dealers for illicit means," potentially violating South Africa's arms embargoes and international protocols.

## Right-Wing Connections

The investigation uncovered potential links to right-wing groups. In December 2015, law enforcement discovered a cache of weapons during a raid in Bothasig, Cape Town, including:
- Thousands of rounds of ammunition
- Silencers
- Various weapons
- Nazi and AWB paraphernalia

The raid led to the arrest of Keith Conroy, 71, reportedly a former right-hand man to late AWB leader Eugene Terre'Blanche.

## Underground Market

Beyond conflict zones, sources indicate these weapons are being channeled into an underground collectors' market, where firearms used in actual combat command premium prices.

## Legal Proceedings

A significant case involving SANDF weapons trafficking is pending in the Western Cape High Court. Businessman Irshaad Laher and arms dealer Alan Raves face charges related to a syndicate that allegedly diverted at least 2,000 firearms marked for destruction.

The amended indictment accuses Raves of stealing multiple weapons from the Durban Light Infantry between 2012 and 2015, including:
- Vickers 7.62mm machine gun (nicknamed "chainsaw" for its devastating effect)
- Vektor SS 77 machine gun (prototype model)
- Gorjunov light machine gun
- RPD light machine gun

The defendants face multiple charges, including racketeering, corruption, theft, and possession of prohibited firearms. Their next court appearance is scheduled for May 12.

*The SANDF has not responded to requests for comment, while the SA Police Service has indicated they will provide a statement at a later time.*

The recent guilty plea by Michael Flynn for lying to the FBI, coupled with his agreement to cooperate against his former employer, has sparked renewed discussions about presidential impeachment. While some commentators, including a CNN.com columnist and former Deputy Assistant Attorney General Harry Litman, suggest impeachment may be imminent, it's crucial to distinguish between bringing impeachment charges and successfully removing a president from office.

Despite the developments in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation since May, the practical likelihood of a successful impeachment has arguably diminished. This paradox stems from impeachment being fundamentally a political process rather than a legal one.

The mathematics of impeachment are stark: A House majority must pass articles of impeachment, requiring—if voted on today—22 Republican representatives to join a unified Democratic vote. Even if Democrats capture the House in the next election and pass articles independently, conviction in the Senate demands a two-thirds majority, necessitating approximately 15 Republican senators.

Such widespread Republican defection has become increasingly improbable, primarily because GOP voters have demonstrated unwavering loyalty to Trump despite controversial developments. According to Gallup polling:

- 84% Republican approval when Mueller was appointed
- 87% approval following Donald Trump Jr.'s Russia email revelations
- 81% approval in late November
- Never below 79% since inauguration

Conversely, Republican senators who have challenged Trump have faced severe political consequences. Consider:

- Senator Jeff Flake (Arizona): After publishing criticism of Trump, his approval among Republican constituents plummeted, leading to his decision not to seek reelection
- Senator Bob Corker (Tennessee): Following his pointed criticism of Trump's fitness for office, his support among Tennessee Republicans swung dramatically from +40 points in February to -12 points by October, similarly resulting in his retirement announcement

François Legault and his Coalition Avenir Québec (CAQ) have devised a cynical, divisive, and inhumane immigration policy, exploiting Canada's federal system to deflect responsibility for its harshest consequences.  L’actualité magazine recently revealed the CAQ’s plan, which threatens to expel immigrants after four years if they fail French and "values" tests.  However, the CAQ wouldn’t conduct the expulsions themselves.  Lacking that authority, they would deny immigrants the Quebec selection certificate required for permanent residency and report them to Ottawa as being in the country illegally, leaving the federal government to handle the removals. This allows the CAQ to appear tough on immigration while blaming Ottawa for any resulting hardship.

This scheme mirrors the CAQ’s approach to defining the very “values” immigrants are expected to uphold.  Instead of providing specifics, the CAQ has deferred the task to unelected civil servants, conveniently delaying any potentially controversial details until after the October election. Legault's waffling on the issue further underscores this lack of clarity.  For example, he publicly reversed his position on whether wearing a facial veil would constitute a failure of the values test within the same interview, echoing the indecision displayed by Liberal Justice Minister Stéphanie Vallée on similar issues last year.

While some defend the CAQ policy by pointing to existing requirements for immigrants to sign a declaration promising to respect Quebec values and learn French, these comparisons are misleading.  The declaration is signed *before* arrival, not after years of settling in.  And while applicants for Canadian citizenship must pass a test, failure does not lead to expulsion.  The CAQ’s policy, on the other hand, threatens to uproot settled immigrants after years of contributing to Quebec society, subjecting them to prolonged uncertainty and stress.

Legault’s policy is not only inhumane but also deeply divisive.  It stigmatizes immigrants as threats to Quebec's language and values, playing on anxieties for electoral gain. He blames immigrants for potential integration challenges, ignoring systemic discrimination and refusing to acknowledge its well-documented existence.  Ultimately, this policy sends a clear message to immigrants: you are not welcome here. This may be the one area where the policy proves “successful,” as it could deter immigration to Quebec, achieving the CAQ's stated objective of reducing immigration numbers.

In short, Legault's immigration policy is a cynical ploy designed to appeal to nativist sentiments while shirking responsibility for its consequences. It’s a strategy that preys on fear and division, ultimately harming both immigrants and Quebec society as a whole.

Following the division of their households, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle formally separated from the Royal Foundation, the charity they previously shared with Prince William and Kate Middleton.  A recent report reveals that all references to the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have been removed from the charity's website.

The *Daily Mail* reports that the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are now listed as the sole principals of the Royal Foundation, with the Duke of Cambridge further designated as its founding member.  Originally launched in 2009 by Princes William and Harry to support the charitable endeavors of the British Royal Family, the organization later welcomed Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle as patrons after their respective marriages.

The website has been purged of not only their names but also any mention of the Sussexes' projects.  Prince Harry's Invictus Games and the community cookbook he launched with his wife, previously featured under the "Programmes" section, have been removed.

The homepage now features only the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.  The charity's programmes are categorized under five headings: mental health, conservation, service, young people, and early years.  A section previously titled "Empowering Communities," highlighting Meghan Markle’s work on female empowerment, has also been removed.

The homepage now states: "Driven by a desire to make a difference together, The Royal Foundation is the primary philanthropic and charitable vehicle for The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge,"  emphasizing their focus on wildlife conservation and mental health.

This move followed the Sussexes' decision to relocate from Kensington Palace and establish their own independent charity, Sussex Royal.  The June announcement of their household separation stated: "The couple will be establishing their home at Frogmore Cottage on the Windsor Castle estate."

These decisions have fueled rumors of a rift between the brothers and their wives. However, royal sources have denied such allegations, stating the move reflects the couples' preparations for "their future roles, which are obviously on divergent tracks."

# Unacademy Acquires Professional Networking Platform TapChief in Rs 100 Crore Deal

Edtech startup Unacademy announced on Tuesday its acquisition of TapChief, a professional networking and "future-of-work" platform, in a deal valued at Rs 100 crore. Under the agreement, Unacademy will acquire a majority stake in TapChief and facilitate the exit of all existing investors, with TapChief joining the Unacademy Group.

## About TapChief

Founded in 2016 by BITS Pilani alumni Shashank Murali, Binay Krishna, and Arjun Krishna, TapChief has built a robust platform that enables professionals to:
- Interact and learn from domain experts
- Collaborate with businesses worldwide
- Build their personal brand online

The platform has achieved significant milestones:
- Over 1.5 lakh registered professionals
- More than 50,000 completed gigs for various organizations
- Services provided to 150+ enterprise customers across sectors including education, FMCG, e-commerce, enterprise SaaS, and upskilling

## Strategic Alignment

"Our endeavour at Unacademy has always been to democratise education and make learning accessible and affordable for everyone. TapChief shares a similar ethos in a different space, as evident from the open community of professionals and learners they've created," said Gaurav Munjal, Co-Founder and CEO of Unacademy Group.

Expressing enthusiasm about the acquisition, Munjal added, "Shashank and his team have delivered promising results in a short span of time and I am delighted to welcome the TapChief team to the Unacademy Group."

A major development project on Edinburgh's outskirts is actively seeking new tenants, aiming to create significant employment opportunities in the area.

The development, located at Heriot-Watt Research Park, features a 32,000-square-foot facility combining science laboratories and office space. CSPG, led by entrepreneur Mark Emlick, is spearheading the search for new tenants while managing the renovation process on behalf of the landlord. - Research and development
- Design and engineering
- Training programs
- Prototyping activities

The Lok Sabha passed the GST (Compensation to States) Amendment Bill, 2017 on Wednesday, increasing the cess on luxury vehicles from 15% to 25% to compensate states for revenue losses after the GST rollout.  The bill replaces a September ordinance enacted for the same purpose.  Finance Minister Arun Jaitley, responding to a short debate, confirmed the increased cess revenue would be used for state compensation. He highlighted that the GST Council, including state finance ministers, meets monthly to rationalize taxes based on revenue collection.

During the debate, members advocated for reduced GST rates on various items like sanitary napkins, agricultural equipment, handicrafts, handloom products, and sports goods. Some even proposed a single GST slab instead of the current four.

However, the debate was disrupted by uproar from the opposition, specifically the Congress and TMC, over controversial comments made by Union Minister Anant Kumar Hegde regarding secularism and the Constitution.  At a Karnataka function on Sunday, Hegde reportedly questioned the identity of those who call themselves secular without acknowledging their religious background, and also declared an intent to change the Constitution.

Parliamentary Affairs Minister Anant Kumar attempted to defuse the situation, claiming Hegde's remarks were being distorted, but this failed to appease the opposition, who continued their protests and demanded Hegde's resignation, forcing four adjournments.

Despite the disruptions, the discussion on the GST bill continued.  BJD member Bhartruhari Mahtab noted that the full impact of GST on the exchequer would be clear after January, once implementation stabilized. He revealed that the center had provided over ₹1,000 crore in compensation to Odisha and ₹2,000 crore to West Bengal in the past three months.  AIADMK's T G Venkatesh Babu, JDU's Kaushalendra Kumar, and SAD's Prem Singh Chandumajhra requested special packages for Tamil Nadu, Bihar, and Punjab, respectively.

ROME (Reuters) -  Italy is grappling with a severe coronavirus crisis and a deep economic recession.  On Wednesday, President Sergio Mattarella moved swiftly to address the situation, asking former European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi to form a new government.  Mattarella’s action followed the collapse of outgoing Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte’s coalition government on Tuesday evening.  The president stressed the urgency of the situation, warning that Italy risked missing out on over 200 billion euros ($243 billion) in European Union recovery funds if a new government wasn't formed immediately.

Draghi, renowned for his role in saving the euro zone from collapse in 2012, accepted the mandate.  Expressing confidence in securing parliamentary backing, he acknowledged the challenges ahead: “This is a difficult time. Beating the pandemic, completing the vaccination campaign, offering answers to the everyday problems of the people and relaunching the country are the challenges we face.”  He emphasized the opportunity presented by the EU funds: “We have extraordinary European Union resources at our disposal, we have the opportunity to do so much for our country.”

Investors reacted positively to Draghi's appointment, with Italian borrowing costs poised for their largest single-day drop since June and the Milan bourse blue chip index rising 2.5%.  However, securing the necessary political support is far from guaranteed. The 5-Star Movement, the largest party in parliament, immediately declared its opposition, potentially complicating Draghi's efforts to form a stable government.

Draghi, nicknamed “Super Mario” for his decisive actions at the ECB, where he famously pledged to do “whatever it takes” to save the euro, had largely been out of the public eye since leaving the ECB in October 2019.  His return to the political stage comes as Italy faces a confluence of crises.  As the first European country hit by the coronavirus, Italy has suffered over 89,000 deaths, the sixth-highest toll globally.  Lockdowns implemented to control the virus have ravaged the economy, resulting in an 8.8% GDP contraction in 2020, the steepest decline since World War Two.

# All Blacks' Post-Match Analysis: Lessons from Bledisloe I

## Game Review and Tactical Missteps

Despite securing a 33-25 victory in Bledisloe I, the All Blacks faced a rigorous review on Monday where players were held accountable for their performance. Aaron Smith revealed the team's tactical shortcomings during their analysis.

"We had a plan around how we wanted to exit and get our forwards in the game early," Smith told The Breakdown on Sky. "But there was just so many opportunities. We fell into that trap of, 'we could go on here, it's hot here, we could do this'."

Smith emphasized what should have been their approach: "We should have really got our forwards into the game, getting our loose forwards carrying early, cleaning rucks fast. And as you saw the first plays after halftime were direct, at them, we're coming. That sets our game up. Our game drivers won't do that again."

## Leadership and Responsibility

While Smith disclosed his role in the defensive group during games, he noted that offensive messaging responsibility lies with the No 10s. This insight highlighted the need for improvement from the No 10-No 12-No 15 axis of Richie Mo'unga, David Havili, and Damian McKenzie. Looking ahead to Saturday's match, expectations are high for either Mo'unga or Beauden Barrett to deliver a more measured first-half performance, likely incorporating more tactical kicking to pressure the Wallabies.

## Performance Analysis

Despite the criticism, Smith found positives in their performance, noting that the Wallabies only gained momentum through All Blacks' errors:

"Our intensity was there, because we were so eager and ready for a physical battle, but maybe early on skills, our ability to see space, and maybe respecting the ball a bit, and respecting the Australians with their defence as well was missing in that first half."

He added, "The only reason we were under pressure was because we let them off the hook. We were putting them under so much pressure at set-piece time, but we were unable to capitalise."

## Advice for Young Players

Smith offered valuable guidance for younger squad members regarding media attention and performance reviews. With modern players facing intense scrutiny, particularly through social media, Smith emphasized the importance of maintaining perspective:

"It comes with time, and the old factor of, 'do you read all your press, or do you read none?' If you do one or the other you've got to have a plan around it. If you read a lot of the articles, you've got to read the bad ones too. Take it for what it is."

I had planned to take the rest of the evening off, but the people have spoken, and I feel obliged to respond. In our Command Line series, my most recent post outlined the steps to install the latest version of Mozilla's Firefox browser to replace the default Extended Support Release in Debian 9. A reader named "poorplayer" commented, asking if there was a way to install the newest version of LibreOffice. To clarify, the default build of LibreOffice in the Debian Stretch repository is version 5, while the latest version available is actually 6.4.

Fortunately, where there's a will, there's a way, and we have found it. Installing LibreOffice is a bit more involved than simply downloading and clicking a .deb file. However, with a few simple terminal commands, you can have a fresh and up-to-date version of LibreOffice on your Chromebook in no time. First, you should remove any previous installations of LibreOffice. If you installed it via the terminal, use the following command to remove it:

```
sudo apt remove libreoffice
```

Next, visit the LibreOffice website and download the latest Linux version, which is currently 6.4.1.

Thomas Wayne Capenhurst, a Dixon man, pleaded guilty in a Sacramento federal court on Monday to the conspiracy to bomb his brother's home in Suisun City in 2018. According to U.S. Attorney McGregor W. Scott, Capenhurst pleaded guilty to both the conspiracy charge and malicious use of explosive materials.

Court documents revealed that Capenhurst had offered $10,000 each to co-defendant Robert McGraw and another man to place pipe bombs at his brother's Blue Jay Drive residence. On February 17, 2018, McGraw placed a pipe bomb on the front porch of the home and ignited the fuse before fleeing, resulting in an explosion that caused damage to the property.

Fortunately, despite the family of five being present in the house at the time of the incident, no injuries were reported. The investigation into this case was conducted by various law enforcement agencies, including the Suisun City Police Department, U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, and the FBI's Solano County Violent Crimes Task Force, among others.

Robert McGraw is set for a status conference on October 5, while Thomas Wayne Capenhurst is scheduled for sentencing on January 4 by U.S. District Judge Kimberley J. Mueller. Capenhurst could face a prison sentence of five to 20 years and a $250,000 fine for malicious use of explosive materials, as well as a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine for conspiracy. Assistant U.S. Attorney Ross Pearson is leading the prosecution in this case.

Manchester City’s 2-1 loss to Lyon on Wednesday, their fourth consecutive Champions League defeat, lays bare the challenge facing the Premier League champions.  Despite racking up 100 points domestically last season and being tipped as favorites for the European title, City struggled in front of a partially empty Etihad Stadium.  The 15,000 empty seats highlight the nagging question of when the Champions League will capture the imagination of the club's fans and players alike.  While other contenders like Liverpool, Real Madrid, and Juventus thrive on fervent home support in European competition, City have yet to cultivate a similar atmosphere. This lack of home advantage is a stark contrast to their domestic dominance. Pep Guardiola's absence due to suspension was cited as a contributing factor to the loss, but the reality remains that City are the first English club to lose four straight Champions League matches, three of which were at home. This disappointing streak underscores the significant hurdle they face in translating their Premier League success to the European stage.

On Friday, the Chilean peso experienced gains following the approval by senators of a referendum to change the country's constitution, which dates back to the dictatorship era, set for next year. Meanwhile, other Latin American currencies remained largely stable as traders prepared for the holiday season.

The peso rose by up to 1% after Congress approved the plan to let voters decide if a new constitution is necessary—a central demand of the protests that have brought the country to a standstill since October, significantly impacting the currency.

The gains on Friday added to an improving global outlook this week, positioning the peso for its largest-ever monthly increase. A basket of Latin American currencies also seemed poised to end the year on a strong note, buoyed by the United States securing back-to-back trade deals with key partners China, Mexico, and Canada.

However, analysts noted there was little motivation for assets in the developing world to maintain their recent momentum, given the lack of a formally signed U.S.-China trade deal and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's firm stance on Brexit negotiations. "The emerging market rally is losing some momentum," said Win Thin, head of emerging market currency strategy at Brown Brothers Harriman. "It's very quiet at our trading desk, especially with the year-end and some uncertainty ahead."

The Brazilian real remained nearly flat, despite a better-than-expected rise in the IPCA-15 consumer price index, which is seen as the official inflation forecast for Latin America’s largest economy. Mexico’s peso saw a slight increase for the second consecutive day. On Thursday, the central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate for the fourth straight time, as anticipated.

In equities trading, Brazilian shares dipped from record highs, with the largest domestic airline, Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA, declining about 1.2%.

IBM experienced a noteworthy milestone as its quarterly revenue increased for the first time in almost six years, primarily fueled by growth in key areas such as cloud and security services. Specifically, in the fourth quarter ending on Dec. 31, the company's revenue surged by 3.6 percent to reach US$22.54 billion, marking a significant uptick after 23 consecutive quarters of stagnation.

Despite this revenue growth, IBM reported a net loss of $1.05 billion, translating to a loss of $1.14 per share, compared to a profit of $4.50 billion or $4.72 per share. This decline in profitability can be attributed to a $5.5 billion charge linked to the recent U.S. tax reform.

(Reporting by Pushkala Aripaka in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

# Adobe's Digital Experience Platform Sees Pandemic-Driven Growth and Innovation

## Pandemic Drives Digital Transformation
When the pandemic hit last year, Adobe saw it as a significant opportunity to help customers digitize and adapt to stay afloat. Adobe's Experience Platform, which helps companies manage everything from website setup to ecommerce and customer outreach, became increasingly crucial for both Adobe's business and its clients.

## Strong Financial Performance
This digital transformation push led to remarkable growth in Adobe's digital experience business. In Q1 2021, subscription revenue for the unit grew 27% year-over-year, reaching $812 million. Adobe's stock price has surged approximately 50% over the past year, resulting in a market cap of $242 billion.

## Expanding Customer Base
Adobe recently revealed several new additions to its customer roster, including:
- ServiceNow
- BJ's Wholesale Club
- Panera Bread
- EY
- TSB Bank

The company also disclosed long-term partnerships with industry giants like Coca-Cola, Home Depot, and Hilton.

## Focus on AI-Driven Personalization
According to Anil Chakaravarthy, executive VP of Adobe's digital experience business, the company's current focus is helping businesses leverage AI for marketing personalization. "Since everybody's going digital, as a consumer we are bombarded by digital emails, texts, mobile, et cetera," he explained. "For something to really cut through and appeal to a consumer, it has to be personalized with the full context of the customer."

## Key Strategic Initiatives
Adobe is pursuing several key initiatives:
1. Refining customer data collection while ensuring privacy compliance
2. Enhancing B2B customer experience understanding
3. Developing AI capabilities to identify key decision-makers in potential client organizations
4. Streamlining marketing workflows through the Workfront acquisition

## Looking Ahead
As businesses recognize that pandemic-driven digital changes are permanent, Adobe continues to evolve its Experience Platform. "We are at the beginning of this next phase of the journey of the Experience Cloud," noted Chakaravarthy, highlighting the company's commitment to innovation in the digital experience space.

The dominant religion story of 2017, evangelical support for then-candidate Donald Trump, continued into 2018, shifting focus to the Trump administration's reciprocal support for evangelicals.  This continued prominence was reflected in the annual poll of the Religion News Association (RNA), reported by the Religion News Service (RNS).

"Evangelicals are strongly represented in President Trump's cabinet and religious advisory board, shaping administration priorities ranging from Jerusalem to Supreme Court appointments to interpretations of religious liberty," stated RNS President Manya Brachear Pashman.

Stephen Strang, author of *God and Donald Trump*, noted that a large majority of evangelicals remain aligned with the president, attributing this loyalty to fulfilled campaign promises. These include strengthening religious liberty protections, appointing a conservative Supreme Court justice, supporting pastors and churches, and prioritizing the American family.

Pashman added, "These so-called 'Trumpvangelicals' enjoy unprecedented access to the Oval Office, facilitated by Vice President Mike Pence, a conservative Christian, and an informal advisory panel composed almost entirely of conservative evangelical Christian leaders."

The RNA's top 10 religion stories of 2018 also included:

* **Charlottesville white supremacist march:** Neo-Nazis brandishing anti-Semitic slogans were met with resistance from various religious groups.
* **The travel ban:**  While the Trump administration framed the travel ban as a national security measure, critics deemed it anti-Muslim.
* **Jerusalem:** Trump's official recognition of Jerusalem as Israel's capital drew praise from many Jewish leaders and Israel supporters, but faced international condemnation, with 128 nations in the UN General Assembly declaring the decision "null and void."
* **Rohingya atrocities:**  Myanmar's Buddhist majority persecuted its Rohingya Muslim minority, forcing over 500,000 to flee the country.
* **Sutherland Springs church shooting:** The deadliest mass shooting in Texas history claimed the lives of 26 parishioners.
* **Judge Roy Moore's Senate run.**
* **Conservative judicial nominees:**  Including the appointment of Neil Gorsuch.
* **NFL national anthem protests:**  Player protests during the national anthem sparked backlash from fans and viewers.
* **500th anniversary of the Protestant Reformation.**

While not in the top 10, the *Masterpiece Cakeshop* Supreme Court case, addressing religious liberty, ranked 11th.

Trump himself was named Religion Newsmaker of the Year, surpassing Pope Francis, Martin Luther, and Judge Roy Moore.

Strang, a charismatic evangelical, acknowledged that many evangelicals initially opposed Trump's candidacy. However, he argued that a vast majority ultimately supported him on Election Day.  "What was the alternative?" Strang asked, criticizing Hillary Clinton's support for Planned Parenthood, late-term abortions, and same-sex marriage, and highlighting her perceived lack of outreach to evangelical Christians.

The RNA, compiler of the top 10 list, is the largest organization of religion journalists in the United States.

PORTLAND, Ore. — Growing tensions in the Middle East have sparked fear and frustration here at home. Dozens of people gathered downtown on Friday evening to protest the U.S. drone strike that killed one of Iran’s top military leaders, General Qasem Soleimani. The rally was organized by the Democratic Socialists of America of Portland.

Despite Terry Schrunk Plaza in downtown Portland being 2,350 miles from the White House, distance was irrelevant to those who assembled there on Friday night. “We’ll do anything to stop the Trump administration from escalating this into a full-blown war,” said protester Mark McLeod. “I knew from the moment I heard about this last night that this is a terrible, terrible thing.”

President Trump hailed the operation as a victory. The U.S. officially classified Soleimani as a terrorist, accusing him of orchestrating covert operations that killed hundreds of U.S. troops in Iraq after the 2003 invasion. “Soleimani was plotting imminent and sinister attacks on American diplomats and military personnel, but we caught him in the act and terminated him,” President Trump stated.

However, some fear this week's events could spark another conflict in the Middle East. Protester Justin Allen expressed his concerns, stating, “If we're not out here shouting stuff, who will?” Allen, who joined the Navy after 9/11, reflected on the Iraq war with a changed perspective. “We just kept sending more and more kids off to die, and I don’t want that to happen again because this guy in the White House needs a news cycle distraction from all the crimes he and his friends keep committing,” Allen said.

In response to similar criticisms, President Trump countered, “We took action last night to stop a war. We did not take action to start a war.”

# Manchester United Eye French Star Rabiot as Potential Pogba Replacement

According to French outlet L'Equipe, Manchester United are targeting PSG midfielder Adrien Rabiot as a potential replacement for Paul Pogba, amid strong speculation linking the latter with a summer move to Real Madrid.

## Pogba's United Journey
Paul Pogba, who rejoined United from Juventus in 2016 for a then-record transfer fee, has enjoyed a successful stint at Old Trafford, winning both the EFL Cup and UEFA Europa League under Jose Mourinho. Despite occasional criticism from his former manager, Pogba has demonstrated his world-class abilities, particularly this season, contributing 15 goals and 9 assists across all competitions.

## Real Madrid's Interest
Real Madrid, following a disappointing season, are keen to secure Pogba's services as part of Zinedine Zidane's squad overhaul. However, reports suggest Los Blancos are hoping to offer a lower salary package than the midfielder's current earnings at United.

## The Rabiot Option
United's interest in Rabiot comes at an opportune time, as the PSG midfielder will become a free agent at the season's end. The 2018-19 campaign has been challenging for Rabiot, who has made just 14 appearances for the Parisian club. With no intention of extending his contract, the French midfielder is set to depart PSG this summer.

## Competition for Signature
While L'Equipe is considered reliable for French football news, United face significant competition for Rabiot's signature. Several top clubs, including Barcelona, Manchester City, and Liverpool, are also pursuing the talented midfielder. United's absence from next season's Champions League could potentially impact their chances of securing the deal.

## What's Next
Manchester United will conclude their 2018-19 campaign this Sunday at Old Trafford against Cardiff City, after which attention will turn to their summer transfer activities.

*Source: L'Equipe (via English publication)*

# Aireon and Avinor Partner to Deploy Space-Based Surveillance for Helicopter Operations in Norwegian Airspace

*MCLEAN, Va., Feb. 23, 2021* /PRNewswire/ -- Aireon LLC and Avinor Air Navigation Services have announced an agreement to implement space-based Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast (ADS-B) technology for monitoring helicopter operations in the Bodo Oceanic Flight Information Region (FIR) and surrounding airspace. The monitored area encompasses the Norwegian Basin and Barents Sea, with surveillance focusing on helicopter movements from ground level through flight level 100. Avinor, a state-owned company under the Norwegian Ministry of Transport and Communications, manages 44 state-owned airports and facilitates travel for approximately 50 million passengers annually.

The implementation of space-based ADS-B technology will provide Avinor with real-time visibility throughout the region, significantly enhancing safety and search and rescue capabilities. This marks the first application of space-based ADS-B specifically designed for helicopter surveillance. The region's helicopter fleet is equipped with ADS-B antennas, enabling the Aireon system to track low-altitude traffic. The surveillance data will be transmitted in real-time to Avinor's facilities and integrated into their air traffic automation platform.

Don Thoma, CEO of Aireon, noted, "Since the Aireon system's deployment in 2019, we've observed exceptional visibility of helicopter movements during pre-operational testing. Avinor's innovative application of our data to enhance safety and rescue operations sets a new standard. This implementation demonstrates that space-based ADS-B is the premier solution for low-altitude monitoring."

Anders Kirsebom, CEO of Avinor Air Navigation Services, added, "Space-based ADS-B technology will be crucial to our Arctic High North surveillance capabilities. We look forward to collaborating with Aireon and anticipate this becoming an essential tool for our air traffic controllers at the Polaris Area Control Centre in Bodø, Norway."

Future plans include potentially expanding the vertical surveillance limit to monitor commercial aircraft at higher altitudes.

## About Aireon LLC
Aireon operates the world's first space-based air traffic surveillance system for ADS-B equipped aircraft. By extending formerly ground-based technologies globally, Aireon enhances aviation efficiency, safety, and environmental sustainability while providing cost benefits to stakeholders. The company's high-fidelity, low-latency surveillance data supports various applications, enabling enhanced asset tracking and situational awareness. Aireon partners with leading ANSPs worldwide, including NAV CANADA, Enav, NATS, the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA), and Naviair, alongside Iridium Communications. For more information, visit www.aireon.com.

## About Avinor Air Navigation Services
Avinor Air Navigation Services leads Norway's air navigation services and pioneers digital Remote Towers systems and UTM. With extensive ATM experience spanning Arctic conditions to international hub operations, the company has successfully implemented sustainable initiatives in air traffic operations. Avinor ANS was among Europe's first ANSPs to implement Free Route Airspace and leads in curved approaches and direct climb and descent procedures. The organization serves approximately 50 airports and provides en-route services through three control centers.

During a Senate committee hearing, Senator Wong raised concerns about whether the Prime Minister had requested the inclusion of Pastor Brian Houston at a White House state dinner. "I think the public has a right to know whether our Prime Minister asked for Mr Brian Houston to go to the White House," she stated, emphasizing the need for transparency. "And if he did so, he should be, frankly, man enough and brave enough to answer the question."

The state dinner, held on September 20, was attended by prominent Australians like Gina Rinehart and Andrew Forrest. However, Brian Houston was not present, and the government has neither confirmed nor denied if his invitation was suggested by the Prime Minister or his staff. At the Senate estimates hearing, Senator Wong inquired if Australia provided a list of potential attendees, but officials avoided direct responses.

An official from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet explained, "Senator, I think any matters relating to the compilation or consideration of the guest list for a state dinner provided by the US would be a matter that might impact on international relations." Senator Wong expressed her disbelief, "You've got to be kidding," while Finance Minister Mathias Cormann interjected, stating that the dinner arrangements were the responsibility of the US.

Bentson wants to facilitate civil discussions on politics and bridge the divide between people with differing viewpoints. He created Neighbor to Neighbor (N2N) as a grassroots effort to bring together individuals who self-identify as conservatives, liberals, Democrats, Republicans, or independents. The goal of N2N is not to persuade or convert but to foster mutual understanding and respectful dialogue among neighbors.

To kick off his N2N initiative, Bentson set up in Pioneer Park with a sign inviting passersby to talk politics. While the response has been slow, he remains committed to the idea of encouraging meaningful conversations and reducing political polarization in society. By getting people with diverse perspectives in the same room, Bentson hopes to create a space for open dialogue where differences can be explored and common ground can be found.

Bentson's motivation stems from the current toxic political climate where disagreements often lead to division and animosity. He believes that avoiding political conversations only perpetuates the problem and that engaging in respectful dialogue, even with those we disagree with, is crucial for finding solutions to shared challenges. By promoting Neighbor to Neighbor as a platform for civil discourse, Bentson aims to counter the prevailing trend of demonizing those with opposing views.

Despite the initial challenges of attracting participants, Bentson remains optimistic about the potential for N2N to spark meaningful discussions and reconnect individuals on a human level. His vision is for N2N groups to provide a safe and inclusive environment where people can express their thoughts and feelings while actively seeking to understand those of others. Through this process of dialogue and empathy, Bentson believes that communities can move towards greater unity and cooperation in addressing common problems.

If you are interested in joining the Neighbor to Neighbor groups or supporting this initiative, Bentson encourages you to reach out to him via email at sbentson@gmail.com. “We have a planned protest tomorrow at a statewide law enforcement conference in Sacramento,” Jones stated. “I know people have this overwhelming urge to do what they can. ... One of the things you can do is go down there. Go down to the convention center tomorrow between 11 and 1 and show your support for law enforcement.”

What did Jones expect? Emotions were already running high over the shooting death of Deputy Mark Stasyuk, a 27-year-old killed on Monday during a routine call in Rancho Cordova.

Choosing such a solemn moment to make a political statement under the guise of a call to action was ill-timed. And people responded. Groups, mainly older individuals, some carrying American flags and a couple wearing red "Make America Great Again" hats similar to those worn by President Donald Trump, gathered to support law enforcement and confront BLM.

The BLM group included clergy, a mix of white and African American individuals, and a diverse array of supporters. The pro-law enforcement side was primarily composed of older white individuals, along with some younger participants. I didn’t stay for the entire event, but I witnessed the tensest moments firsthand.

This clash of ideologies was on the verge of exploding.

As Leong worked to maintain peace, Jones' office issued a clarification on his earlier comments: “Sheriff Jones never called for a counterprotest—which would encourage responding persons to protest or address the planned protest directly—but rather gave the community an outlet for their grief and support where over a hundred Sheriff’s Department personnel and law enforcement from around the state will be gathered to learn better ways to police their communities.”

Really?

Re-read what Jones said on Monday and determine his true intent. It seemed like he was trying to correct one misstep by making another.

AUSTIN, Texas (AP) — The winning numbers for Tuesday evening's Texas Lottery "All or Nothing Night" drawing are: 01-02-05-07-12-13-15-16-19-22-23-24 (one, two, five, seven, twelve, thirteen, fifteen, sixteen, nineteen, twenty-two, twenty-three, twenty-four).

Claudio Ranieri has strongly criticized Aboubakar Kamara for displaying disrespect towards his Fulham teammates, supporters, and the club by disregarding instructions and taking a crucial penalty, which he missed, potentially jeopardizing their victory against Huddersfield.

Fulham ultimately secured three vital points with a 1-0 win, thanks to Aleksandar Mitrovic’s stoppage-time goal. Earlier in the match, Kamara ignored Mitrovic, the club’s designated penalty taker, opting to take the penalty himself, which was subsequently saved by Huddersfield's Jonas Lossl at 0-0.

Kamara had previously scored from the penalty spot in a 4-1 defeat against Manchester United earlier this month. However, the normally composed 67-year-old Ranieri was visibly upset that Kamara “thought only of himself” and suggested he might consider dropping him from the team for his actions, which Ranieri claimed he had never encountered before.

Ranieri expressed his frustration, stating, “It is not possible to explain what happened after we got the penalty, or maybe I should say it is easy when a man thinks only of himself. It is not right. He didn’t respect me, the club, his teammates, the crowd. He took the ball and just said, ‘I want to shoot.’ He didn’t listen to reason.”

Ranieri continued, “I have spoken a little to him. I think he didn’t understand what I said. Mitrovic was the designated taker, but Kamara scored our last penalty and took it on himself, ‘I am the man.’ He did not apologize, he just told me ‘I wanted to shoot.’ I said to him, ‘If the whole team just said I want to shoot, what would happen?’ It is impossible to speak to this man.”

Ranieri further lamented, “He did not understand the reason; for him, everything is fine, we won the match. It is unbelievable; the first time in my life I have seen that. I understand why the fans might boo him, but of course, it is better if the fans and us are altogether. You must respect the nominated taker.”

Considering Kamara’s future in the team, Ranieri said, “I hope he can understand; it is clearly difficult. I don’t know if that is it, if it is finished or if it will continue. Maybe I will take him away from the squad. But I will do what is best for the squad. If it is good for them, he plays. If I think it isn’t, he comes out. We’ll play the Arsenal match on Tuesday, then I decide. The other players are calm because we won – but not me. It is not important whether we won or lost, it is important what you did and why.”

Mitrovic’s last-minute goal left Huddersfield at the bottom of the Premier League, having lost all seven of their league fixtures this month. Their manager, David Wagner, reflected on their current situation, saying, “Obviously it’s a low point. Not only because we’ve lost seven in a row but how we lost it. It’s a heavy loss we’ve conceded at Fulham. We will need for sure a little bit longer than only 30 minutes afterwards to deal with it. December wasn’t our month, obviously. But for me, it’s not possible to think so quickly after the game about the transfer window or the next game. I have to reflect. It’s very difficult.”

Press Association

A damning Corruption and Crime Commission report, which was tabled in WA Parliament on Tuesday, found smuggling drugs into jail was as easy as stuffing them down the front of a prison officer's pants. The report found corrupt officers swapped "large amounts" of cash for anabolic steroids, methylamphetamine, and synthetic cannabis. It alleged two former prison officers at the center of the investigation "possessed and supplied steroids and methylamphetamine to prisoners." 

A covert investigation into the security of the state's corrections system has unveiled a "disturbing network" of corrupt prison guards, prisoners, and "organized crime syndicates" smuggling drugs into WA prisons. Lax security in WA's prison system has been the subject of an ongoing Corruption and Crime Commission investigation. There were "multiple instances" of custodial officers associating with criminals and members of crime gangs, using prohibited drugs, smuggling prohibited drugs into prison, and taking bribes in the form of cash and drugs, according to investigators.

The report labeled the state's prison system a "corruption risk hot-spot."

Kochi: On Saturday, two additional trains departed from Ernakulam district, transporting migrant laborers from Kerala. A total of 1,111 migrant workers traveled to Khurda Road railway station in Odisha from Aluva railway station in Ernakulam, while 1,140 were taken to Danapur railway station in Bihar from Ernakulam North railway station.

Each of these trains included 24 sleeper class coaches. To adhere to social distancing norms, each coach, which typically accommodates 72 passengers, was limited to carrying only 45 individuals, explained Kerala Minister VS Sunil Kumar.

The Kerala State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) provided buses to transport the laborers to the railway stations. Additionally, police vans were used to carry them from their camps to the railway stations.

# The Inspiring Story of Uche Ikoro: Ability in Disability

## Introduction
Uche Ikoro, a 23-year-old father of two from Abiriba in Abia state, works as a commercial cab driver with Eastern Mass Transit. Despite being born with no legs and partially deformed arms, he operates routes between Enugu, Ebonyi, Anambra, and beyond. His story exemplifies triumph over physical challenges and society's expectations.

## Professional Journey
Our correspondent, who encountered Ikoro at the Eastern Mass Transit Terminal in Holy Ghost Enugu on December 27, 2020, witnessed his remarkable ability to manipulate the vehicle's controls. His exceptional driving skills, demonstrated over six years in the profession, have earned him recognition as one of the most respected commercial drivers in the southeast region.

Before becoming a driver, Ikoro worked as a building engineer and solar light installer. He began his driving career in 2015, initially operating on the Lagos route before focusing on the southeast region for better returns. The transition to commercial driving was made possible through the generosity of Very Reverend Father Professor Johnbosco Akam, who provided him with his first cab.

## Personal Philosophy
"In this life, if you believe in God, God will believe in you," Ikoro states. He firmly believes that his physical condition should not condemn him to a life of begging or poverty. Speaking impeccable English and holding a Senior School Certificate with excellent grades, Ikoro chose not to pursue further education to focus on supporting his family.

## Views on Begging and Disability
Ikoro strongly opposes begging as a means of survival for persons with disabilities. He emphasizes that "begging can not empower anyone because more efforts were required to break even." He considers it dehumanizing and believes it reduces individuals to social misfits.

HENRY COUNTY, Tenn. — People from all over West Tennessee and various parts of the country gathered at Paris Landing State Park to witness the solar eclipse in near-totality. The park hosted a public viewing event, featuring bounce houses, an EVAC helicopter appearance, and live animal displays, all free of charge.

Park rangers noted meeting visitors who traveled from as far as Indiana, New York, and Michigan to seize this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Among the attendees was A.J. Grott, who had eagerly anticipated the eclipse for over a year and journeyed with his family from Memphis. "If you have a chance for 2024 or you had a chance here, if you didn’t take it, you should’ve," said Grott, an eclipse enthusiast. "If you have a chance next time, take it, 'cause it’s indescribably awesome."

The climax of the event occurred around 1:21 p.m., when Paris Landing experienced 99 percent totality of the eclipse. For those who missed this spectacle, the next total eclipse will occur on April 8, 2024, or August 21, 2045.

Rodney Rice entered his home state of West Virginia on a Sunday afternoon. The singer-songwriter from Littleton had just left Nashville after spending four days in a recording studio, marking his first proper visit to the country music hub. He was en route to visit family and install a kayak rack on his vehicle.

Despite the unconventional timing for travel, Rodney had been isolated for months and was eager to record new songs. Despite the challenges of the year, he remained productive. 

"I’m adhering to safety measures, wearing a mask, and carrying hand sanitizer," Rice said. "Everyone in the studio was diligent about it too, we were all masked up. I’m just trying to make my way across the country as safely as possible."

Rodney was thrilled that his upcoming second album, SAME SHIrT, DIFFERENT DAY, set to release on streaming platforms on October 23, was gaining attention. The album, labeled as “Bubblin’ Up” on the Americana Music Association’s chart, features twelve tracks of gritty, twangy country-rock with an array of guest musicians. The songs touch on themes like critiquing the current presidential administration and the struggles of a corporate job.

This album follows his 2014 debut, Empty Pockets and a Troubled Mind. Rodney felt more at ease in the studio this time around and found inspiration in the tumultuous state of the world.

"I prefer the second one," he remarked. "The songs feel more current and relevant. The first album included some of the earliest songs I had ever written, spanning from high school to the recording session. It covered a broader time frame."

The opening track of SAME SHIrT, DIFFERENT DAY, titled “Ain’t Got a Dollar,” delves into the presidency of Trump and the notion that politics often revolves around money. Rodney expressed his embarrassment over having a reality TV star as the country's leader, incorporating military references influenced by his family and friends' military service.

Rodney's upbringing in West Virginia, with its blend of city life and rural surroundings where darkness descends early in the “hollers,” has shaped his musical style. He believes Appalachia shares common daily life aspects across regions like West Virginia, Tennessee, and Kentucky, emphasizing the value of diverse experiences.

After returning to West Virginia to attend the University of West Virginia for a degree in geology, Rodney spent years in the oil industry before transitioning to focus on his music full-time. His time in Texas on oil rigs influenced his music, with songs like “Middle Managed Blues” drawing from his corporate job experiences.

Moving to Colorado after meeting a woman from Boulder, Rodney immersed himself in music during his Texas days, watching performances by outlaw country legend Billy Joe Shaver, who played a significant role in Rodney's musical journey.

Rodney's early exposure to music, raiding his sister’s collection of Uncle Tupelo, Waylon Jennings, and Shaver tapes and CDs, left a lasting impression. Attending a concert by John Prine at a young age further fueled his passion for music.

SAME SHIrT, DIFFERENT DAY will be available on October 23. For more information on how to access the album, visit Rodney Rice's website.

According to a report by The Fly, analysts at BMO Capital Markets raised their target price for Copper Mountain Mining (OTCMKTS:CPPMF) from $2.10 to $2.50 in a research note issued on Friday. The brokerage has given the stock an “outperform” rating, with the new price objective suggesting a potential 31.58% upside from the current price of the company.

In addition to BMO Capital Markets' assessment, several other brokerages have also expressed their views on CPPMF. CIBC raised their price target for Copper Mountain Mining from $2.40 to $2.75, endorsing an “outperform” rating on Friday. Scotiabank increased their target price from $1.50 to $1.75 and assigned a “sector perform” rating on Tuesday, December 1st. TD Securities, on the other hand, elevated their price objective from $2.25 to $2.75 and rated the stock as a “buy” in a report released on Friday.

On Friday, shares of Copper Mountain Mining traded up $0.17 to reach $1.90, with a total of 211,163 shares exchanged compared to the average volume of 86,660. The company's fifty-day moving average stands at $1.27, while the 200-day moving average is at $0.82. Copper Mountain Mining Corporation is a Canadian mining company that primarily explores for copper, gold, and silver deposits. Its main asset is the Copper Mountain mine, which encompasses 135 crown granted mineral claims, 176 located mineral claims, 15 mining leases, and 12 fee simple properties covering an area of 6,702.1 hectares situated to the south of Princeton, British Columbia.

Prince Turki Al-Faisal, Saudi Arabia's former spy chief, addressed the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the International Peace Institute think tank on Friday.  He stated that Saudi Arabia is proud of its judicial system and will not accept an international investigation into the matter. This stance comes despite calls for an independent probe from UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, human rights groups, and some government leaders.  The calls for an investigation followed Khashoggi's death at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on October 2.  Prince Turki expressed his expectation that the kingdom will fulfill its promise to reveal all the facts surrounding the case, including the whereabouts of Khashoggi's body.  He also noted a prior friendly relationship with Khashoggi, who served as the Saudi embassy spokesman during Turki's ambassadorships to the United States and Britain.

West Coast premiership big man Nathan Vardy seems to have secured the spot as Nic Naitanui's ruck partner for round one of the AFL season. Naitanui made a successful return to the field in the pre-season match against Fremantle, recording 22 hit-outs from five possessions before coming off in the third quarter. This game was crucial for Naitanui, as it was his only match of the pre-season following a hamstring injury over the summer.

Given the return to full-length matches this year, West Coast is looking to provide more support for Naitanui in the ruck. Vardy, who didn't play in the AFL last year due to a serious leg condition, appears to be the likely choice to support Naitanui. With Bailey Williams nursing an ankle injury, Vardy's strong performance in the pre-season games puts him in a good position for a round-one call-up against Gold Coast.

In terms of Oscar Allen, his role in the team for the upcoming season remains uncertain. Allen was the primary ruck support for Naitanui last year, but the Eagles are considering using a recognized ruckman like Vardy or Williams in that role in 2021. Coach Adam Simpson mentioned that Allen has been versatile during the pre-season, alternating between roles in attack and defense. With the potential return of Josh Kennedy for round one, Allen may see more playing time in defense.

The Eagles are dealing with several injury concerns as they approach the start of the season. Star midfielder Tim Kelly missed both pre-season games due to a thumb injury but is expected to be fit for round one. Captain Luke Shuey sustained an ankle injury in the match against Fremantle but is likely to be available for the season opener. On the other hand, recruit Zac Langdon suffered a serious concussion and is unlikely to be selected for round one.

Furthermore, onballer Elliot Yeo will be sidelined at the beginning of the season due to ongoing issues with osteitis pubis. Although there are options to consider, such as defender Harry Edwards, the Eagles are leaning towards a more traditional ruck setup for round one. With uncertainties surrounding the roles of players like Allen and Vardy, West Coast will continue to assess their options leading up to the start of the AFL season.

The Arizona Cardinals recently reduced their roster to 52 players, leaving an open spot due to two players on the COVID list and one player returning imminently. The team will likely make further adjustments through waiver claims and free agents, but we now have a clear view of the initial 53-man roster.

Here is a breakdown of the positions and players on the roster:

Quarterbacks:
The top two quarterback spots were secure, with the decision revolving around whether Streveler would make the final 53. In today's NFL climate, having three capable quarterbacks is vital, especially given ongoing COVID concerns. The team values Streveler and may opt to keep him on the roster to avoid exposing him to waivers.

Running back:
The running back group consists of Chase Edmonds, James Conner, Eno Benjamin, and Jonathan Ward. The challenge ahead will be determining the depth chart and game-day activations among these four players.

Wide receivers:
DeAndre Hopkins, A.J. Green, Christian Kirk, Rondale Moore, Andy Isabella, and Antoine Wesley comprise the wide receiver corps. While the Cardinals were expected to carry six receivers, some surprises emerged in the final selection, notably Wesley making the cut over others like Greg Dortch.

Tight end:
Dan Arnold, Maxx Williams, and Darrell Daniels form the tight end group, with Ross Travis a potential practice squad candidate.

Offensive line:
The offensive line includes D.J. Humphries, Justin Murray, Rodney Hudson, Brian Winters, Kelvin Beachum, Josh Jones, Max Garcia, and Josh Miles. Once Justin Pugh returns from the COVID reserve, the line will be complete with nine linemen.

Defensive line:
J.J. Watt, Rashard Lawrence, Jordan Phillips, Zach Allen, Leki Fotu, Corey Peters, and Michael Dogbe make up the defensive line group. Dogbe's presence on the roster was unexpected due to the numbers game, with the possibility of a seventh lineman being carried.

Outside linebacker:
Chandler Jones, Markus Golden, Devon Kennard, Dennis Gardeck, and Victor Dimukeje are the outside linebackers. Gardeck's return from the PUP list required him to be on the roster, while Dimukeje's inclusion was not surprising given his preseason performance.

Inside linebacker:
Zaven Collins, Isaiah Simmons, Jordan Hicks, Tanner Vallejo, and Zeke Turner complete the inside linebacker group. Turner's special teams prowess adds depth to the position.

Cornerback:
Byron Murphy, Marco Wilson, Tay Gowan, and Luq Barcoo currently fill the cornerback spots, with Robert Alford set to return from the COVID list. Malcolm Butler's sudden retirement has left a gap to be addressed in the secondary.

Safety:
Budda Baker, Jalen Thompson, Deionte Thompson, and Charles Washington make up the safety group. The decision to cut three safeties, including established players like Chris Banjo and Shawn Williams, was unexpected but highlights the depth in this position.

Specialists:
The specialists—Matt Prater, Andy Lee, and Aaron Brewer—remain unchanged, with potential practice squad additions like punter Ryan Winslow for backup purposes.

The Cardinals' roster decisions reflect a mix of expected choices and surprising outcomes, setting the stage for further adjustments as the season progresses.

Tanzanian President John Magufuli has confidently declared that his country has successfully eradicated coronavirus, attributing this achievement to the power of prayer, the efforts of local health officials, and frontline healthcare workers. He emphasized the importance of continued vigilance and precautionary measures despite the positive outlook.

Magufuli's remarks were made during a speech delivered at a church in Dodoma, the capital city of Tanzania, where he commended churchgoers for not wearing masks as a symbol of the country's victory over the virus and the diminishing fear among the population.

While the President claimed that there were only four Covid-19 patients left in hospitals in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania has not reported any new data on coronavirus cases since April 29. The last available figures from the World Health Organization indicated 509 reported cases and 21 deaths in the country.

Concerns have been raised by regional WHO officials regarding Tanzania's approach to social distancing and the decision to keep places of worship open despite the risks associated with large gatherings. The US Embassy in Tanzania issued a health alert in May, warning of the high risk of contracting Covid-19 due to overwhelmed hospitals in Dar es Salaam.

President Magufuli initially downplayed the seriousness of the virus in Tanzania, urging citizens to rely on prayer to combat the disease and dismissing the reported increase in positive cases as a result of faulty test kits. Despite this, the country has started to ease coronavirus restrictions, with universities, high schools, and international travel resuming while primary and secondary schools remain closed.
