Fissures in the Trinamool Congress (TMC) widened on Friday, months ahead of the state assembly elections, as the party suffered a spree of resignations.

Can you imagine taking care of two children, one with special needs, working at a doctor’s office all day, and then having the stamina to attend a Beaufort County School Board meeting for four long hours? That is exactly what Kerri Lewis did a few weeks ago. I grow faint at the mere thought of it.

Ms. Lewis sat through the meeting, listening to the board's bickering and, according to her, watching most of the members act like spoiled children. This remarkable woman had no intention of speaking at the meeting but became so disturbed by the proceedings that she declared it “horrible.”

When given the opportunity to speak, she had quite a lot to say, and she did. Her main purpose for attending these meetings, she said, was to see what everyone looked like and to hear what they said in person. “I want them to know these purple glasses are listening every single time,” she later told an Island Packet reporter.

You might have seen Ms. Lewis making her remarks on the Beaufort County Channel or on Facebook, as I did. I admire her energy and passion for trying to make Beaufort County Schools a more productive place for her children and the many others who have no voice in board decisions. I bet she is an outstanding employee at Beaufort Memorial Hospital, where she has quickly become a celebrity.

You can attend an upcoming school board meeting if you wish, at 6 p.m. on Tuesday, May 16, at the Bluffton Public Library.

Thanks for representing us

I must say I admire U.S. Rep. Mark Sanford. Whether you like him or not, he is a staunch supporter of Beaufort County. He makes himself available as much as possible to all of us in his district and does not shy away from his critics.

I also applaud state Sen. Tom Davis and state Reps. Bill Herbkersman and Weston Newton, who all care about our part of South Carolina and are willing to step up and help if needed.

If you care to attend the next meeting of the Greater Bluffton Republican Club, it will be held at 5:30 p.m. on May 1, in the Roasting Room above the Corner Perk on May River Road. There, you will have a chance to chat with Newton and Herbkersman. The two will provide an update on the state legislative session and address any questions you may have. This is a free event, and the public is invited.

Reading the sky

The MCAS Beaufort Air Show, scheduled for April 29-30, will host the GEICO Skytypers, six SNJ-2 planes that fly low to the ground while writing messages in the sky. These messages can be seen from miles away, so if you have a boat, it would be fun to motor over and watch from the water. The air show will also include the Blue Angels flight team, and they are fabulous. We have taken the children to see all of the planes and watch them perform several times. This exciting event is free and open to the public. For more information, visit www.beaufortairshow.com.

Why I miss Paris

While my sister and her husband were in Paris recently, they nibbled on one of my favorite treats—a croque monsieur—and I was very jealous. Translated from French, croque monsieur means “mister crunch.” The sandwich is made with ham and Gruyere cheese, butter, and it is toasted, sometimes served with a béchamel sauce. There is also a version called croque madame, which is topped with a poached or fried egg. Either of these delights is wonderful, especially if you are sitting outside a café in Paris, watching the world go by.

Meredith Amick is shown filling one of the gallon jugs of hand sanitizer that will be delivered to the front lines in the battle against the coronavirus. (Staff photo by Tony Baughman)

Located in the Leesville area of Lake Murray, Hollow Creek Distillery is a charming retreat where visitors can wander off the beaten path, enjoy warm Southern hospitality, and escape the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

Nestled in the trees, you'll find a quaint little red barn with white rocking chairs on the front porch. From there, you can sit back, relax, and gaze out at the wide expanse of the lake across Highway 378. Typically, on a springtime Saturday, guests could wander inside, learn about the art of moonshine-making, and savor some of Craig and Meredith Amick's handcrafted spirits.

However, this spring is far from ordinary at Hollow Creek. Instead of welcoming guests and offering a taste of their fine Southern moonshine, Hollow Creek Distillery has pivoted to a life-saving mission.

Recently, the Amicks received a call from the State of South Carolina, asking if they would be willing to use their moonshine still to produce hand sanitizer. Without hesitation, they agreed to assist their fellow South Carolinians on the front lines of the battle against the coronavirus.

"At first, we thought it was a joke, but it turned out to be very real," Meredith Amick remarked, standing next to Hollow Creek's substantial still. "So, we had to make some adjustments here."

For two weeks straight, the Amicks worked tirelessly, putting in 14-hour days operating the moonshine still to meet the State's urgent request. Last week, they delivered 1,375 gallon jugs of their clear, potent germ-killing solution to the state's Department of Transportation, which is overseeing the distribution to those in critical need.

"It was a privilege to be called upon by the State government to contribute to this cause," Mrs. Amick stated. "This is our home, and we are grateful to be able to support the community and state that have played a significant role in our lives and education.

**PAINTSVILLE, Ky. (AP) — Update on the Fatal Shooting of Five People in Kentucky (all times local):**

**4:25 p.m.**

The Kentucky State Police have reported that a gunman killed his parents, his girlfriend, and his girlfriend’s mother during a weekend shooting spree in Kentucky. State Police Trooper William Petry released the names of the victims and their relationships to the shooter, Joseph Nickell, on Sunday.

Petry stated that Nickell’s parents, James and Arlene Nickell, were shot and killed on Saturday at a residence in the McKenzie Branch area of Flatgap, Kentucky. Later, Joseph Nickell’s girlfriend, Lindsey Vanhoose, and her mother, Patricia Vanhoose, were fatally shot at an apartment in nearby Paintsville. Authorities found Joseph Nickell’s body at the apartment, describing the incident as a murder-suicide.

**3:30 p.m.**

The Kentucky State Police have disclosed the names of four individuals killed in the weekend shooting spree. According to a news release by State Police Trooper William Petry, James and Arlene Nickell were shot dead on Saturday at a residence in the McKenzie Branch area of Flatgap, Kentucky. Lindsey and Patricia Vanhoose were later found fatally shot at an apartment in Paintsville.

Johnson County Sheriff Dwayne Price confirmed that the shooter, Joseph Nickell, was also found dead at the apartment, in what authorities have described as a murder-suicide involving several family members.

Louise Kenny, a professor of obstetrics and a consultant obstetrician and gynaecologist, has witnessed the adverse impact of the Eighth Amendment on pregnant women with cancer. She emphasized that the Eighth Amendment casts a shadow over the care of women with complex medical needs in Ireland. In response to a previous opinion article by Prof Eamon McGuinness, Prof Kenny refuted claims that the Eighth Amendment does not endanger pregnant women's lives.

Prof Kenny cited the case of Michelle Harte, a woman who had to travel to Britain for an abortion while terminally ill with cancer. Despite being advised to terminate her pregnancy by doctors at Cork University Hospital, the hospital's ethics committee concluded that there was no immediate risk to Ms Harte's life and advised against termination.

Prof Kenny highlighted the challenges faced by pregnant women with cancer in accessing advanced cancer treatments that are often available only through clinical trials. She stressed the importance of having clear guidelines and legal interpretations to ensure timely and appropriate care for such patients.

Ms Harte's tragic case underscored the limitations imposed by the Eighth Amendment on women's healthcare choices. Despite the State providing substantial compensation to Ms Harte, she passed away in 2011. Prof Kenny urged for an open and respectful debate on the issue to ensure that decisions are made based on facts rather than opinions.

In conclusion, the Eighth Amendment has had real-life implications for pregnant women with cancer in Ireland. Prof Kenny's advocacy for the repeal of this amendment is rooted in her firsthand experiences of the obstacles it creates for women seeking essential medical care. The need for clarity, compassion, and evidence-based decision-making in women's healthcare cannot be overstated.

Robert Lewandowski scored his second consecutive home hat-trick in the Bundesliga as 10-man Bayern Munich dominated Stuttgart 4-0, extending their lead at the top to four points. The Polish striker, who netted three times against Borussia Dortmund in his last league appearance at the Allianz Arena, needed just 39 minutes to replicate that performance here.

Serge Gnabry also found the net in a commanding first half, as Hansi Flick's side overcame the early dismissal of Alphonso Davies to secure a resounding victory. Davies was sent off after VAR upgraded his yellow card to a red for a studs-up challenge on Wataru Endo.

After weathering an early storm, Bayern took the lead through Lewandowski, who moved into second place on the Bundesliga's all-time top scorer list by converting Gnabry's low cross for his 269th goal in the competition.

- Ten men
- Four goals
- Three points
- Clean sheet
- Job well done

#FCBVfB 4-0 pic.twitter.com/fCxqUFC8a5 — FC Bayern English (@FCBayernEN) March 20, 2021

Gnabry then turned from provider to scorer, capitalizing on a slick exchange between Thomas Muller and Leroy Sane to finish a superb team goal. A minute later, Lewandowski's powerful header from Muller's right-wing cross put Bayern three goals ahead with less than a quarter of the game played. The prolific Pole completed his hat-trick just before halftime, seizing the ball inside the box and firing a left-footed shot into the bottom right corner, making it three goals from three shots.

Bayern's number nine should have added a fourth just past the hour mark but uncharacteristically misfired after being set up by Benjamin Pavard's low cross. However, that miss was inconsequential as the champions comfortably saw out their victory.

**What does it mean? History beckons for Lewandowski**

Having already scored more Bundesliga hat-tricks than any other player, Lewandowski added a 13th here, extending his lead over Mario Gomez (10) to three. The Pole now has 35 league goals this season and is likely aiming to break Gerd Muller's record of 40 goals in a single Bundesliga campaign, with eight games remaining. In fact, 'Der Bomber's' all-time scoring record of 365 goals doesn't seem out of reach for Lewandowski, who, at 32, still has several years at the top level.

**Lewa stars for Bayern**

Bayern faced challenges even before losing Davies, but the game's complexion changed entirely when Lewandowski scored his first goal in spectacular fashion. The fact that the Polish international completed his hat-trick with just three shots speaks volumes about his quality in front of goal.

**Davies errs again**

Were it not for Lewandowski's brilliance, Davies' reckless early challenge could have made for a difficult afternoon for his teammates.

An enormous Norway Spruce is headed to Rockefeller Center. This year's Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree was cut down in secret by a Newburgh landscaping company, Lynn Warren Lawn Maintenance & Landscaping, which was named as the company put in charge of the stealth operation. It took over a week of preparation, during which branches were tied down to allow the massive Norway Spruce to be safely cut and placed on a trailer for its journey to 30 Rockefeller Center.

Unlike previous years, the 2020 tree wasn’t selected from the Hudson Valley. Instead, it came from the yard of an Oneonta business owner known as “Daddy Al” Dick. New York State Police were on the scene yesterday as the tree was finally cut and prepared for transport. They posted images on Facebook showing the tree being hoisted by a giant crane onto a waiting trailer. State Police then escorted the tree south, through the Hudson Valley on its way to New York City.

This year, all parties involved in the Christmas tree-cutting were sworn to secrecy, but now that it's cut down, the cat is out of the bag. While the tree was en route to New York, crews were busy at Rockefeller Center preparing a large base and support for the famous Christmas Tree. It will be erected this weekend and decorated with over 35,000 LED lights. Although large crowds will not be invited to watch its unveiling, the tree lighting will be televised on NBC on Wednesday, Dec. 2, starting at 7 p.m.

Mayor DeBlasio announced that the tree would be lit in Rockefeller Center and the Times Square ball will drop on New Year's Eve, urging residents to stay home and enjoy the annual traditions on TV.

The tourism and sports minister, Phiphat Ratchakitprakarn, emphasized that the number of Covid-19 cases in Phuket must reach zero before the reopening to foreign tourists on July 1 under the sandbox scheme. The Phuket sandbox scheme, designed for vaccinated tourists without quarantine, requires high standards, with the government aiming for zero cases on the island by the designated date.

To achieve this goal, the government is focused on accelerating inoculations, particularly in Bangkok, to attain herd immunity by the fourth quarter. Mr. Phiphat stressed the importance of reducing daily infections to below 200 by the end of the month to restore confidence in international tourism. Once the situation is under control, discussions for travel bubbles will resume with countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Laos, and Malaysia.

Neighboring countries and the Chinese market, especially with the Golden Week Holiday in October, are being closely monitored. However, no country is willing to engage in a travel bubble discussion with Thailand while the infection rates remain high. If new cases continue to emerge in Phuket despite 70% vaccination coverage, further actions will be discussed with the Public Health Ministry.

Looking ahead, the government plans to establish a tourism fund by collecting a fee of 300 baht from foreign tourists starting in January to provide emergency support for the industry. The fund, which has been approved by the National Tourism Policy Committee, aims to help the tourism sector deal with uncertainties in the future. If Thailand can attract 20.8 million visitors in 2022, it would generate 6.2 billion baht for the fund.

In terms of the sandbox initiative, 10 areas are set to participate in the fourth quarter, with some regions already partaking in the program. The government maintains its target of 3-4 million international tourist arrivals, assuming the sandbox scheme in pilot areas progresses as planned.

In 2016, Level-5 made several mobile-related announcements, one of which was a smartphone port of the original *Yo-kai Watch* monster-collecting RPG.  Originally released for the Nintendo 3DS in Japan in 2013, *Yo-kai Watch* saw a worldwide release through Nintendo in 2015.  The sequel, *Yo-kai Watch 2*, enjoyed a surge in popularity, but sadly, that marked the franchise's peak; it has since faded from the spotlight. I thoroughly enjoyed the 3DS *Yo-kai Watch* game, but the second entry was truly exceptional.  Even the *Yo-kai Watch* anime received a global release with dubs. Despite the 2016 announcement, *Yo-kai Watch* never made it to mobile platforms at the time, though it did receive a Nintendo Switch port, which I imported from the Japanese eShop. While a solid conversion, it lacked English language support.  You can view the original 2016 smartphone trailer [here](link-placeholder).

Hugh Jackman, much like the character he portrays, is nearing the end of his tenure with the superhero realm. Once again, he's poised to don the muttonchops and CGI adamantium claws for his role in "Logan." However, Jackman insists that this will be his final performance as Wolverine, promising to retire the cigar and claws for good. We've heard similar claims before, as it seems that every Wolverine appearance is touted as his last. But this time, Jackman assures us, he truly means it—unless circumstances change.

In a conversation with ScreenRant about "Logan," Jackman suggested there might still be one adventure left for him, albeit contingent on a nearly impossible collaboration between 20th Century Fox and Marvel Studios. He expressed, "If [an Avengers movie] was on the table when I made my decision, it certainly would have made me pause. That’s for sure. Because I always love the idea of him within that dynamic, with the Hulk obviously. […] At the moment, honestly, if I really did have [the Avengers] there, I probably wouldn’t have said this is the last [movie]."

Considering the logistical challenges, it's clear that coordinating rival movie studio executives is akin to corralling a bag full of wet cats—it's chaotic and usually unproductive. However, the successful collaboration between Sony Pictures and Marvel for Spider-Man sets a precedent. If they could reach a custody arrangement, there's no reason Fox can't take similar steps. Even if Fox is hesitant to concede any control to Marvel, would they really leave potential profits on the table? With the Infinity Stones storyline, it’s conceivable that Wolverine could be pulled into the Avengers universe for a movie or two.

London was brimming with rainbows, glitter, and love at this year’s Pride parade. Over one million people flooded the streets for the annual event celebrating the LGBT community and advocating for its rights. Pride director Christopher Joell-Deshields described this year’s parade as the most diverse yet. "It’s just a day to be proud of, really. People can come and express themselves freely and celebrate whatever they wish," he added.

Approximately 30,000 individuals from 472 organizations participated in the march through the heart of the capital. Laks Mann, from Gaysians, joined the march with his friend Sasha McCarthy and her five-year-old daughter, Gabriella Morales. "We are a group that supports the Asian LGBT community," he explained. "We were established last year at Pride because I felt the need for us to come together and have a united voice."

Cheers and shouts filled the air as the parade commenced with a grand rainbow flag waving high along Regent Street.

Oakland, California cosmetic surgeon Dr. Gabriel H. Patino provides skilled hair transplantation procedures for clients in Oakland, Berkeley, and surrounding areas of California at his practice, the Cosmetic Surgical Center of El Cerrito. Millions of Americans suffer from hair loss and may not know that there are many varieties of treatment available. The most effective solutions will be provided by a surgeon like Dr. Gabriel Patino, who is an experienced hair loss surgeon.

Hair transplant surgery provides immediate, visible results. During the procedure, hair is taken from an area of abundance on the head and replaced in the areas where hair loss has occurred. Up to 95% of transplanted hairs will remain alive and continue to grow and thicken. Since transplants will not prevent future hair loss or reverse the process of hair loss, Dr. Patino commonly suggests both hair transplant surgery and a regimen of Propecia. Some clients who are averse to taking prescription medication may benefit from a topical solution instead.

The Cosmetic Surgical Center of El Cerrito can treat current hair loss and help prevent future hair loss with the application of advanced techniques and technology. Dr. Patino and his team work closely with each client to provide specific treatment options best suited for their needs. Though over-the-counter solutions are available, including topical products like Minoxidil, that boast FDA approval, the results of such products can be unclear and widely varied. The medication in retail treatments is weaker than that found in prescription treatments, and the application process is messy, inconsistent and demanding. Certain orally taken medications like Propecia and Finasteride effectively reduce dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a testosterone byproduct that causes hair loss, and results are less noticeable than those of skilled hair transplant surgery.

Dr. Patino of the Cosmetic Surgical Center of El Cerrito specializes in a wide variety of advanced surgical and non-surgical cosmetic solutions, skin rejuvenation and hair restoration, helping clients achieve healthy, youthful, natural results.

To learn more about the services provided by Dr. Gabriel H. Patino at the Cosmetic Surgical Center of El Cerrito, visit them online at http://www.thecosmeticsurgicalcenter.com.

FreeMove has been selected by the global power management company Eaton to enhance and accelerate its business operations throughout Europe with top-tier mobile managed services.

Tensions mounted on Good Morning Britain on Friday as Piers Morgan snapped at producers. This week, for the first time in a long while, the outspoken host has been consistently present on the ITV daytime show without taking a day off.

After returning from his two-week break, Piers has been co-hosting GMB with Susanna Reid from Monday through Friday, discussing topics ranging from England's second lockdown of the year to the US Election debacle and Donald Trump's explosive claims.

The lack of time off this week may have contributed to his irritation on Friday morning, as he complained about receiving instructions from the show's producers.

As the cameras resumed after an ad break, a surprised Susanna exclaimed, "What did you just say, Piers Morgan?"

Piers ranted, "There are people in my ear saying 'here's what you do.' It's almost like presenting by numbers. 'If you could do this, do this.' No! I've been here for nearly five years."

Susanna interjected, "You've not been here on a Friday, though."

"No, I haven't," Piers admitted, before adding, "And tension is mounting this week!"

One viewer did not respond kindly to Piers' outburst, tweeting, "Is this narcissistic lump of dung really bringing in the viewers? He thinks it's his own show, but in fact, he's just a yelling, ranting, and boring moron."

Baylor University Police Investigate Reported Sexual Assault

WACO, Texas – The Baylor University Police Department (BUPD) is actively investigating a reported sexual assault.  While details are still being confirmed, this timely warning is issued to inform the community and encourage protective measures.

Senator Chuck Schumer Outlines Democrats' Strategy for Barrett Hearing

On Monday, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., detailed the Democrats' approach for the Judiciary Committee's hearing on Amy Coney Barrett's Supreme Court nomination. Schumer emphasized two main focal points: the potential for Barrett to overturn the Affordable Care Act and what he described as the Republicans' hypocrisy in confirming a Supreme Court nominee so close to an election. "We will concentrate on issues like women's reproductive rights, labor rights, climate change, and, above all, health care," Schumer stated during an appearance on MSNBC's "Morning Joe." "We're going to illustrate to the American people the potential damage posed by this nominee, who has expressed admiration for Antonin Scalia, whose philosophy could set us back 100 years."

Democrats plan to share personal stories from citizens across the country to highlight how Supreme Court decisions can profoundly impact Americans' lives. When asked about the possibility of Democrats expanding the Supreme Court should they win the presidency and regain control of the Senate, Schumer remained non-committal, stating, "Everything will be on the table" if that scenario unfolds.

Barrett and Lawmakers Pay Tribute to Ruth Bader Ginsburg

In her opening statement, Amy Coney Barrett paid tribute to Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whom she is nominated to replace. "When I was 21 and just starting my career, Ruth Bader Ginsburg sat in this seat. She told the committee that what became of her could only happen in America," Barrett said. "I am nominated to fill Justice Ginsburg's seat, but no one will ever take her place. I am eternally grateful for the path she paved and the life she led."

Before Barrett's remarks, several of the 22 senators on the committee reflected on Ginsburg's historic tenure and judicial legacy. Committee Chair Lindsey Graham called Ginsburg "an active litigator, advocating for equal justice and better rights for women," noting the friendship she shared with Scalia. Senator Dianne Feinstein recalled Ginsburg's confirmation hearing as a "real thrill" for a trailblazer who "staunchly believed in a woman's right to full equality and autonomy." Senator Amy Klobuchar emphasized that Ginsburg's legacy could not be erased, saying, "To the women of America, we have come so far, and in the name of RBG, we must not go backwards."

Democrats Emphasize Health Care on First Day of Barrett Hearing

On the first day of Supreme Court hearings, Senate Democrats delivered a unified message: Health care coverage and protections for millions of Americans are at risk if Barrett is confirmed. In harmonious fashion, Democrats displayed photos of constituents battling illnesses who stand to lose essential treatments if the Affordable Care Act is repealed.

# Honest Lagos Airport Cab Driver Returns $2,400 and Passport to Passenger

A cab driver at Lagos' Murtala Muhammed International Airport (MMIA) demonstrated exceptional honesty by returning $2,400 (approximately N888,000) and an international passport forgotten by a passenger. Olayinka Adeniyi, who operates under the Airport Car Hire Association of Nigeria (ACHAN), made this discovery after completing a trip on July 29.

## The Discovery

"At about 1:30 a.m. on July 29, I met this passenger on arrival at the International airport," recalled Adeniyi, a commissioned driver with over 15 years of experience at the airport. "I negotiated with him and we agreed at N6,000 to transport him to his destination at Ikorodu."

After returning to the airport from dropping off his passenger, Adeniyi found an envelope on the back seat of his car. Upon inspection, he discovered an international passport and a second envelope containing twenty-four $100 bills. Following protocol, he reported the find to the officer on duty at the airport's arrival car park and was directed to submit the items to ACHAN's secretariat.

"I never had it in mind to take someone's belongings because it would put sorrow in another family's life," Adeniyi explained.

## The Passenger's Story

The passenger, Dele Ayeni, had just arrived from Cairo when he met Adeniyi. "While on the way, I decided to drop my jacket on the floor of the car to avoid being noticed as an important man sitting in the rear seat of the car," Ayeni explained.

The loss wasn't immediately apparent to Ayeni. "Unfortunately, I did not open my luggage to bring out what I had for my family members until after I woke up in the noon. That was when I discovered that the envelope was missing in my jacket," he said. Following his wife's advice, he returned to the airport to inquire about the missing items.

# Internet Governance Conference Shifts Focus as US Signals Change

A global conference on Internet governance in Brazil is expected to be less contentious than initially anticipated, following the United States' willingness to relax its control over key Internet functions.

The US has agreed to relinquish oversight of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) - a California-based nonprofit responsible for managing domain names - responding to demands from Brazil and other nations following revelations of widespread electronic surveillance.

"The focus has shifted from a political reaction to the NSA allegations toward more constructive criticism and dialogue about the Internet's future," notes William Beer, a São Paulo-based cybersecurity expert.

The Net Mundial conference, a two-day event in São Paulo opening Wednesday under Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff, will address several crucial topics:

- Cybersecurity
- Privacy protection
- Freedom of expression
- Future oversight of the decentralized network

Representatives from diverse nations - including China, Cuba, the United States, and European countries - will participate. However, organizers emphasize that government officials will share equal standing with:

- Internet companies
- Academic institutions
- Technical experts
- Internet user advocacy groups

"All stakeholders deserve equal participation in this multi-stakeholder process," explains Virgilio Almeida, Brazil's IT policy secretary and conference chair.

While the conference isn't expected to produce binding decisions, Almeida suggests it will initiate an important dialogue that will "sow the seeds" for future Internet governance reforms.

## Background and Context

The conference emerges from controversy surrounding NSA surveillance programs, which targeted multiple world leaders, including:

- Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff
- German Chancellor Angela Merkel

These revelations, disclosed by former NSA analyst Edward Snowden, prompted international calls to reduce US control over the Internet - a network originally created 50 years ago to connect American universities with the defense industry.

## ICANN Transition

In a surprising move last month, the US government announced plans to transfer ICANN oversight to an international body by September 2015. This transition comes with one crucial condition: the new organization cannot be under any government's control.

The debate over ICANN's future management likely represents a new point of contention, particularly with nations advocating for multilateral control through organizations like the United Nations.

China, Russia, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan have jointly proposed developing a UN-based Internet code of conduct. However, this proposal - originating from countries known for Internet censorship - is unlikely to gain widespread support at the conference.

"Most participants here favor a multi-stakeholder model for the Internet," Almeida told Reuters. "China prefers a UN treaty approach, but the UN only represents governments."

*Originally reported by Reuters, with writing by Anthony Boadle and editing by Kieran Murray and Andre Grenon*

Hiring in India has stagnated despite the country experiencing the fastest growth rate among the world's major economies.

A ManpowerGroup survey of 5,110 employers found that only 16 percent plan to increase their workforce in the quarter ending in September. The survey focused on formal sector companies, defined as those employing ten or more workers.  Data on India's informal labor market, which employs the majority of the workforce, remains limited.

"Diversity, automated recruitment, virtual reality, and remote working options are major trends expected to drive recruitment in India in 2018," AG Rao, Group Managing Director of ManpowerGroup India, said in a statement Tuesday. The service sector and wholesale and retail trade anticipate the strongest hiring outlook, with 20 percent of respondents in these sectors indicating plans to hire in the September quarter.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government is relying on robust economic growth to generate jobs before the 2019 general elections.  GDP growth has accelerated for four consecutive quarters, reaching 7.7 percent in the quarter ending in March.

Modi's 2014 campaign promised the creation of 10 million jobs.  Four years later, the actual number of jobs created remains unclear.  Government data indicates that over 12 million Indians enter the workforce annually.

While hiring isn't significantly increasing, data suggests that large-scale job losses are also absent. According to data compiled by the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE), the unemployment rate fell to 5.29 percent in May from 5.64 percent the previous month, the lowest since January.  Official government unemployment data for 2018 is not yet available.

"A significant portion of the recent growth acceleration stems from increased public administration spending," said Mahesh Vyas, CEO of CMIE.  "This is not sustainable, and therefore, the nature of the current growth imposes inherent limitations."

The Acting Inspector General of Police (IGP), Mr. Mohammed Adamu, has issued a stern warning to politicians and others who might threaten the peace and security of Nigeria in the upcoming elections. Speaking in Abuja shortly after succeeding the former IGP, Ibrahim Idris, Adamu emphasized that the police force would not hesitate to identify, isolate, and prosecute anyone attempting to undermine the nation's democracy.

"I am fully aware of the potential security threats posed by certain misguided political actors and their followers during the general elections," Adamu remarked. "To these individuals, I issue a clear warning: our nation has endured enough election-related violence. Therefore, under my leadership, the Nigeria Police will collaborate with the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) and other security agencies to ensure a peaceful and secure environment for all political parties and citizens to exercise their electoral rights freely."

The new police chief assured that the Force would respond decisively to anyone or any group intending to incite violence in the general elections slated to begin next month. "We will not hesitate to identify, isolate, and bring to justice anyone or any group that threatens our cherished democratic order. To those unrepentant offenders seeking to challenge our collective resolve, consider this message clear and unambiguous," he stated.

"In our efforts to protect law-abiding citizens during the general elections, we are prepared to deploy our powerful resources to deal firmly and decisively with electoral offenders," he concluded.

Earlier this week, Khloe Kardashian addressed reports that she was dating Tristan Thompson while he was still involved with his now-ex, Jordan Craig, who was pregnant at the time. In an Instagram story, the "Keeping Up with the Kardashians" star explained that although she was aware of Craig's pregnancy, Thompson had referred to Craig as his ex and provided "physical proof" that they were no longer together.

Craig reportedly claimed that Thompson began cheating on her just one month into her pregnancy. Kardashian and Thompson were first linked as a couple in September 2016, during which time Craig was six months pregnant. According to court documents obtained by Radar Online, Craig stated that she discovered Thompson's infidelity one month into her pregnancy. She confronted him, but he denied the allegations. Her suspicions were confirmed when she saw paparazzi photos of him with Kardashian, as per the documents.

"Their relationship went viral, and everything took a turn for the worse," Craig said in the court documents, according to Radar Online. "Every day, several articles were published worldwide mocking my new unfortunate reality, and my pregnancy became one of the most popular gossip headlines due to the woman Tristan was now publicly dating during my pregnancy."

Kardashian acknowledged that she knew Craig was pregnant when she began dating Thompson, but he assured her that he and Craig had broken up. Kardashian shared her perspective in an Instagram Story on Tuesday night, stating that she went on a blind date with Thompson. The NBA player informed her that his ex, Craig, was pregnant. This revelation made Kardashian hesitant to pursue a relationship, but Thompson assured her that he and Craig were no longer together.

"He pleaded with me that the relationship was over long before we met. He had me talk with his closest circle," she wrote on Instagram, according to TMZ. "He showed me physical proof (correspondence between the two) and had me on calls with his lawyer to prove his point. His best friends, business associates, and even his mother told me that he and his ex were broken up before we met."

Kardashian expressed her deep regret, stating she is "so completely and utterly sorry" if what she believed at the time was not true. "Truthfully, from the deepest parts of my soul, I am sorry!" she wrote. "I'm sorry for any pain that has been caused. No woman deserves to go through anything like this."

A representative for Kardashian declined to comment, and a representative for Thompson did not immediately respond to INSIDER's request for comment.

President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko extended his New Year's greetings to Ukrainians as 2018 approached, highlighting the nation's recovery from a prolonged crisis sparked by war, and its transition towards development. He emphasized the urgency of accelerating economic growth, which he asserted the government must ensure.

"The government should boost economic growth rates in the new year," Poroshenko stated in his New Year's Eve message. "We need to improve the standard of living for the majority of Ukrainians, and we can achieve this. As president, I will create the political conditions necessary for economic progress."

Poroshenko acknowledged that, although there have been some mistakes, the country is moving forward. After enduring several years of crisis due to the war, Ukraine is now shifting towards recovery and development. 

He expressed gratitude to his fellow citizens, saying, "Thank you to each of you for all that the country has achieved. This is the result of our collective efforts."

Additionally, he congratulated the hundreds of thousands of Ukrainians who have already taken advantage of the "visa-free regime" with the European Union. "I once again extend my greetings to the hundreds of thousands who have utilized the visa-free regime and to the millions who will benefit from it in the future. I congratulate us all on our determined and irreversible path toward Europe. Just last year, on this festive night, we wished for the visa-free regime, and now it has become a reality," he noted.

The president offered "sincere greetings to our international partners." He mentioned that the United States had recently decided to supply Ukraine with modern defensive weapons—a step also supported by Canada and other countries. Furthermore, the European Union extended sanctions against the aggressor nation, and the Stockholm arbitration tribunal's decision, which he likened to a Christmas gift, protected Ukraine from extremely unfavorable conditions of a previous gas contract.

The latest episode, ‘Painful Evacuation’, begins with Hannah interviewing a writer who advocates childlessness as an essential ingredient for being a committed writer. When she passes on this wisdom to Hannah, it becomes a ritualistic transfer of knowledge. However, the end of the episode offers a contrasting view. Despite being told to embrace childlessness, Hannah finds out she is pregnant when she visits the hospital due to a UTI. The doctor, someone she had a past encounter with, offers to fund her abortion, assuming that's what she wants. This highlights societal expectations and the stigma around single women and pregnancy, especially in conservative societies like India.

In a society where women often face pressure to prioritize child-rearing over their careers, it is disheartening that the burden of this choice primarily falls on women. Balancing motherhood and a career is a challenge faced by many, and it is essential to create a supportive environment that empowers women to pursue fulfilling professional lives without sacrificing their personal choices.

Reflecting on the portrayal of pregnancy on TV as a symbol of maturity, a writer expresses disappointment in how motherhood is equated with growing up. This perspective, while valid, seems to overlook the complexities faced by women in different societal contexts. In many parts of the world, especially in less privileged settings, the decision to continue a pregnancy as an unmarried woman may still be met with societal resistance, highlighting the diverse challenges women encounter based on their circumstances.

It is important to recognize that the decision to have children or not should be a personal choice, independent of societal expectations or stereotypes. Women, especially those navigating the complexities of singlehood in their thirties, should trust their instincts and not allow external opinions to diminish their sense of womanhood. Motherhood should not be viewed as a mandatory milestone but as a conscious choice that individuals should be free to make.

The portrayal of female agency and empowerment is a central theme in the HBO series "Girls," where characters grapple with societal expectations and individual autonomy.

# Electric Car Batteries: The Race for Italy's Gigafactory

The transition to electric vehicles has made battery production plants strategically crucial, reducing dependence on Asian manufacturers and maintaining relevance in the automotive sector. While raw material procurement—including lithium, nickel, cobalt, and manganese—poses challenges due to increasing global demand, recycling and remanufactured batteries offer promising solutions. Italy's National Recovery and Resilience Plan (PNRR) allocates €1 billion for the national battery, solar, and wind power industry from its €6 billion sustainable mobility infrastructure budget, potentially supporting gigafactory projects for electric vehicle batteries.

## Two Major Players Emerge

### Italvolt's Ambitious Plans
Swedish entrepreneur Lars Carlstrom's Italvolt has proposed a €4 billion investment to transform the former Olivetti site in Scarmagno, near Turin. The project promises:
- 45GWh production capacity
- 3,500 direct jobs
- 10,000 indirect jobs in related industries
- Construction beginning next year
- Production launch in 2024

However, concerns exist about Italvolt's credibility. Despite its name, the company maintains offices in both Milan and Coventry, England. Carlstrom's controversial past includes failed business ventures and unresolved debt-related legal issues.

### Stellantis's Strategic Position
The automotive giant Stellantis has recently announced plans to:
- Produce electric vehicles in Melfi, Basilicata
- Establish battery assembly operations
- Already secured two gigafactories in France and Germany through a TotalEnergies partnership

## The North-South Debate

The location of Italy's potential gigafactory has sparked regional tension:
- Turin advocates emphasize Mirafiori's available space and logistical advantages
- Melfi supporters highlight their facility's proven productivity record
- Industry experts warn that internal disputes could benefit competitors, particularly Spain

Simone Marinelli, Fiom's automotive sector coordinator, emphasizes the need for:
- A unified approach to production planning
- Careful consideration of plants currently producing diesel engines
- Avoiding worker opposition between regions

## Political Landscape

The issue has gained political attention:
- The M5S advocates for a research and development center alongside production facilities
- Piedmontese parliamentarians strongly support the Turin location
- Lucanian representatives, though fewer in number, defend Melfi's credentials as Italy's most productive automotive site

While Italy debates internal logistics, competitors like Spain stand ready to capitalize on any delays or indecision in establishing this crucial infrastructure.

KINGSLEY, MI – The Humane Society of the United States (HSUS) is offering a $5,000 reward, double its standard offering, for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible for the shooting and neglect of a two-year-old pit bull in Northern Michigan.

The dog, named Phoenix by rescuers, was discovered by a hunter near Kingsley in Grand Traverse County on November 25.  He was suffering from a gunshot wound to the back of the neck, multiple wounds covering his face and body, and severe malnourishment.  After five days of intensive care by Grand Traverse County Animal Control and Cherryland Humane Society, Phoenix died on November 30. He had stabilized but began having seizures, likely resulting from brain injuries related to the gunshot wound, which ultimately led to his death.

“Phoenix did not deserve to suffer – likely afraid and in pain – from a gunshot wound and malnourishment,” said Molly Tamulevich, Michigan state director for HSUS. “It takes a truly callous person to leave an injured dog to die. We hope this reward will encourage anyone with information about this terrible crime to come forward.”

HSUS’ animal cruelty campaign aims to raise awareness about the link between animal cruelty and human violence. Studies show a correlation between animal cruelty and other crimes, including narcotics, firearms offenses, and sexual assault.  The campaign also provides resources and support to law enforcement, social workers, educators, legislators, and families, while working to strengthen laws against animal cruelty.  “Securing the serious attention and engagement of law enforcement officials, prosecutors and residents in cases involving allegations of cruelty to animals is an essential step in protecting the whole community,” an HSUS release stated.

**Letter from Samantha Davenport**

To the Editor:

I am a regular reader of www.AllOTSEGO.com and its weekly print edition. On two occasions, I have noticed references to the Baseball Hall of Fame as "Mecca" or "the Mecca." 

While I deeply value the Hall of Fame and understand that this term might be a long-standing tradition, I find it, frankly, tone-deaf. 

I apologize for being so direct. For many, including some of our esteemed Bassett physicians, equating the Hall with the Vatican or the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem would be inappropriate. For others, again including some of our respected Bassett physicians, the term "Mecca" specifically evokes Howard University.

I am aware that we, as part of your readership, cherish our community, both locally and globally. I believe we all strive to be as inclusive as possible, and I assume your staff and sponsors share this sentiment.

Therefore, I kindly request that you consider using other expressions of high praise for our esteemed local institution.

Thank you in advance for your consideration.

Laurie Jean Nelson, born on January 16, 1953, in North Carolina, passed away on February 13, 2019. She spent her early years in Santa Barbara, where she graduated from high school in 1971. Laurie married Phil Nelson in 1980, and they enjoyed their time together in Santa Barbara before eventually settling in Lake Tahoe. Laurie had a vibrant personality, an engaging smile, and a love for laughter. She found fulfillment working in hospitality at Caesars in Lake Tahoe, cherishing the encounters with celebrities like Red Skeleton.

After retiring from the Forest Service, Phil and Laurie relocated to Boise, Idaho, seeking a milder climate and a change of scenery. In Boise, they immersed themselves in the community, with Laurie starting her own business creating glass yard art with the help of her sister-in-law. She took immense pride in this new venture. The couple enjoyed the Boise nightlife, biking along the green belt, and spending time with their pugs, particularly her beloved Cricket. Their annual trips to Hawaii for the Pro Bowl became a cherished tradition, providing them with respite and enjoyment each year.

Laurie faced a significant health scare when she suffered a massive heart attack six years ago. Despite the ordeal, she believed she survived to support Phil during his own illness in 2018, staying by his side until his passing later that year. Laurie faced her own medical challenges with determination, as she believed it was what Phil would have wanted. Now reunited with her beloved husband, Laurie leaves behind a legacy of strength and resilience. She is survived by her stepson, Shawn Nelson, his family, her sister Dundie, and her extended family.

Laurie's zest for life, her unwavering support for her loved ones, and her entrepreneurial spirit will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

After running a mobile food business for the past five years, a woman from Etna is gearing up to introduce her authentic Jamaican cuisine to a storefront at the Shoppes at Turnberry in early 2022.

Reana Jackson, born to Jamaican immigrants in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida, made her way to Columbus in 2005 with dreams of pursuing a career in journalism. However, her passion for cooking the traditional dishes of her parents' homeland, such as jerk-style cuisine, overshadowed her journalistic ambitions. Jerk-style involves dry-rubbing or wet marinating meat with a flavorful and spicy mixture.

Honoring her heritage, Jackson discovered her love for preparing meals not only for herself but also for larger groups of people. "I realized that others enjoyed my food, and I had a strong desire to cook for a wider audience," expressed Jackson.

In 2016, she took the leap to convert her passion into a profession by launching Twinado Kitchen's Jerk Shack, a mobile food business that she initially operated from tents at festivals and pop-up events. The business, named after her twin sons, aged 8, quickly gained popularity. In 2017, she upgraded to a trailer to expand her services further.

Looking towards the future, Jackson aims to establish a permanent presence at The Shoppes at Turnberry in January or February, underscoring the need for a larger space as demand for her cuisine continues to surge. "We have truly outgrown the trailer," Jackson stated. "Our customer base is growing, especially from Pickerington, and I see the potential with the area's expansion."

The exact address of the upcoming establishment is pending as the space is undergoing conversion from a storage unit located between Omezzo Restaurant & Pizzeria at 1755 Hill Road North and Goodwill at 1771 Hill Road North.

Upon opening, the 39-year-old entrepreneur plans to operate the eatery for carryout exclusively from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday through Saturday, offering an array of dishes including jerk chicken, jerk beef, various jerk seafood options, oxtail, and lamb chops. "I can't wait to share some delicious Jamaican food with our customers," added Jackson enthusiastically.

Jackson's anticipation is mirrored by city officials, who are thrilled that she has chosen Pickerington for her storefront venture.

On Monday, Dec. 13, a judge in Rochester Hills, Mich., declined the request to move 15-year-old Ethan Crumbley, charged with killing four students and injuring others in a shooting at Oxford High School, out of an adult jail. Crumbley is charged as an adult with killing four classmates and injuring seven other people in the Nov. 30 shooting at Oxford High School, about 30 miles (50 kilometers) north of Detroit.

During his probable cause conference, Crumbley’s attorney, Paulette Loftin, argued that he should be moved back to a juvenile facility, stating that he "should not be considered a menace to other juveniles." Loftin emphasized that Crumbley had no prior history of trouble and that the incident was isolated.

Assistant Oakland County Prosecutor Marc Keast countered Loftin's argument, highlighting the severity of the charges and security concerns as reasons for Crumbley to remain in an adult facility. Keast emphasized that the shooting was not an isolated incident but a planned, premeditated mass murder targeting juveniles.

Judge Nancy Carniak sided with Keast and ruled that Crumbley would remain in the adult jail. She adjourned the probable cause hearing to Jan. 7 to review witness statements and evidence. A competency exam may be ordered at a later date if requested by Crumbley's attorneys.

The school officials met with Ethan Crumbley and his parents on the morning of the shooting after a concerning drawing was found. Despite this, the Crumbleys refused to take their son home. James Crumbley had purchased the gun used in the shooting just days before, and their son had access to it.

Crumbley's parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, are also being held at the jail and face charges of involuntary manslaughter for failing to intervene on the day of the tragedy. Their hearings are scheduled for the following day, Tuesday.

The conference on Monday was a procedural hearing to prepare for a preliminary hearing set for Dec. 20, which will be rescheduled. Keast assured that steps would be taken to ensure Crumbley is separated from adult inmates at the jail to protect his safety.

Overall, the court proceedings and decisions surrounding Crumbley's case reflect the gravity of the charges and the complexities involved in addressing such a tragic event.

# Antarctica's Hidden Heat: New Evidence Supports Mantle Plume Theory

Three decades ago, a University of Colorado Denver scientist proposed an intriguing hypothesis: a mantle plume beneath Marie Byrd Land could explain both the region's volcanic activity and its distinctive topographic dome. Recent seismic imaging has now validated this theory, though it initially met with skepticism. "I thought it was crazy," admitted Hélène Seroussi of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). "The concept of such intense heat coexisting with an ice sheet seemed implausible."

A groundbreaking NASA study has now provided compelling evidence for this geothermal heat source deep beneath Antarctica. While this mantle plume doesn't pose a new or escalating threat to the West Antarctic ice sheet, it offers crucial insights into two phenomena: the sheet's rapid collapse during previous periods of climate change and its current instability.

The ice sheet's stability depends heavily on its basal lubrication—the water underneath that facilitates glacial movement. Understanding these subglacial water sources and their future behavior is crucial for predicting future ice loss to the ocean.

Beneath Antarctica's bedrock lies an intricate network of rivers and lakes, including one that rivals Lake Erie in size. These water bodies exhibit dynamic behavior, with rapid filling and draining cycles that can cause the overhead ice surface—thousands of feet thick—to fluctuate by up to 20 feet (6 meters). These movements enable scientists to calculate the volume and distribution of subglacial water.

Given the scarcity of direct measurements beneath the ice, Seroussi and colleague Erik Ivins of JPL turned to numerical modeling. They employed the Ice Sheet System Model (ISSM), a sophisticated numerical representation of ice sheet physics developed by JPL and UC Irvine researchers. Seroussi enhanced the model to account for various heat sources and transport mechanisms, including:

- Natural heating processes
- Heat transport from phase changes
- Frictional effects
- Other thermal phenomena

To validate their model, the researchers utilized surface altitude data from NASA's IceSat satellite and Operation IceBridge flights. "These observations provided crucial constraints on possible melt rates—precisely what we aimed to predict," explained Ivins. The team ran numerous simulations testing various plume parameters, given the uncertainty about the mantle plume's exact location and dimensions.

Their findings revealed that the mantle plume's energy flux cannot exceed 150 milliwatts per square meter. For context:
- Typical U.S. regions without volcanic activity: 40-60 milliwatts
- Yellowstone National Park (average): 200 milliwatts
- Individual geothermal features: Significantly higher

The simulations identified one exceptional area inland from the Ross Sea, characterized by intense water flows, requiring 150-180 milliwatts per square meter to match observations. Seismic data suggests this heat reaches the ice through a crustal rift, similar to Africa's Great Rift Valley.

Mantle plumes are theorized to be narrow streams of hot rock that rise through Earth's mantle, spreading mushroom-like beneath the crust. This concept, proposed in the 1970s, explains geothermal activity far from tectonic plate boundaries, such as in Hawaii and Yellowstone.

# The Evolution of COVID-19 Vaccine Research: Examining Common Concerns

## Historical Context
Traditionally, vaccine research focused primarily on generating neutralizing antibodies to protect against viral infections. However, the COVID-19 vaccines represent a departure from this established approach. Their unprecedented rapid global deployment has raised questions about both short-term and long-term effects on human immune system pathophysiology, with many scientists noting incomplete investigation of these impacts.

## Adverse Events Reporting
Major adverse event databases, including the UK's Yellow Card Scheme and the US Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS), have documented numerous post-vaccination outcomes. These range from anaphylactic reactions and myocarditis to fatalities. While some have dismissed these concerns, recent research has begun to validate several previously contested observations.

## Key Research Findings

### Genetic Expression Changes
A recent study revealed consistent alterations in gene expression across various immune cell types, supporting concerns about genetic impacts. The research documented:

- Changes in immune cell gene expression patterns
- Modifications to inflammatory response mechanisms
- Altered T-cell responses

### Symptom Manifestation
The study examined healthy volunteers who received a double dose of inactivated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. Researchers observed pathophysiological changes similar to those seen in actual SARS-CoV-2 infections, suggesting the vaccine may mimic infection patterns.

### Immune System Effects
Several significant findings emerged regarding immune system function:

- Consistent reductions in CD8+ T cells, crucial for protective immunity
- Increased monocyte levels, indicating immune system activation
- Enhanced NF-κB inflammatory signaling
- Reduced Type I interferon responses 28 days post-vaccination

## Statistical Context
Public Health England data from September 2021 indicated that of 600,000 cases studied, 57% occurred in vaccinated individuals. Additionally, research across 68 countries and 2,947 US counties suggested higher COVID-19-related hospitalization risks among vaccinated populations compared to those with natural immunity.

## Broader Implications
The research indicates that vaccination influences multiple health indicators, including:

- Diabetes-related markers
- Renal function
- Cholesterol metabolism
- Coagulation parameters
- Electrolyte balance

## Conclusion
These findings suggest that post-vaccination immune system changes may create increased vulnerability to various health challenges, warranting further investigation and continued monitoring of long-term effects.

# Police Facial Recognition System Raises Privacy and Legal Concerns, Watchdog Warns

A controversial facial recognition system intended to aid police in apprehending criminals may undermine public trust and potentially violate laws, according to a watchdog's warning.

Information Commissioner Elizabeth Denham expressed concerns about the surveillance software, which scans crowds and attempts to match faces against an offender database, describing it as "particularly intrusive." Her comments coincide with a critical report revealing that automated facial recognition technology (FRT) used with CCTV cameras has proven "almost entirely inaccurate."

## Key Findings and Concerns

- The system risks losing its public safety benefits due to eroding public trust
- Police forces maintain over 19 million mugshots ("custody images")
- Database includes hundreds of thousands of innocent individuals
- Technology deployed at major events, including:
  - Notting Hill Carnival
  - Sporting events
  - Music concerts
  - Shopping centers

## Accuracy Issues

A study by civil liberties groups revealed alarming statistics:

- 98% of "matches" by one police force were incorrect
- Metropolitan Police: 102 false matches out of 104 total
- South Wales Police: 2,451 incorrect matches out of 2,685 (91% error rate)
  - Only 15 arrests from 234 "correct" matches
  - Received £2.6 million Home Office grant

## Commissioner's Response

Denham emphasized that while FRT might offer significant public safety benefits, its use requires:

1. Clear evidence of effectiveness
2. Greater transparency
3. Proper legal framework
4. Protection of public rights

"It's a real step change in the way law-abiding people are monitored as they go about their daily lives," Denham stated. She has formally addressed her concerns to the Home Office and National Police Chiefs' Council, warning of potential legal action if issues remain unresolved.

## Additional Concerns

- Higher false match rates in areas with large ethnic minority populations
- Lack of transparency in implementation
- Questions about data retention, especially for innocent individuals
- Risk of Britain "sleepwalking into a surveillance state"

Big Brother Watch director Silkie Carlo concluded, "It is deeply disturbing and undemocratic that police are using a technology that is almost entirely inaccurate."

# UK Imposes Strict Travel Restrictions on India Amid COVID-19 Surge

The United Kingdom has announced its strictest travel restrictions on India following a dramatic surge in coronavirus cases. The announcement came Monday, coinciding with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's cancellation of his scheduled trip to New Delhi.

Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced that effective Friday at 0300 GMT, India would be added to Britain's "red list" of countries. This designation bans all arrivals from India except for UK or Irish nationals.

"We've made the difficult but vital decision to add India to the Red List," Hancock told Parliament. "This means anyone who is not a UK or Irish resident or a British citizen cannot enter the UK if they've been in India in the previous 10 days."

He further explained that UK and Irish residents and British citizens who have been in India within 10 days of their arrival must complete a mandatory 10-day hotel quarantine upon entry.

The measure was implemented as a precautionary step while authorities assess the COVID-19 variant first identified in India. When questioned about the effectiveness of current vaccines against this variant, Hancock expressed uncertainty but emphasized that research was underway to determine this as quickly as possible.

"Our primary concern regarding the variant first found in India is the potential reduced effectiveness of vaccines, both in terms of transmission and in reducing hospitalizations and deaths," Hancock explained. "We share similar concerns about the variant first identified in South Africa, which largely drove today's decision."

Earlier that day, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced the cancellation of his planned visit to India. While expressing his frustration with the situation, he acknowledged it was "only sensible" given the circumstances. Johnson will instead hold virtual discussions with Prime Minister Narendra Modi later this month to advance their plans for the UK-India partnership, with an in-person meeting to be rescheduled later in the year.

"Narendra Modi and I have concluded that, regrettably, I cannot proceed with the trip," Johnson stated during a visit to Gloucestershire. "Given the situation in India and the state of the pandemic there, postponing is the only sensible option. Many countries, including our own, have faced similar challenges. There's enormous sympathy for what India is currently experiencing."

Round Rock — Unless there's a complete meltdown in the final days of the season, the Round Rock Express are headed to the playoffs next week. The Express (81-53) have put the San Antonio Missions (78-56) on the ropes by winning the first two games of their crucial series. Round Rock needed just four more wins to secure the division lead going into Wednesday night.

Manager Mickey Storey expressed confidence in his team but remained cautious, stating, "I'm confident in my team, but not comfortable. Sure, I like our position. A lot of things can still happen, though. Until you've slammed the door shut, it's still open a crack."

The Express, boasting the best record in the Pacific Coast League, are so sure of their playoff spot that they have started selling tickets for the postseason. A best-of-five semifinal series against the Iowa Cubs (71-63) would kick off with games 1 and 2 at Dell Diamond next Wednesday and Thursday nights. The series would then move to Des Moines for the weekend.

Round Rock will be without their star player for the playoffs as the Houston Astros announced the promotion of left fielder Kyle Tucker once major league rosters expand next week. Tucker, a member of the All-PCL Team, achieved a rare 30-home run/30-stolen base season, making him a standout player in the league's history.

Despite the upcoming loss of Tucker, Round Rock has more immediate business to attend to. They will have the chance to clinch in their home finale on Thursday or in the season-ending series over Labor Day weekend against Omaha (57-76), which currently holds the worst record in the PCL.

The recent 6-0 and 4-3 victories on Monday and Tuesday, with stellar pitching from Jose Urquidy and Kent Emanuel and key contributions from Chas McCormick, have all but sealed the fate of the Missions. Round Rock secured the season series 9-5 and claimed the inaugural I-35 Traffic Cone trophy, crucial in potential tiebreaker scenarios.

Emanuel's dominant performance, pitching a one-hit shutout over eight innings on Tuesday, showcased his importance in Round Rock's late-season surge. His precision and preparation have been vital in his success as a starter, boasting impressive stats both on the road and at home.

The playoff push has injected a new energy and intensity into the team, with McCormick leading the offense and emphasizing the team's depth and strength at this crucial juncture. Emanuel echoed this sentiment, acknowledging the shift in focus as the team approaches the end of the regular season.

The PCL playoffs have a set format, meaning Round Rock won't have home-field advantage against Iowa in the semifinals but would secure it if they progress to the championship series, with games three, four, and five set to take place at Dell Diamond on the weekend of September 13-15. The pinnacle of the Triple-A season, the one-shot title game, will be held on September 17 in Memphis.

STOCKHOLM –  Struggling chip joint venture ST-Ericsson, owned by Ericsson and STMicroelectronics, faces an uncertain future.  The two parent companies have enlisted an external advisor to explore strategic options for the loss-making unit.  This follows media reports that JP Morgan has been engaged to review possibilities, including finding a new partner, selling assets, or even a complete sale.  French newspaper Les Echos suggested a scenario where ST-Ericsson could be sold piecemeal, with technologies like connectivity, power management, and software architecture attracting different buyers.  Remaining parts of the business might be reabsorbed by the parent companies. While no decision has been announced, one is expected by the end of the year.

ST-Ericsson continues to struggle financially.  In the second quarter, it reported an operating loss of $235 million, attributed to the collapsing demand for feature phones from clients like Nokia and Sony Ericsson, and the challenging transition to supplying chips for the smartphone market.  The company’s full-year 2011 loss totaled $841 million on sales of $1.65 billion, and it has accumulated losses of around $2 billion over its three years of operation.

While Ericsson and STMicroelectronics have publicly stated their support for ST-Ericsson's ongoing cost-cutting initiatives aimed at lowering the break-even point, analysts are skeptical about the prospects of a sale.  "The possibilities for Ericsson are limited except to hold on to its share and try and do the turnaround themselves," said Mirko Maier, analyst at LBBW. Finding a buyer for the entire business, or even substantial parts of it, appears challenging given its financial performance.

Although a sale or break-up wasn't explicitly mentioned in the official statement from the parent companies, Ericsson's head of media relations confirmed that all options are under consideration.

Over the next week, the Tallahassee Democrat is partnering with Catholic Charities on the Christmas Connection to spotlight local families who need help this Christmas. Here's how you can help:

**How to Help**

1. **Donate in Person**: Drop off donated items at the Christmas Connection warehouse at 2990-2 Apalachee Parkway, next to the Supervisor of Elections office. The warehouse is open 10 a.m.-6 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and 1-5 p.m. on Sundays. Days of operation are Nov. 20-23 and Nov. 28 to Dec. 20. The deadline for donated items is Dec. 15. Donations can also be dropped off at Morningstar Storage, 5600 Roanoke Trail, Tallahassee. Hours are 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday through Friday; 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday, and 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Sunday.

2. **Wish List**: Shop early and shop easily with the Christmas Connection Amazon wish list. You can view the wish list at the website TheChristmasConnection.org.

3. **Blanket Day**: Drop off new blankets and heaters from 10 a.m.-6 p.m. Saturday, Dec. 4, and Sunday, Dec. 5, from 1 to 5 p.m. at the Apalachee Parkway location. A volunteer will help you unload your car.

4. **Donate Online or by Mail**: Make a monetary donation online at TheChristmasConnection.org or send a check to Christmas Connection, P.O. Box 20165, Tallahassee, FL 32316.

5. **Adopt a Family**: Complete a brief request form on the website, and a family in need will be assigned to you by the volunteer adoption coordinator. All families are referred to us from social service organizations in the Big Bend area.

6. **Host a Christmas Connection Collection Drive or Holiday Party**: Gather people from your office, school, church, sports team, family, or friends and host a party or collection drive to benefit neighbors in need. You can sign up online on the website and then collect gift items, gift cards, and/or monetary donations, which can be brought to the collection site during regular operating hours.

7. **Volunteer**: You can sign up on the website to donate your time and talents. Due to COVID, there is a limit on how many people can volunteer at one time.

**Most Needed Items This Year**: Bikes, gift cards, blankets, towels, teenage gifts, heaters (electric/space), housewares, diapers, and nonperishable foods. All donations must be new.

# From Actor to Musician: A Conversation Between Ed Droste and Finn Wolfhard

## Introduction
While most know Finn Wolfhard as Mike Wheeler from Netflix's "Stranger Things," his Vancouver indie-rock band Calpurnia is far from a celebrity vanity project. The four young musicians have been playing together since before Wolfhard's rise to fame, drawing inspiration from both contemporary acts like Grizzly Bear, Mac DeMarco, and Twin Peaks, as well as classics like the Beatles, the Cars, and the Velvet Underground.

Wolfhard's success on "Stranger Things" opened doors in the music world. Through his castmate Joe Keery, he connected with Twin Peaks frontman Cadien Lake James, who went on to produce Calpurnia's debut six-track EP, "Scout," at Twin Peaks' Chicago studio.

## The Band's Formation and Creative Process
In a conversation with Grizzly Bear frontman Ed Droste, Wolfhard detailed Calpurnia's organic formation. It began when he met drummer Malcolm Craig on a PUP music video shoot, where they played younger versions of the band members. They later met guitarist Ayla Tesler-Mabe at a summer rock camp, and bassist Jack Anderson joined through Ayla's connection, completing the lineup.

The band operates as a true democracy, with all members contributing equally to the creative process. Songs typically start with one member's idea—a riff, drumbeat, or lyrics—and evolve through collaborative development. This approach extends to their studio work, where even their engineer and producer are treated as equal creative partners.

## Balancing Acting and Music
Wolfhard maintains a clear distinction between his acting and musical pursuits, though he acknowledges some overlap in areas like stage presence and improvisation. He approaches both crafts with intense focus, using music as a therapeutic tool to organize his thoughts before and after acting.

## Live Performance and Future Plans
Despite having played only five shows, Calpurnia has ambitious plans for the future. While current touring is limited by school schedules and Wolfhard's acting commitments, they aim to conduct a full North American tour after releasing their album, when other band members complete school.

## Musical Influences and Legacy
The band's sound reflects a diverse range of influences, from contemporary indie rock to classic bands. Wolfhard credits his parents for shaping 90% of his musical foundation, particularly his father's eclectic taste, which introduced him to everything from the Beatles to Future Islands.

## Conclusion
The conversation between Droste and Wolfhard reveals Calpurnia as a serious musical endeavor, grounded in genuine passion and collaborative spirit. Despite the challenges of balancing multiple creative pursuits and educational commitments, the band maintains a clear vision for their future in music.

*Calpurnia's Scout EP was released on June 15 via Royal Mountain Records.*

LARWILL, Ind. (WANE) – Whitko Community Schools have announced they will be providing a $100 stipend, funded by the Federal CARES program, to employees who receive their COVID-19 vaccination.

Superintendent Steve Darnell informed staff via email that beginning Monday, vaccinations will be offered to all K-12 educational personnel. As an incentive, the district will utilize federal CARES funding to grant a $100 stipend to all employees who get vaccinated.

The email instructed, "Once you have completed the full vaccination process (either one shot or two, depending on the vaccine brand), kindly submit a copy of your CDC vaccination card displaying your fully vaccinated status, along with a completed claim voucher to Vicki Camden. The stipend will be processed as additional pay in the subsequent payroll cycle."

Employees who schedule vaccinations during work hours are required to utilize sick or personal leave time. In case an employee experiences vaccine side effects, any additional time needed would be considered an acceptable COVID-19 leave request covered by federal Department of Labor regulations, according to the email.

Superintendent Darnell mentioned that the district is collaborating with Meijer to organize onsite vaccination clinics at Pierceton Elementary and Whitko Jr-Sr High School. Further details will be shared once they are confirmed.

"I urge you to take advantage of the $100 stipend for getting vaccinated. By collectively following CDC guidelines and protocols (such as hand washing, social distancing, and mask usage) along with the newly available vaccines, we can combat the virus together as Americans. Each positive step we take brings us closer to regaining the broader sense of normalcy we enjoyed a year ago," Superintendent Darnell emphasized.

SHREVEPORT, La. (KTAL/KMSS) – The Caddo Parish Sheriff’s Office has introduced a new facility dedicated to housing loose livestock collected by their team. This two-acre holding pen, located behind the Caddo Correctional Center, is designed to accommodate horses, cows, goats, domestic pigs, and donkeys that frequently escape from pastures and other enclosures within the parish.

The Sheriff’s Office Stock Patrol retrieves loose livestock on a weekly—and sometimes daily—basis. Some animals remain for just a few hours until their owners are found, while others may stay for several weeks. If the owners cannot be identified, the animals are advertised for ten days before being auctioned off.

“A cow or horse on the roadway after dark poses a significant risk to public safety. By law, when these animals are picked up, we must thoroughly attempt to locate the owner. This often means the animal will be housed by the Caddo Sheriff’s Office for an extended period,” explained Sheriff Steve Prator.

The new facility features three covered holding areas, a gated unloading zone, and a barn equipped with two stalls. It was constructed by the Sheriff's Office's Building and Grounds and Livestock Patrol teams.

The total cost of building the holding pen was approximately $17,000, which includes donations and in-kind services.

Tech giants have transformed our daily lives, yet governments worldwide are increasingly concerned about their growing influence. Known collectively as GAFAM—Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Microsoft—these companies face accusations of tax evasion, unfair competition, media content theft, and the spread of fake news.

As the European Union prepares to unveil measures to regulate these companies on December 15, here is a global overview of ongoing regulatory efforts:

**Taxation**

The 27-member EU has yet to reach a consensus on taxing digital giants, but individual member states are taking action. France and Italy have implemented a three percent tax on their turnover, Austria has imposed a five percent tax on advertising revenues, and Spain has introduced a three percent charge on specific activities. Outside the EU, the United Kingdom has instituted a two percent tax on certain digital services. Beyond Europe, India imposed a tax on online advertising in 2016, while Australia applied a 10 percent VAT on digital services such as streaming, downloading games and apps, e-books, and data storage. These measures have angered the United States, home to these tech giants, which has threatened reciprocal tariffs. Meanwhile, negotiations for a global tax on multinationals, led by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, stalled in October.

**Competition**

Digital giants are frequently criticized for their market dominance and sidelining of competitors. Between 2017 and 2019, the EU fined Google 8.25 billion euros ($10 billion) for market dominance via its Android system, a decision Google is contesting in court. In 2013, the EU fined Microsoft 561 million euros for forcing users of Windows 7 to use its Internet Explorer search engine. Amazon and Apple are also under investigation for potential breaches of EU competition laws. In the U.S., federal and state antitrust authorities filed lawsuits against Facebook on December 9, challenging its acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp. Additionally, in October, the Justice Department and 11 states initiated proceedings against Google for allegedly strengthening its monopoly on online searches and advertising illegally.

**Personal Data**

Tech giants frequently face criticism over their collection and use of personal data.
